editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE, AND MY SINGVLAR good Lord, PHILIP Earle of MONGOMERY, one of the Gentlemen of his Maie≈øties Bed-chamber, and Knight of the mo≈øt honourable Order of the Garter.
div.p:
AFter ≈øome vnplea≈øing intermi≈øsions, I returne to that taske of Contemplation,
wherein onely my ≈øoule findeth rest. If in other imployments I haue indeauoured to ≈øerue God and his Church, yet in none (I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe) with equall contentment. Me thinkes Controuer≈øie is not right in my way to Heauen; how euer the importunity of an aduer≈øarie may force me to fetch it in: Jf Truth oppre≈ø≈øed by an erroneous teacher cry (like a raui≈øht virgin) for my ayd, I betray it, if J releeue it not; when I haue done, I
returne gladly to the≈øe paths of peace. The fauour which my late Polemicall labour hath found (beyond merit) from the learned, cannot diuert my loue to tho≈øe wrangling ≈øtudies. How earne≈øtly doth my hart rather wi≈øh an vniuer≈øall ce≈ø≈øation of the≈øe armes; that all the Profe≈ø≈øors of the deare name of Christ might bee taken vp with nothing, but holy and peaceable thoughts of deuotion; the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe wherof hath ≈øo farre affected mee,
that (if J might doe it without danger of mi≈ø-con≈øtruction) I could beg euen of an enemy this leaue to be happy. I haue already giuen account to the world, of ≈øome expences of my houres this way, & here J bring more; which if ≈øome reader may cen≈øure as poore, none can cen≈øure as vnprofitable. J am bold to write them vnder your Honourable Name, whereto I deeply obliged; that J may leaue behind me this meane, but faithfull Te≈øtimony, of
mine humble thankefulne≈ø≈øe to your Lo: and your mo≈øt honored and vertuous Lady. The noble re≈øpects I haue had from you both, de≈øerue my prayers, & be≈øt ≈øeruices, which ≈øhall neuer bee wanting to you and yours,

closer.signed: From your Honors ≈øincerely deuoted in all true duty. IOS. HALL.

div.head: SAVL in DAVIDS Caue.
div.p:
IT was the ≈øtrange lot of Dauid, that tho≈øe whom hee pur≈øued, pre≈øerued him from tho≈øe whom hee had pre≈øerued; The Phili≈øtims, whom
Dauid had newly ≈ømitten in Keilah, call off Saul from ≈ømiting Dauid in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, when there was but an hillock betwixt him and death: Wicked purpo≈øes are ea≈øily checked, not ea≈øily broken off. Sauls ≈øword is ≈øcarce dry from the bloud of the Phili≈øtims, when it thir≈øts anew for the bloud of Dauid; and now in a renued cha≈øe, hunts him dry-foot thorow euery wilderne≈ø≈øe: The very de≈øert is too faire a refuge for innocence; The hils and rocks are ≈øearched in an angry iealou≈øie; the very wilde goats of the mountaines were not allowed to bee companions for him, which had no fault but his vertue.
Oh the ≈øeemingly-vnequall di≈øtribution of the≈øe earthly things; Cruelty and oppre≈ø≈øion raignes in a palace, whiles goodne≈ø≈øe lurkes among the rockes and caues, and thinkes it happine≈ø≈øe enough to ≈øteale a life.

Like a dead man, Dauid is faine to be hid vnder the earth, and ≈øeekes the comfort of protection in darkne≈ø≈øe: and now the wi≈øe prouidence of God leads Saul to his enemy without bloud; He, which before broght them within an hils di≈øtance without interview, brings them now both within one roofe; ≈øo as that whiles Saul ≈øeekes Dauid and findes him not, hee is found of Dauid vn≈øought. If
Saul had knowne his owne opportunities, how Dauid and his men had interred them≈øelues, he had ≈øaued a treble labour, of cha≈øe, of execution, and buriall, for had he but ≈øtopt the mouth of that caue, his enemies had layd them≈øelues downe in their owne graues: The wi≈ødome of God thinkes fit to hide from euill men, & ≈øpirits, tho≈øe means and ≈øea≈øons, which might be (if they had been taken) mo≈øt preiudiciall to his owne: Wee had been oft foyled; if Satan could but haue knowne our hearts: ≈øomtimes wee lye open to euils, and happy it is for vs that hee onely knowes it, which pitties in ≈øteed of tempting vs.

It is not long, ≈øince Saul ≈øayd of Dauid (lodged them in Keilah) God hath deliuered him into mine hands, for he is ≈øhut in, ≈øeeing hee is come into a City that hath gates and bars; but now contrarily God deliuers Saul (ere he was aware) into the hands of Dauid, and without the helpe of gates and bars, hath inclo≈øed him within the valley of the ≈øhadow of death: How iu≈øt it is with God, that tho≈øe who ≈øeeke mi≈øcheefe to others, finde it to them ≈øelues; and euen whiles they are ≈øpredding nets, are in≈ønared; Their deliberate plotting of euill, is ≈øurprized with a ≈øudden judgement.

How amazedly mu≈øt Dauid
needes looke, when he ≈øaw Saul enter into the caue, where him≈øelfe was? what is this (thinkes hee) which God hath done? Is this pre≈øence purpo≈øed, or ca≈øuall; is Saul here to pur≈øue, or to tempt me? Where ≈øuddenly the action bewrayes the intent, and tels Dauid that Saul ≈øought ≈øecrecy and not him. The ≈øuperfluity of his maliciou≈øne≈ø≈øe brought him into the wilderne≈ø≈øe, the nece≈ø≈øity of nature led him into the caue: Euen tho≈øe actions wherin we place ≈øhame, are not exempted from a prouidence. The fingers of Dauids followers itched to cea≈øe on their Ma≈øters enemy; and that they might not ≈øeeme led ≈øo
much by faction, as by faith, they vrge Dauid with a promi≈øe from God; The day is come whereof the Lord ≈øaid vnto thee, Behold I will deliuer thine enemie into thine hand, and thou ≈øhalt do to him, as it ≈øhall ≈øeeme good to thee. This argument ≈øeemed to carry ≈øuch command with it, as that Dauid not onely may, but mu≈øt embrue his hands in blood, vnle≈ø≈øe he will bee found wanting to God and him≈øelfe, tho≈øe temptations are mo≈øt powerfull, which fetch their force from the pretence of a religious obedience: Whereas tho≈øe which are ray≈øed from arbitrary and priuate re≈øpects, admit of an ea≈øie di≈øpen≈øation.

If there were ≈øuch a prediction, one clau≈øe of it was ambiguous; and they take it at the wor≈øt: Thou ≈øhalt doe to him as ≈øhall ≈øeeme good to thee: that might not ≈øeeme good to him, which ≈øeemed euill vnto God. There is nothing more dangerous then to make con≈øtruction of Gods purpo≈øes out of euentuall appearances, If carnall probabilities might be the rule of our iudgement, what could God ≈øeeme to intend other then Sauls death in offering him naked into the hands of tho≈øe whom he vniu≈øtly per≈øecuted? how could Dauids ≈øoldiers thinke that God had ≈øent Saul thither on any other errand, then to fetch his
bane, and if Saul could haue ≈øeene his owne danger, hee had giuen him≈øelfe for dead, for his hart guilty to his owne bloody de≈øires could not but haue expected the ≈øame mea≈øure which is meant: But wi≈øe and holy Dauid not tran≈øported either with mi≈øconcert of the euent, or fury of pa≈ø≈øion, or ≈øollicitation of his followers dares make no other v≈øe of this accident then the triall of his loyalty, and the inducement of his peace; It had beene as ea≈øie for him to cut the throate of Saul as his garment; but now his coate only ≈øhall be the wor≈øe, not his per≈øon; neither doth he in the moyming of a cloake ≈øeeke his
own reuenge, but a monument of his innocence. Before Saul rent Samuels garment, now Dauid cutteth Sauls; both were ≈øignificant; The rending of the one, ≈øignified the Kingdome torne out of tho≈øe vnworthy hands; the cutting of the other, that the life of Saul might haue beene as ea≈øily cut off.

Saul needs no other monitor of his owne danger, then what he weares. The vpper garment of Saul was laid a≈øide, whiles he went to couer his feete; ≈øo as the cut of the garment, did not threaten any touch of the body, yet euen this violence offered to a remote garment ≈øtrikes the hart of Dauid, which findes
a pre≈øent remor≈øe for harmefully touching, that which did once touch the per≈øon of his mai≈øter, Tender con≈øciences are moued to regret at tho≈øe actions, which ≈øtrong harts pa≈ø≈øe ouer with a carele≈ø≈øe ea≈øe. It troubled not Saul to ≈øeeke after the blood of a righteons ≈øeruant; there is no le≈ø≈øe difference of con≈øciences then ≈øtomackes; Some ≈øtomacks will dige≈øt the harde≈øt meates, and turne ouer ≈øub≈øtances, not in their nature edible, whiles others ≈øurret of the lighte≈øt food, and complaine euen of dainties: Euery gratious hart is in ≈øome mea≈øure ≈øcrupulous, and findes more ≈øafetie in feare, then in pre≈øumption: And
if it be ≈øo ≈øtrait as to curbe it ≈øelfe in from the libertie which it might take in things which are not vnlawfull, how much le≈ø≈øe will it dare to take ≈øcope vnto euill: By how much that ≈øtate is better, where nothing is allowed, then where all things; by ≈øo much is the ≈øtrict and timorous con≈øcience better then the lawle≈ø≈øe. There is good likelyhood of that man which is any way ≈øcrupulous of his wayes; but he which makes no bones of his actions, is apparently hopele≈ø≈øe.

SINCE Dauids followers pleaded Gods te≈øtimony to him as a motiue to blood. Dauid appeales the ≈øame God for his pre≈øeruation
from blood. The Lord keepe me from doing that thing to my mai≈øter the Lords anoynted; and now the good man hath worke enough to defend both him≈øelfe and his per≈øecuter, him≈øelfe, from the importunate nece≈ø≈øitie of doing violence, and his mai≈øter from ≈øuffering it. It was not more ea≈øie to rule his owne hands, then difficult to rule a multitude: Dauids troupe con≈øi≈øted of male-contents, all, that were in di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, in debt, in bitterne≈ø≈øe of ≈øoule were gathered to him: Many if neuer ≈øo well ordered, are hard to command, a few if di≈øorderly, more hard; many and di≈øorderly mu≈øt needes be
≈øo much the harde≈øt of all, that Dauid neuer atchiued any victorie like vnto this, wherein the fir≈øt ouercame him≈øelfe, then his ≈øoldiers.

AND what was the charme, wherewith Dauid allayed tho≈øe raging ≈øpirits of his followers? No other but this; He is the Anoynted of the Lord. That holy oyle was the Antidote for his blood; Saul did not lend Dauid ≈øo impearceable an Armour, when he ≈øhould incounter Goliah, as Dauid now lent him in this plea of his vnction. Which of all the di≈øconted outlawes that lurked in that caue, dur≈øt put forth his hand again≈øt Saul, when they once heard, He
is the Lords anoynted: Such an impre≈ø≈øion of awe hath the diuine prouidence cau≈øed his Image to make in the harts of men, as that it makes traytors cowards; So as in≈øteed of ≈øtriking they tremble; How much more lawle≈ø≈øe, then the outlawes of I≈ørael are tho≈øe profe≈ø≈øed Ring-leaders of Chri≈øtianity; which teach and practi≈øe, and incourage, and reward, and canonize the violation of maie≈øtie. It is not enough for tho≈øe who are commanders of others to refraine their owne hands from euill, but they mu≈øt carefully preuent the iniquitie of their heeles, el≈øe they ≈øhall bee iu≈øtly reputed to doe that by
others, which in their owne per≈øon they auoyded; the lawes both of God and man, pre≈øuppo≈øe vs in ≈øome ≈øort an≈øwerable for our charge: as taking it for granted, that wee ≈øhould not vndertake tho≈øe raynes, which we cannot mannage.

There was no rea≈øon Dauid ≈øhould loo≈øe the thankes of ≈øo noble a demon≈øtration of his loyalty; Whereto he tru≈øts ≈øo much, that hee dares call backe the man by whom he was pur≈øued; and make him iudge whether that fact had not de≈øerued a life. As his act, ≈øo his word and ge≈øture imported nothing but humble obedience, neither was there more meekene≈ø≈øe
then force in that ≈øea≈øonable per≈øwa≈øion; Wherein hee lets Saul ≈øee the error of his credulity, the vniu≈øt ≈ølaunders of maliciou≈øne≈ø≈øe, the oportunity of his reuenge, the proofe of his forbearance, the vndeniable euidence of his innocence; and after a lowly di≈øparagement of him≈øelfe, appeales to God for iudgement, for protection.

So liuely and feeling oratory did Saul finde in the lap of his garment, and the lips of Dauid, that it is not in the power of his enuy, or ill nature to hold out any longer. Is this thy voyce my ≈øonne Dauid, and Saul lift vp his voyce and wept, and ≈øaid: Thou art more righteous
then I; Hee, who≈øe harpe had wont to quiet the frenzy of Saul, hath now by his words calmed his fury; ≈øo as now hee ≈øheds teares in ≈øteed of blood: and confe≈ø≈øes his owne wrong, and Dauids integrity; And (as if he were new againe entered into the bounds of Naioth in Ramath) he prayes, and prophe≈øies good to him, whom he maliced for good; The Lord render thee good for that thou ha≈øt done to mee this day; for now behold I know that thou ≈øhalt be king. There is no hart made of fle≈øh, that ≈øome time or other relents not, euen flint and marble, will in ≈øome wether ≈øtand on dropes. I cannot think
the≈øe teares and prote≈øtations fayned. Doubtle≈ø≈øe Saul meant as he ≈øaid, and pa≈ø≈øed through ≈øen≈øible fits of good and euill: Let no man like him≈øelfe the better for good motions; the pray≈øe and benefit of tho≈øe gue≈øts is not in the receit, but the retention.

Who, that had ≈øeene this meeting, could but haue thought all had beene ≈øure on Dauids ≈øide? What can ≈øecure vs if not teares, and prayers and oathes? Doubtle≈ø≈øe Dauids men which knew them≈øelues obnoxious to lawes and creditors, began to thinke of ≈øome new refuge, as making account this new peeced league would be euerla≈øting; they looked
when Saul would take Dauid home to the court, and di≈ø≈øolue his army, and recompence that vniu≈øt per≈øecution with iu≈øt honor; when behold in the loo≈øe, Saul goes home, but Dauid and his men goe vp vnto the hold. Wi≈øe Dauid knowes Saul not to be more kinde, then vntru≈øty; and therefore had rather ≈øeeke ≈øafely in his hold, then in the hold of an hollow and vn≈øteedy friend≈øhip. Heere are good words but no ≈øecurity, which therefore an experienced man giues the hearing, but ≈øtands the while vpon his own guard. No charity bindes vs to a tru≈øt of tho≈øe, whom we haue found faithle≈ø≈øe; Credulity
vpon weake grounds after palpable di≈øapointments, is the daughter of folly: A man that is weatherwi≈øe, though he finde an abatement of the ≈øtorme, yet will not ≈øtirre from vnder his ≈øhelter whiles hee ≈øees it thicke in the winde, di≈øtru≈øt is the iu≈øt gaine of vnfaithfulne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Nabal and Abigail.
div.p:
IF innocency could haue ≈øecurd from Sauls malice, Dauid had not beene per≈øecuted; and yet vnder that wicked King, aged Samuel dies in his bed. That there might be no place for enuy, the good Prophet had retyred him≈øelfe to the Schooles. Yet hee that hated Dauid, for what hee ≈øhould bee, did no le≈ø≈øe hate Samuel for what hee had beene. Euen in the mid≈øt of Sauls malignity, there remained in his
heart impre≈ø≈øions of awfulne≈ø≈øe vnto Samuel: hee feared, where he loued not. The re≈øtraint of God curbeth the rage of his mo≈øt violent enemies, ≈øo as they cannot doe their wor≈øt. As good husbands, doe not put all their corne to the ouen, but ≈øaue ≈øome for ≈øeed, ≈øo doth God euer in the wor≈øt per≈øecutions.

SAMVEL is dead, Dauid bani≈øhed, Saul tyranizeth, I≈ørael hath good cau≈øe to mourne; it is no maruell if this lamentation be vniuer≈øall. There is no I≈øraelite that feeleth not the lo≈ø≈øe of a Samuel. A good Prophet is the common trea≈øure, wherin euery gracious ≈øoule hath a ≈øhare That man hath a dry heart, which
can part with Gods Prophet without teares.

NABAL was according to his name fooli≈øh; yet rich and mighty. Earthly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions are not alwayes accompanied with wit and grace. Euen the line of faithfull Caleb will afford an ill-condition'd Nabal. Vertue is not like vnto lands inheritable. All that is traduced with the ≈øeede, is either euill, or not good. Let no mam brag with the Iewes, that he hath Abram to his father; God hath rai≈øed vp of this ≈øtone, a ≈øonne to Caleb.

ABIGAIL (which ≈øignified her fathers ioy) had ≈øorrow enough to bee matched with ≈øo vnworthy an husband; If her
father had meant, ≈øhee ≈øhould haue had ioy in her≈øelfe, or in her life, he had not di≈øpo≈øed her to an husband (though rich) yet fond and wicked; It is like hee married her to the wealth, not to the man. Many a childe is ca≈øt away vpon riches. Wealth in our matches, ≈øhould bee as ≈øome graines or ≈øcruples in the balance, ≈øuperadded to the gold of vertuous qualities, to weigh downe the ≈øcales; when it is made the ≈øub≈øtancc of the weight, and good qualities the appendance, there is but one earth poy≈øed with another; which, where≈øoeuer it is done, it is a wonder, if either the children proue not the parents ≈øorrow,
or the parents, theirs.

NABALS ≈øheep-≈øhearing was famous; Three thou≈øand fleeces mu≈øt needes require many hands; neither is any thing more plentiful commonly then a Churles fea≈øt: What a world was this, that the noble Champion & Re≈øcuer of I≈ørael, Gods Anoynted, is driuen to ≈øend to a ba≈øe Carle for victuals? It is no mea≈øuring of men by the depth of the pur≈øe, by outward pro≈øperity. Seruants are oft-times ≈øet on hor≈øe-backe, whiles Princes walke on foot. Our e≈øtimation mu≈øt bee led by their inward worth, which is not alterable by time, nor dimini≈øhable with externall conditions.

ONE rag of a Dauid is more worth, then the ward-robes of a thou≈øand Nabals. Euen the be≈øt de≈øeruings may want. No man may be contemned for his nece≈ø≈øity; perhaps he may be ≈øo much richer in grace, as hee is poorer in e≈øtate; neither hath violence or ca≈øualty more impoueri≈øhed a Dauid, then his pouerty hath enriched him. Hee, who≈øe folly hath made him≈øelfe mi≈øerable, is iu≈øtly rewarded with neglect; but he, that ≈øuffers for good, de≈øerues ≈øo much more honour from others, as his di≈øtre≈ø≈øe is more. Our compa≈ø≈øion or re≈øpect mu≈øt be ruled, according to the cau≈øe of anothers mi≈øery.

ONE good turne requires another; in ≈øome ca≈øes not hurting is meritorious: Hee that ≈øhould examine the qualities of Dauids followers mu≈øt needes grant it worthy of a fee, that Nabals flocks lay vntouched in Carmel; but more, that Dauids Souldiers were Nabals Sheepheards; yea, the keepers of his ≈øhepheards, gaue them a ju≈øt intere≈øt in that ≈øheep-≈øhearing fea≈øt, ju≈øtly ≈øhould they haue beene ≈øet at the vpper end of the table. That Nabals ≈øheepe were ≈øafe, he might thanke his Shepheards; that his Shepheards were ≈øafe, hee might thanke Dauids Souldiers; It is no ≈ømall benefit that wee receiue in a ≈øafe
protection; well may we think our ≈øub≈øtance due, where wee owe our ≈øelues. Yet this churli≈øh Nabal doth not onely giue nothing to Dauids me≈ø≈øengers, but which is wor≈øe then nothing, ill words; Who is Dauid, or who is the ≈øonne of I≈øhai; There be many ≈øeruants now a dayes, that breake away from their Ma≈øters‚ñ™ Dauid asked him bread, he giues him ≈øtones. Nothing is more cheap then good words; the≈øe Nabal might haue giuen, and been neuer
the poorer; If he had beene re≈øolued to ≈øhut his hands, in a feare of Sauls reuenge, he might haue ≈øo tempered his deniall, that the repul≈øe might haue beene free from offence: But now his foule mouth doth not onely deny, but reuile. It ≈øhould haue beene Nabals glory, that his Tribe yeelded ≈øuch a Succe≈ø≈øor to the Throne of I≈ørael; now in all likely hood, his enuy ≈øtirs him vp to di≈øgrace that man, who ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed him in honour and vertue, more then hee was ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed by him in vertue and ea≈øe; Many an one ≈øpeaks faire, that meanes ill, but when the mouth ≈øpeakes foule, it argues a corrupt heart; If with S. Iames
his verball benefactors, wee ≈øay onely, Depart in peace, warme your ≈øelues, fill your bellies, wee ≈øhall an≈øwer for hypocriticall vncharitablene≈ø≈øe, but if wee rate & cur≈øe tho≈øe needy ≈øoules, whom we ought to releeue, wee ≈øhall giue a more fearefull account of a ≈øauage cruelty, in trampling on tho≈øe whom God hath humbled. If healing with good words bee ju≈øtly puni≈øhable, what torment is there for tho≈øe that wound with euill.

DAVID, which had all this while beene in the ≈øchole of patience; hath now his le≈ø≈øon to ≈øeeke; Hee, who had happily dige≈øted all the rayling and per≈øecutions of a wicked Ma≈øter,
