Wherefore ≈øerue the≈øe recorded weakne≈ø≈øes of holy men, but to ≈øtrengthen vs again≈øt the con≈øcience of our infirmities? not that we ≈øhould take courage to imitate them in the euill, whereunto they haue been mi≈øcarried; But we ≈øhould take heart to our ≈øelues, again≈øt the di≈øcouragement of our own euils.

THE wi≈ødome of God hath
≈øo contriued it, that commonly (in ≈øocieties) good is mixed with euill; wicked Nabal hath in his hou≈øe a wi≈øe and good ≈øeruant, a prudent and worthy wife; That wi≈øe ≈øeruant is carefull to aduerti≈øe his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe of the danger; his prudent Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe is carefull to preuent it.

THE liues of all his family were now in hazard: ≈øhe dares not commit this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to the fidelity of a me≈ø≈øenger, but forgetting her ≈øex, puts her≈øelfe into the errand; Her foot is not ≈ølow, her hand is not empty; According to the offence ≈øhee frames her ≈øatisfaction; Her husband refu≈øed to giue, ≈øhee brings a bountiful gift; her hu≈øband
gaue ill words, ≈øhee ≈øweetens them with a meeke and humble deprecation; Her hu≈øband could ≈øay, Who is Dauid? ≈øhe fals at his feet, her husband di≈ømi≈ø≈øes Dauids men empty, ≈øhe brings her ≈øeruants laden with proui≈øion; as if it had been only meant to ea≈øe the repelled me≈ø≈øengers of the carriage, not to ≈øcant them of the required beneuolence; No wit, no art could deui≈øe a more pithy and powerfull Oratory: As all ≈øati≈øfaction, ≈øo hers, begins with a confe≈ø≈øion, wherein ≈øhee deeply blameth the folly of her hu≈øband: She could not haue been a good wife, if ≈øhee had not honoured her vnworthy head; If
a ≈øtranger ≈øhould haue termed him foole in her hearing, hee could not haue gone away in peace: Now to ≈øaue his life, ≈øhe is bold to acknowledge his folly: It is a good di≈øparagement that pre≈øerueth. There is the ≈øame way to our peace in heauen; the only meanes to e≈øcape judgement, is to complaine of our owne vilene≈ø≈øe; ≈øhee pleadeth her ignorance of the fact, and therein, her freedome from the offence; ≈øhe humbly craueth acceptation of her pre≈øent, with pardon of the fault; ≈øhe profe≈ø≈øeth Dauids honorable acts and merits; ≈øhee foretels his future ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and glory; ≈øhe layes before him the happy peace of his
≈øoule, in refraining from innocent bloud. Dauids bre≈øt, which could not through the ≈øeeds of grace, grow to a ≈øtubborne≈ø≈øe in ill re≈øolutions, cannot but relent with the≈øe powerfull and fea≈øonable per≈øwa≈øions; and now, in ≈øteed of reuenge, hee ble≈ø≈øeth God for ≈øending Abigail to meet him; he ble≈ø≈øeth Abigail for her councell, hee ble≈ø≈øeth the councell for ≈øo whol≈øome efficacy, and now reioyceth more in being ouercome with a wi≈øe and gracious aduice, then he would haue reioyced in a reuengefull victory.

A good heart is ea≈øily ≈øtayed from ≈øinning, and is glad when it findes occa≈øion to bee cro≈ø≈øed
in ill purpo≈øes; Tho≈øe ≈øecret checks which are rai≈øed within it ≈øelfe, do readily con≈øpire with all outward retentiues; It neuer yeelded to a wicked motion, without much reluctation, and when it is ouercome, it is but with halfe a con≈øent; whereas peruer≈øe and obdurate ≈øinners, by rea≈øon they take full delight in euill, and haue already in their conceit ≈øwallowed the plea≈øure of ≈øin, abide not to bee re≈øi≈øted, running on headily, in tho≈øe wicked cour≈øes they haue propounded, in ≈øpight of oppo≈øition; and if they bee forcibly ≈øtopped in their way, they grow ≈øullen and mutinous. Dauid had not only vowed, but deeply
≈øworne the death of Nabal, and all his family, to the very dog that lay at his doore; yet now he prai≈øeth God, that hath giuen the occa≈øion and grace to violate it. Wicked vowes are ill made, but wor≈øe kept. Our tongue cannot tye vs to commit ≈øinne. Good men thinke them≈øelues happy, that ≈øince they had not the grace to deny ≈øin; yet they had not the opportunity to accompli≈øh it. If Abigail had fit ≈øtill at home, Dauid had ≈øinned, and ≈øhe had dyed: Now her di≈øcreet admonition hath pre≈øerued her from the ≈øword, and diuerted him from bloud≈øhed. And now, what thankes, what benedictons hath ≈øhee for
this ≈øea≈øonable Councell. How ≈øhould it encourage vs to admoni≈øh our brethren; to ≈øee that if wee preuaile, wee haue ble≈ø≈øings from them; if we preuaile not, we haue yet ble≈ø≈øings from God, and thankes of our owne hearts.

How neere was Nabal to a mi≈øcheefe, and perceiues it not? Dauid was comming at the foot of the hill to cut his throat, while hee was fea≈øting in his hou≈øe without feare; Little doe ≈øinners know, how neere their iollity is to perdition. Many time judgement is at the thre≈øhold, whiles drunkenne≈ø≈øe and ≈øurfet are at the boord. Had he beene any other then ‚Ä¢
Nabal, he
had not ≈øate downe to fea≈øt, till he had beene ≈øure of his peace with Dauid; either not to expect danger, or not to cleare it, was ≈øotti≈øh; So fooli≈øh are carnall men, that giue them≈øelues ouer to their plea≈øures, whiles there are deadly quarrels depending again≈øt them in Heauen. There is nothing wherein wi≈ødome is more ≈øeene, then in the temperate v≈øe of pro≈øperity. A Nabal cannot abound, but he mu≈øt be drunke and ≈øurfet; Exce≈ø≈øe is a true argument of folly: We v≈øe to ≈øay, that When drinke is in, wit is out; but if wit were not out, drinke would not be in.

It was no time to adui≈øe Nabal, while his rea≈øon was drowned
in a deluge of wine. A bea≈øt or a ≈øtone is as capable of good councell, as a Drunkard. Oh that the noble≈øt Creature ≈øhould ≈øo farre aba≈øe him≈øelfe, as for a little liquor, to lo≈øe the v≈øe of tho≈øe faculties, whereby he is a Man. Tho≈øe that haue to doe with drinke or phrenzy, mu≈øt be glad to watch times; So did Abigail, who the next morning pre≈øents to her husband, the view of his faults, of his danger, He then ≈øees how neere hee was to death, and felt it not. That worldly minde is ≈øo apprehen≈øiue of the death that ≈øhould haue beene, as that hee dies, to thinke he had like to haue dyed; Who would think a man could
bee ≈øo affected with a danger pa≈øt, and yet ≈øo ≈øencele≈ø≈øe of a future, yea imminent? He that was ye≈øter-night as a bea≈øt, is now as a ≈øtone; hee was then ouer-merry, now dead and lumpi≈øh; Carnall hearts are euer in extremity. If they bee once downe, their de≈øection is de≈øperate, becau≈øe they haue no inward comfort, to mitigate their ≈øorrow; What difference there was betwixt the di≈øpo≈øition of Dauid and Nabal? How oft had Dauid beene in the valley of the ≈øhadow of death, and feared no euill? Nabal is but once put in minde of a death that might haue been, and is ≈øtricken dead.

It is ju≈øt with God, that they
who liue without grace, ≈øhould dye without comfort; neither can we expect better, while wee goe on in our ≈øins. The ≈øpeech of Abigail ≈ømote Nabal into a qualme; that tongue had doubtle≈ø≈øe oft adui≈øed him well, and preuailed not; now, occa≈øions his death, who≈øe reformation it could not effect; ≈øhee meant nothing but his amendment; God meant to make that louing In≈øtrument the meanes of his reuenge: ≈øhe ≈øpeakes, and God ≈øtrikes; within ten dayes, that ≈øwound ends in death. And now Nabal payes deare for his vncharitable reproch; for his riotous exce≈ø≈øe; That God, which would not ≈øuffer Dauid to
right him≈øelfe by his owne ≈øword, takes the quarrell of his Seruant into his owne hand, Dauid hath now his ends without ≈øin; reioycing in the ju≈øt executions of God, who would neither ≈øuffer him to ≈øinne in reuenging, nor ≈øuffer his aduer≈øary to ≈øin vnreuenged.

Our louing God is more angry with the wrongs done to his ≈øeruants, then them≈øelues can be, and knowes how to puni≈øh that ju≈øtly, which we could not vndertake with wronging God, more then men haue wronged vs. He that ≈øaith, Vengeance is mine, I will repay, repayes oft-times when we haue forgiuen, when we haue forgotten;
and cals to reckoning after our di≈øcharges; It is dangerous offending any fauorite of him, who≈øe di≈øplea≈øure and reuenge is euerla≈øting.

How farre God lookes beyond our purpo≈øes? Abigail came only to plead for an ill husband; and now God makes this iourney a preparation for a better; So that in one act, ≈øhee pre≈øerud an ill husband, and wonne a good one for the future; Dauid well remembers her comely per≈øon, her wife ≈øpeeches, her gracefull carriage; and now, when mode≈øty found it ≈øea≈øonable; he ≈øendes to ≈øue to her, which had beene his ≈øuppliant; ≈øhe intreated for her
husband, Dauid treates with her for his wife; her reque≈øt was to e≈øcape his ≈øword, hee wi≈øheth her to his bed; It was a faire ≈øuite to change a Dauid for a Nabal; to become Dauids Queene, in ≈øteed of Nabals drudge; ≈øhee that learned humilitie vnder ≈øo hard a Tuter, aba≈øeth her ≈øelfe no le≈ø≈øe when Dauid offers to aduance her; (Let thine hand-maid be a ≈øeruant to wa≈øh the feet of the ≈øeruants of my Lord) None are ≈øo fit to be great, as tho≈øe that can ≈øtoope loew≈øt: How could Dauid be more happy in a wife; he finds at once piety, wi≈ødom, humility, faithfulnes, wealth, beauty? How could Abigail bee
more happy in an husband, then in the Prophet, the Champion, the Anoynted of God? Tho≈øe mariages are well made, wherein vertues are matched, and happine≈ø≈øe is mutuall.

div.head: Dauid and Achi≈øh.
div.p:
GOOD motions that fall into wicked harts, are like ≈øome ≈øparks that fall from the flint and ≈øteele, into wet tinder; light≈øome for the time, but ≈øoone out. After Sauls teares and prote≈øtations, yet is he now againe, in the wildernes with three thou≈øand men to hunt after inocent Dauid: How inuincible is the charity and loyalty of an hone≈øt hart? The ≈øame hand that ≈øpared Saul in
the caue, ≈øpares him ≈øleeping in the field; The ≈øame hand that cut away the lappe of his mai≈øters garment; caryed away his ≈øpeare; that ≈øpeare, which might as well haue caryed away, the life of the owner; is only born away for a proofe of the fidelity of the bearer. Still Saul is ≈øtrong, but Dauid victorious, and triumphs ouer the malice of his per≈øecutor; Yet ≈øtill the victor flyeth, from him whom he hath ouercome; A man that ≈øees; how farre Saul was tran≈øported, with his rancorous enuy, cannot but ≈øay, that hee was neuer more mad then when he was ≈øober; For euen after he had ≈øaid (Ble≈ø≈øed art thou my ≈øonne
Dauid, thou ≈øhalt do great things and al≈øo preuaile;) yet ≈øtill hee pur≈øues him; whom hee grants a≈ø≈øured to preuaile; what is this but to re≈øolue to loo≈øe his labour in ≈øinning? and in ≈øpight of him≈øelfe to offend? How ≈øhamefull is our inequality of di≈øpo≈øition to good? We know we cannot mi≈ø≈øe of the reward of well-doing, and yet doe it not; whiles wicked men ca≈øt away their endeauours vpon tho≈øe euill proiects, whereof they are ≈øure to faile; ≈øinne blindes the eyes and hardens the heart, and thru≈øts men into wilfull mi≈øchiefes, how euer dangerous, how euer impo≈ø≈øible; and neuer leaues them till
it haue brought them to vtter confu≈øion.

THE ouer-long continuance of a tentation, may ea≈øily weary the be≈øt patience: and may attaine that by protraction, which it could neuer doe by violence; Dauid him≈øelfe at la≈øt begins to bend vncler this triall; and re≈øolues ≈øo to flee from Saul, as that hee runnes from the Church of God; and whiles he will auoyde the malice of his ma≈øter, ioynes him≈øelfe with Gods enemies. The greate≈øt Saints vpon earth, are not alwayes vpon the ≈øame pitch of ≈øpirituall ≈øtrength; He that ≈øometimes ≈øaid (I will not be affraid for ten thou≈øand, now
≈øaies, I ≈øhall peri≈øh one day by the hand of Saul) He had wont to con≈øult with God, now hee ≈øaies thus in his owne hart; How many euident experiments had Dauid of Gods deliuerances; how certaine and cleare predictions of his future Kingdome; how infallible earne≈øt was the holy oyle, wherewith hee was anoynted, of the crowne of I≈ørael? And yet (Dauid ≈øaid in his heart, I ≈øhall now peri≈øh one day by the hand of Saul:) The be≈øt faith, is but like the twy-light, mixed with ≈øome degrees of darkne≈ø≈ø, & infidelity; We doe vtterly mi≈øreakon the greate≈øt earthly holine≈ø≈øe, if we exempt it from infirmities, It is
not long ≈øince Dauid told Saul, that tho≈øe wicked enemies of his, which ca≈øt him out from abiding in the inheritance of the Lord, did as good as bid him; Goe ≈øerue other Gods, yet now is he gone from the inheritance of God, into the land of the Phili≈øtims; That Saul might ≈øeeke him no more, hee hides him≈øelfe out of the li≈øts of the Church, where a good man would not looke for him: Once before had Dauid fled to this Achi≈øh, when hee was glad to ≈øcrabble on the doozes, and let his ≈øpittle fal vpon his beard, in a ≈øemblance of madne≈ø≈øe, that he might e≈øcape, yet now in a ≈øemblance of friend≈øhip, is hee
returned to ≈øaue that life, which he was in danger to haue lo≈øt in I≈ørael; Goliah the Champion of the Phili≈øtims, whom Dauid ≈ølew, was of Gath; yet Dauid dwells with Achi≈øh King of the Phili≈øtims in Gath; Euen among≈øt them who≈øe fore-skins he had pre≈øented to Saul, by two hundreds at once, doth Dauid choo≈øe to re≈øide for ≈øafety: How≈øoeuer it was a weakene≈ø≈øe in Dauid, thus by his league of amity to ≈øtrengthen the enemies of God, yet doth not God take aduantage of it for his ouerthrow, but giues him protection, euen where his pre≈øence offended; and giues him fauour where him≈øelfe bore iu≈øt
hatred; Oh the infinite patience and mercy of our God, who doth good to vs for our euill, and in the very act of our prouocation vpholdeth, yea, ble≈ø≈øeth vs with pre≈øeruation.

Could Saul haue rightly con≈øidered it, hee had found it no ≈ømall lo≈ø≈øe and impairing to his kingdome, that ≈øo valiant a Captaine, attended with ≈øixe hundred able ≈øoldiers, and their families ≈øhould for≈øake his land, and ioyne with his enemies; yet he is not quiet till he haue abandoned his owne ≈øtrength: The world hath none ≈øo great enemy to a wicked man, as him≈øelfe; his hands cannot be held from his owne mi≈øchiefe; hee
will needs make his friends, enemies; his enemies, victors, him≈øelfe, mi≈øerable.

DAVID was too wi≈øe, to ca≈øt him≈øelfe into the hands of a Phili≈øtim King, without a≈ø≈øurance; What a≈ø≈øurance could hee haue but promi≈øes? Tho≈øe, Dauid had from Saul abundantly, and tru≈øted them not; Hee dares tru≈øt the fidelity of a Pagan, hee dares not tru≈øt the vowes of a King of I≈ørael; There may bee fidelity without the Church, and fal≈øhood within: It need not bee any newes to finde ≈øome Turks true, and ≈øome Chri≈øtians faithle≈ø≈øe.

EVEN vnwi≈øe men are taught by experience, how
much more they, who haue wit to learne without it? Dauid had well found, what it was to liue in a Court; He therfore, whom enuy droue from the Court of I≈ørael, voluntarily declines the Phili≈øtim Court; and ≈øies for a country-habitation; It had not beene po≈ø≈øible for ≈øo noted a ≈øtranger, after ≈øo much Phili≈øtim-bloud ≈øhed, to liue long in ≈øuch eminency, among≈øt the prea≈øe of tho≈øe, who≈øe ≈øons, or brothers, or fathers, or allies, he had ≈ølaughtered, without ≈øome perilous machination of his ruine; therfore he makes ≈øuit for an earely remoue: (For why ≈øhould thy ≈øeruant dwell in the cheefe City of the Kingdome
with thee?) Tho≈øe that would ≈øtand ≈øure, mu≈øt not affect too much height, or con≈øpicuity; The tall Cedars are mo≈øt ≈øubiect to winds and lightnings, whiles the ≈øhrubs of the valleyes ≈øtand vnmooued; Much greatne≈ø≈øe doth but make a fairer marke for euill; There is true firmne≈ø≈øe and ≈øafety in mediocrity.

How rarely is it ≈øeene, that a man lo≈øeth by his mode≈øty? The change fell out well to Dauid of Ziklag, for Gath; Now he hath a City of his owne; All I≈ørael, where he was anoynted, afforded him not ≈øo much po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: Now the City, which was anciently a≈ø≈øigned to Iudah, returnes to the iu≈øt Owner; and
is by this meanes entayled to the Crowne of Dauids Succe≈ø≈øours. Be≈øides, that now might Dauid liue out of the ≈øight, and hearing of the Phili≈øtim Idolatries, and enioy God no le≈ø≈øe in the wals of a Phili≈øtim-City, then in an I≈øraeliti≈øh wilderne≈ø≈øe; withall, an happy opportunity was now opened to his friends of I≈ørael, to re≈øort vnto his ayd; the heads of the thou≈øands that were of Mana≈ø≈øeh, and many valiant Captaines of the other Tribes, fell dayly to him, and rai≈øed his ≈øix hundred followers to an army, like the Ho≈øt of God. The de≈øerts o≈ø I≈ørael could neuer haue yeelded Dauid ≈øo great an aduantage: That
God, who≈øe the earth is makes room for his own euery-where; and oft times prouideth them a forraine home, more kindely then the natiue; It is no matter for change of our ≈øoyle, ≈øo wee change not our God; If we can euery where acknowledge him, hee will no where bee wanting to vs.

It was not for Gods Champion to be idle; no ≈øooner is he free from Sauls ≈øword, then hee begins an offen≈øiue war again≈øt the Amalekites, Girzites, Ge≈øhurites: Hee knew the≈øe Nations branded by God to de≈øtruction; neither could his increa≈øing army be maintained with a little‚ñ™ By one act therefore, he both reuenges
for God, and prouides for his Ho≈øt. Had it not beene for that old quarrell, which God had with this people, Dauid could not be excu≈øed from a bloudy cruelty, in killing whole Countries, onely for the benefit of the ≈øpoyle: Now his Souldiers were at once, Gods Executioners, and their owne Forragers. The interuention of a command from the Almighty, alters the ≈øtate of any act; and makes that worthy of prai≈øe, which els were no better then damnable. It is now Iu≈øtice, which were otherwi≈øe murder; The will of God is the rule of good; what neede we enquire into other rea≈øons,
of any act or determination, when wee heare it comes from Heauen?

How many hundred yeeres had this brood of Cananites liued ≈øecurely in their Country; ≈øince God commanded them to bee rooted out, and now promi≈øed them≈øelues the certaine≈øt peace? The Phili≈øtims were their friends, if not their Lords; The I≈øraelites had their hands full, neither did they know any grudge betwixt them and their neighbours, when ≈øuddenly the ≈øword of Dauid cuts them off, and leaues none aliue to tell the newes.

THERE is no ≈øafety in protraction; with men, delay cau≈øeth
forgetfulne≈ø≈øe, or abates the force of anger; as all violent motions are weake≈øt at the furthe≈øt; but with him, to whom all times are pre≈øent, what can be gained by prorogation? Alas, what can it preuaile any of the cur≈øed ≈øeed of Canaan, that they haue made a truce with Heauen, and a league with Hell? Their day is comming, and is not the further off, becau≈øe they expect it not.

MISERABLE were the ≈øtraits of Dauid; while he was driuen, not onely to maintaine his army by ≈øpoyle, but to colour his ≈øpoyle by a ≈øinfull di≈ø≈øimulation; He tels Achi≈øh, that he had beene rouing again≈øt the South
or Iudah, and the South of the Ierahmelites, and the South of the Kenites; either fal≈øely, or doubtfully, ≈øo as hee meant to deceiue him, vnder whom hee liued, and by whom hee was tru≈øted: If Achi≈øh were a Phili≈øtim, yet hee was Dauids frend, yea his Patron; and if hee had beene neither, it had not becomne Dauid to bee fal≈øe. The infirmities of Gods children neuer appeare, but in their extremities. It is hard for the be≈øt man, to ≈øay, how far he will bee tempted. If a man wil put him≈øelfe among Phili≈øtims, hee cannot promi≈øe to come forth innocent.

How ea≈øily doe we beleeue
that which we wi≈øh; The more credit Achi≈øh giues vnto Dauid, the more ≈øin it was to deceiue him. And now the conceit of this ingagement, procures him a further ≈øeruice. The Phili≈øtims are a≈ø≈øembled to fight with I≈ørael; Achi≈øh dares tru≈øt Dauid on his ≈øide; yea, to keepe his head for euer; neither can Dauid: do any le≈ø≈øe then promi≈øe his ayd again≈øt his owne fle≈øh: Neuer was Dauid, in all his life, driuen to ≈øo hard an exigent: neuer was hee ≈øo extremely perplexed; For what ≈øhould he do now‚ñ™ To fight with Achi≈øh, he was tyed by promi≈øe, by merit‚ñ™ Not to fight again≈øt I≈ørael, hee was tyed by his calling, by his
vnction; Not to fight for Achi≈øh, were to bee vnthankfull; To fight again≈øt I≈ørael, were to be vnnaturall; Oh what an inward battle mu≈øt Dauid needes haue in his bre≈øt, when he thinks of this battle of I≈ørael, and the Phili≈øtims; How doth he wi≈øh now, that hee had rather ≈øtood to the hazard of Sauls perfecution, then to haue put him≈øelfe vpon the fauour of Achi≈øh; He mu≈øt fight on one ≈øide, and on whether ≈øide ≈øoeuer hee ≈øhould fight, he could not auoyd to be treacherous; a condition wor≈øe then death, to an hone≈øt heart; which way hee would haue re≈øolued, if it had comne to the execution, who can know, ≈øince
him≈øelfe was doubtfull? either cour≈øe had beene no better then de≈øperate. How could the I≈øraelites euer haue receiued him for their King, who in the open field, had fought again≈øt them? And contrarily, if hee would haue fought again≈øt his frend, for his enemy; again≈øt Achi≈øh for Saul, he was now inuironed with jealous Phili≈øtims; and might rather looke for the puni≈øhment of his trea≈øon, then the glory of a victory.

HIS heart had led him into the≈øe ≈øtraits; the Lord findes a way to lead him out: The ≈øugge≈øtions of his enemies do herein befrend him; The Princes of the Phili≈øtims (whether of enuy,
or ≈øu≈øpition) plead for Dauids di≈ømi≈ø≈øion, (Send this fellow back, that he may goe againe to his place, which thou ha≈øt appoynted him, and let him not goe downe to the battle, le≈øt he be an aduer≈øary to vs.) No aduocate could haue ≈øaid more, him≈øelfe dur≈øt not haue ≈øayd ≈øo much. Oh the wi≈ødome, and goodne≈ø≈øe of our God, that can rai≈øe vp an aduer≈øary to deliuer out of tho≈øe euils, which our frends cannot; That by the ≈øword of an enemy, can let out that apo≈øtume, which no Phy≈øician could tell how to cure: It would be wide with vs ≈øomtimes, if it were not for others malice.

There could not bee a more
ju≈øt que≈øtion, then this of the Phili≈øtim Princes, What doe the≈øe Hebrewes here? An I≈øraelite is out of his element, when he is in an army of Phili≈øtims: The true ≈øeruants of God are in their due places, when they are in oppo≈øition to his enemies. Profe≈ø≈øion of ho≈øtility becomes them better then leagues of amity.

YET Achi≈øh likes Dauids conuer≈øation and pre≈øence ≈øo well, that he profe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelfe plea≈øed with him, as with an Angell of God; How ≈øtrange it is to heare, that a Phili≈øtim ≈øhould delight in that holy man, whom an I≈øraelite abhors, and ≈øhould be loth to be quit of Dauid, whom Saul hath expelled.
Termes of ciuility be equally open to all religions, to all profe≈ø≈øions: The common graces of Gods children, are able to attract loue from the mo≈øt ob≈øtinate enemies of goodne≈ø≈øe; If we affect them for by-re≈øpects of valour, wi≈ødome, di≈øcour≈øe, wit, it is their prai≈øe, not ours, But if for diuine grace and religion, it is our prai≈øe with theirs.

SVCH now was Dauids condition, that hee mu≈øt plead for that he feared, and argue again≈øt that which hee de≈øired: (What haue I done? and what hast thou found in thy ≈øeruant, that I may not goe, and fight again≈øt the enemies of my Lord the King?) Neuer any newes could bee more cordiall
to him then this, of his di≈ømi≈ø≈øion; yet mu≈øt he ≈øeeme to ≈øtriue again≈øt it, with an importunate profe≈ø≈øion of his forwardne≈ø≈øe to that act, which hee mo≈øt dete≈øted.

One degree of di≈ø≈øimulation drawes on another; tho≈øe which haue once giuen way to a faulty cour≈øe, cannot ea≈øily, either ≈øtop or turne backe; but are in a ≈øort forced to ≈øecond their ill beginnings, with wor≈øe proceedings. It is a dangerous and mi≈øerable thing, to ca≈øt our ≈øelues into tho≈øe actions, which draw with them a nece≈ø≈øity, either of offending, or mi≈øcarriage.

div.head: Saul and the Witch of Endor.
div.p:
EVEN the wor≈øt men may ≈øomtimes make head again≈øt ≈øome ≈øinnes. Saul hath expelled the Sorcerers out of the land of I≈ørael; and hath forbidden magicke vpon paine of death. He that had no care to expell Satan out of his owne heart, yet will ≈øeeme to driue him out of his kingdome. That wee ≈øee wicked men oppo≈øe them≈øelues to ≈øome ≈øinnes,
there is neither maruell, nor comfort in it: No doubt Satan made ≈øport at this edict of Saul; what cares he to be bani≈øhed in ≈øorcery, whiles he is entertained in malice? He knew and found Saul his; whiles he re≈øi≈øted; and ≈ømiled to yeeld thus farre vnto his va≈ø≈øall: if wee quit not all ≈øinnes, he will be content wee ≈øhould, either abandon or per≈øecute ≈øome.

Where is‚ñ™ no place for holy feare, there will be place for the ≈øeruile; The gracele≈ø≈øe heart of Saul was a≈øtonied at the Phili≈øtims; yet was neuer moued at the frowns of that God, who≈øe anger ≈øent them, nor of tho≈øe ≈øinnes of his, which procured
them. Tho≈øe that cannot feare for loue, ≈øhall tremble for feare: and how much better is awe then terror? preuention then confu≈øion? There is nothing more lamentable to ≈øee a man laugh when hee ≈øhould feare; God ≈øhall laugh when ≈øuch a ones feare commeth:

Extremiry of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, will ≈øend euen the prophane≈øt man to God; like as the drowning man, reacheth out his hand to that bow, which he contemned whiles hee ≈øtood ≈øafe on the banke; Saul now asketh coun≈øell of the Lord; who≈øe Prophet he hated, who≈øe prie≈øts he ≈ølue, who≈øe anoynted he per≈øecutes; Had Saul con≈øulted with God
when he ≈øhould, this euill had not beene; but now, if this euill had not beene; he had con≈øulted with God; The thanke of this act is due, not him, but to his affection; A forced piety is thankele≈ø≈øe, and vnprofitable; God will not an≈øwere him neither by dreames, nor by vrim, nor by Prophets. Why ≈øhould God an≈øwer, that man by dreames, who had re≈øi≈øted him waking? Why ≈øhould he an≈øwer him by vrim, that had ≈ølaine his Prie≈øts? Why ≈øhould he an≈øwer him by Prophets, who hated the Father of the Prophets, rebelled again≈øt the word of the Prophets?

It is an vnrea≈øonable vnequality
to hope to finde God at our command, when wee would not be at his; To looke that God ≈øhould regard our voyce in trouble, when wee would not regard his, in peace.

Vnto what mad ≈øhiftes are men driuen by de≈øpaire? If God will not an≈øwer, Satan ≈øhall; (Saul ≈øaid to his ≈øeruants, ≈øeeke me a woman that hath a familiar ≈øpirit) If Saul had not known this cour≈øe Diueli≈øh, why did he decree to bani≈øh it, to mulct it with death? yet now again≈øt the ≈øtreame of his con≈øcience, he will ≈øeeke to tho≈øe whom he had condemned; There needs no other iudge of Sauls act then him≈øelfe; had hee not before
oppo≈øed this ≈øinne, he had not ≈øo haynou≈øly ≈øinned in committing it; There cannot bee a more fearefull ≈øigne of an heart giuen vp to a reprobate ≈øence, then to ca≈øt it ≈øelfe wilfully into tho≈øe ≈øinnes, which it hath proclaimed to dete≈øt. The declinations to euill are many times in≈øen≈øible, but when it breakes forth into ≈øuch apparant effects, euen others eies may di≈øcerne it; What was Saul the better to fore-know the i≈ø≈øue of his approaching battaile? If this con≈øultation could haue ≈øtrengthned him again≈øt his enemies, or promoted his victory, there might haue bene ≈øome colour for ≈øo foule an act; Now, what
could hee gaine, but the ≈øati≈øfying of his bootle≈ø≈øe curio≈øity; in fore-≈øeeing that, which hee ≈øhould not be able to auoyd?

Fooli≈øh men giue a way their ≈øoules for nothing; The itch of impertinent and vnprofitable knowledge, hath beene the heriditary di≈øtroyer of the ≈øonnes of Adam and Eue; How many haue peri≈øhed to know that which hath procured their peri≈øhing? How ambitious ≈øhould wee bee to know tho≈øe things, the knowledge wherof is eternall life.

Many a leud office are they put to; which ≈øerue wicked ma≈øters; one while Sauls ≈øeruants are ≈øet to kill innocent Dauid;
another while, to ≈øhed the blood of Gods Prie≈øts; and now they mu≈øt goe ≈øeeke for a Witch: It is no ≈ømall happine≈ø≈øe to attend them, from whom we may receiue precepts and examples of vertue.

Had Saul bene good, he had needed no di≈øgui≈øe; Hone≈øt actions neuer ≈øhame the doers; Now that hee goeth about a ≈øinfull bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, hee changeth him≈øelfe; he ≈øeekes the ≈øhelter of the night, he takes but two followers with him; It is true, that if Saul had comne in the port of a King, the Witch had as much di≈ø≈øembled her condition, as now he di≈ø≈øembleth his; yet it was not only de≈øire to
≈øpeed, but guiltine≈ø≈øe that thus altred his habit; ≈øuch is the power of con≈øcience, that euen tho≈øe who are mo≈øt affected to euill, yet are a≈øhamed to bee thought ≈øuch as they de≈øire to be.
Saul needed another face to fit that tongue, which ≈øhould ≈øay (Coniecture to me by the familiar ≈øpirit, and bring me vp whom I ≈øhall name vnto thee;) An obdurate heart can giue way to any thing:

Notwith≈øtanding, the peremptory edict of Saul, there are ≈øtill Witches in I≈ørael: Neither good lawes nor carefull executions, can purge the Church from Malefactors; There will ≈øtill be ≈øome that will ieopard
their heads vpon the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt ≈øins; No garden can bee ≈øo curiou≈øly tended, that there ≈øhould not be one weed left in it. Yet ≈øo farre can good ≈øtatutes, and due inflictions of puni≈øhment vpon offenders, preuaile that mi≈øcheeuous per≈øons are glad to pull in their heads; and dare not doe ill, but in di≈øgui≈øe and darkne≈ø≈øe. It is no ≈ømall aduantage of Iu≈øtice, that it affrights ≈øin, if it cannot be expelled; As contrarily, wofull is the condition of that place, where is a publique profe≈ø≈øion of wickedne≈ø≈øe.

This Witch was no le≈ø≈øe crafty then wicked; ≈øhe had before (as is like) bribed Officers to
e≈øcape inditement, lurke in ≈øecrecy; and now ≈øhee will not worke her feats without ≈øecurity; her ≈øu≈øpition proiects the wor≈øt; (Wherefore ≈øeeke≈øt thou to take me in a ≈ønare, to cau≈øe me to dye?) Oh vaine Sorcere≈ø≈øe, that could bee wary to auoyd the puni≈øhment of Saul, carele≈ø≈øe to auoyd the judgement of God; Could wee fore-thinke what our ≈øinne would co≈øt vs, we dur≈øt not, but bee innocent: This is a good and ≈øea≈øonable an≈øwer for vs, to make vnto Satan, when he ≈øollicites vs to euill (Wherefore ≈øeeke≈øt thou to take me in a ≈ønare, to cau≈øe me to dye?) Nothing is more ≈øure then this intention in the tempter, then this euent in the
i≈ø≈øue; Oh that we could but ≈øo much feare the eternall paines, as wee doe the temporary, and bee but ≈øo carefull to ≈øaue our ≈øoules from torment, as our bodies.

No ≈øooner hath Saul ≈øworne her ≈øafety, then ≈øhee addre≈ø≈øeth her to her ≈øorcery; Hope of impunity drawes on ≈øinne with boldne≈ø≈øe; were it not for the delu≈øions of fal≈øe promi≈øes, Satan ≈øhould haue no Clients. Could Saul be ≈øo ignorant, as to thinke that Magick had power ouer Gods decea≈øed Saints, to rai≈øe them vp; yea, to call them downe from their re≈øt? Time was, when Saul was among the Prophets. And yet now, that
he is in the impure lodg of Diuels, how ≈øencele≈ø≈øe he is, to ≈øay, Bring me vp Samuel? It is no rare thing, to lo≈øe euen our wit and judgement together with graces; How ju≈øtly are they giuen ouer to ≈øotti≈øhne≈ø≈øe, that haue giuen them≈øelues ouer to ≈øin?

The Sorcere≈ø≈øe (it ≈øeemes) exerci≈øing her coniurations in a roome apart, is informed by her Familiar, who it was that ≈øet her on worke; ≈øhee can therefore finde time, in the mid≈øt of her exorci≈ømes, to binde the a≈ø≈øurance of her owne ≈øafety, by expo≈øtulation, Shee cryed with a loud voyce, Why ha≈øt thou deceiued mee, for thou art Saul,) The very name of Saul was an accu≈øation; Yet
is hee ≈øo far from ≈øtriking his bre≈øt, that doubting le≈øt this feare of the Witch, ≈øhould interrupt the de≈øired worke, hee encourages her, whom he ≈øhould haue condemned; (Be not afraid;) He that had more cau≈øe to feare, for his owne ≈øake, in an expectation of ju≈øt judgement, cheeres vp her, that feared‚ñ™ nothing but him≈øelfe: How ill doth it become vs, to giue that coun≈øell to others, whereof wee haue more need and v≈øe in our owne per≈øons?

As one that had more care to ≈øatisfie his curio≈øity, then her ≈øu≈øpicion, he asks, What ≈øawe≈øt thou? Who would not haue looked, that Sauls haire ≈øhould haue ≈øtared
on his head, to heare of a ≈øpirit rai≈øed? His ≈øinne hath ≈øo hardened him, that hee rather plea≈øes him≈øelfe in it, which hath nothing in it but horror; So far is Satan content to de≈øcend to the ≈øeruice of his ≈øeruants, that he will approue his fained obedience to their very outward ≈øences; What forme is ≈øo glorious, that hee either cannot, or dare not vndertake? Here Gods a≈øcend out of the earth; El≈øewhere Satan transformes him into an Angell of light; What wonder is it, that his wicked In≈øtruments appeare like Saints in their hypocriticall di≈ø≈øimulation? If wec will bee iudging by the appearance, we ≈øhall be ≈øure
to erre: No eie could di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt the true Samuel, and a fal≈øe ≈øpirit. Saul, who was well worthy to bee deceiued, ≈øeeing tho≈øe gray haires, and that mantle, inclines him≈øelfe to the ground, and bowes him≈øelfe; Hee that would not wor≈øhip God in Samuel aliue, now wor≈øhips Samuel in Satan; and no meruel; Satan was now become his refuge in ≈øtead of God; his Vrim was darkne≈ø≈øe, his Prophet a Gho≈øt: Euery one that con≈øults with Satan, wor≈øhips him, though hee bow not, neither doth that euill ≈øpirit de≈øire any other reuerence, then to bee ≈øought to.

How cunningly doth Satan
re≈øemble, not onely the habit and ge≈øture, but the language of Samuel, Wherefore ha≈øt thou di≈øquieted me, and wherefore doe≈øt thou aske of mee, ≈øeeing the Lord is gone from thee, and is thine enemy? Nothin is more plea≈øing to that euill one, then to be ≈øolicited, yet in the per≈øon of Samuel, hee can ≈øay, Why ha≈øt thou di≈øquieted mee? Had not the Lord beene gone from Saul, he had neuer comne to the diuelli≈øh Oracle of Endor, and yet the counterfetting ≈øpirit can ≈øay, Why do≈øt thou aske of mee, ≈øeeing the Lord is gone from thee? Satan cares not how little he is knowne to bee him≈øelfe; hee loues to pa≈ø≈øe vnder any forme, rather then his owne.

The more holy the per≈øon is, the more carefully doth Satan act him, that by his ≈øtale he may en≈ønare vs. In euery motion it is good to try the ≈øpirits, whether they bee of God; Good words are no meanes, to di≈øtingui≈øh a Prophet from a Deuill; Samuel him≈øelfe, whiles hee was aliue, could not haue ≈øpoken more grauely, more ≈øeuerely, more diuinely, then this euill Gho≈øt, For the Lord will rent thy Kingdome out of thy hand, and giue it thy neighbour Dauid, becau≈øe thou obeyedst not the voyce of the Lord, nor executed≈øt his fierce wrath vpon the Amalekites, therefore hath the Lord done this vnto thee this day: When the Diuell him≈øelfe puts on grauity and religion,
who can maruell at the hypocri≈øie of men? Well may lewd men bee good Preachers, when Satan him≈øelfe can play the Prophet; Where are tho≈øe Ignorants, that thinke charitably of charmes and ≈øpels, becau≈øe they finde nothing in them, but good words? What Prophet could ≈øpeake better words, then this Diuell in Samuels mantle? Neither is there at any time ≈øo much danger of that wicked ≈øpirit, as when hee ≈øpeakes be≈øt.

I could wonder to heare Satan preach thus prophetically, if I did not know, that as he was once a good Angell, ≈øo hee can ≈øtill act what hee was; Whiles
Saul was in con≈øultation of ≈øparing Agag, we ≈øhall neuer finde that Satan would lay any block in his way; Yea, then he was a prompt Orator, to induce him into that ≈øin; now that it is pa≈øt & gone; he can lade Saul with fearfull denunciations of judgment; Till wee haue ≈øinn'd, Satan is a Para≈øite, when wee haue ≈øinn'd, hee is a Tyrant: What cares hee to flatter any more, when hee hath what hee would? Now his onely worke is to terrifie, and confound, that hee may enioy what hee hath won; How much better is it ≈øeruing that Ma≈øter, who when wee are mo≈øt deiected with the con≈øcience of euill, heartens
vs with inward comfort, and ≈øpeakes peace to the ≈øoule, in the mid≈øt of tumult?

div.head: Ziglag ≈øpoyled and reuenged.
div.p:
HAD not the King of the Phili≈øtims ≈øent Dauid away earely, his wiues, & his people and ≈øub≈øtance, which he left at Ziglag had beene vtterly lo≈øt; Now Achi≈øh did not more plea≈øure Dauid in his intertainment, then in his di≈ømi≈ø≈øion. Saul was not Dauids enemy more in the per≈øecution of his per≈øon, then in the forbearance
of God enemies; Behold, thus late doth Dauid feele the ≈ømart of Sauls ≈øin, in ≈øparing the Amalekites; who, if Gods ≈øentence had beene duely executed, had not now ≈øuruiued, to annoy this parcell of I≈ørael.
As in ≈øpirituall re≈øpects, our ≈øins are alwayes hurtfull to our ≈øelues, ≈øo in temporall, oft-times preiudiciall to po≈øterity; A wicked man de≈øerues ill of tho≈øe, he neuer liued to ≈øee.

It was ≈øtill the lot of Amalek, to take I≈ørael at all aduantages; vpon their fir≈øt coÃÑming out of Aegypt, when they were weary, weake, and vnarmed, then did Amalek a≈ø≈øault them: And now, when one part of I≈ørael was in the field again≈øt the Phili≈øtims, another was gone with the Phili≈øtims again≈øt I≈ørael; the Amalakites ≈øet vpon the coa≈øts of
both; and goes away laded with the ≈øpoyle: No other is to be ex≈øpected of our ≈øpirituall aduer≈øaries, who are euer readie≈øt to a≈ø≈øayle, when we are the vnreadie≈øt to defend.

It was a wofull ≈øpectacle for Dauid and his Souldiers, vpon their returne to finde ruines and a≈øhes in ≈øteed of hou≈øes, and in ≈øteed of their families, ≈øolitude; Their citie was vani≈øhed into ≈ømoake, their hou≈øholds into captiuity; neither could they know whom to accu≈øe, or where to enquire for redre≈ø≈øe; whiles they made account that their home ≈øhould recompence their tedious journey with comfort, the mi≈øerable de≈øolation
of their home doubles the di≈øcomfort of their journey; what remained there but teares and lamentations? They lifted vp their voices, and wept, till they could weepe no more‚ñ™ Heere was plenty of nothing but mi≈øery and ≈øorow. The heart of euery I≈øraelite was brim-full of griefe; Dauids ran ouer; for be≈øides that his cro≈ø≈øe was the ≈øame with theirs, all theirs was his alone; each man lookt on his fellow as a partner of affliction, but euery one lookt vpon Dauid as the cau≈øe of all their affliction; and (as common di≈øplea≈øure is neuer but fruitfull of reuenge) they all agree to ≈øtone him as the
auther of their vndoing, whom they followed all this while, as the hopefull meanes of their aduancements.

Now Dauids lo≈ø≈øe is his lea≈øt griefe; neither (as if euery thing had con≈øpired to torment him) can he looke be≈øides the aggrauation of his ≈øorrow and danger; Saul and his ≈øouldiers had hunted him out of I≈ørael; the Phili≈øtim Courtiers had hunted him from the fauour of Achi≈øh; the Amalekites ≈øpoyled him in Ziglag; yet all the≈øe are ea≈øie aduer≈øaries in compari≈øon of his owne; his owne followers are ≈øo farre from pittying his participation of the lo≈ø≈øe, that they are ready to kill him, becau≈øe
they are mi≈øerable with him. Oh the many and grieuous perplexities of the man after Gods owne heart; If all his traine had ioyned their be≈øt helpes for the mitigation of his griefe, their cordials had beene too weake, but now the vexation that ari≈øes from their fury, and malice, drowneth the ≈øen≈øe of their lo≈ø≈øe, and were enough to di≈øtract the mo≈øt re≈øolute heart; why ≈øhould it be ≈øtrange to vs, that we meete with hard tryals, when wee ≈øee the deare anoynted of God thus plunged into euils?

What ≈øhould the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Son of I≈øhai now doe? whether ≈øhould he thinke to turne him?
to goe backe to I≈ørael hee dur≈øt not; to goe to Achi≈øh he might not; to abide among≈øt tho≈øe wa≈øte heapes he could not; or if there might haue beene harbor in tho≈øe burnt walls, yet there could bee no ≈øafety to remaine with tho≈øe mutinous ≈øpirits. (But Dauid comforted him≈øelfe in the Lord his God;) oh happy and ≈øure refuge of a faithfull Soule; The earth yeelded him nothing, but matter of di≈øcon≈øolation, and heauines; he lifts his eyes aboue the hills, whence commeth his ≈øaluation; It is no meruaile that God remembred Dauid in all his troubles; Since Dauid in all his troubles, did thus remember
his God; hee knew that though no mortall eye of rea≈øon; or ≈øen≈øe could di≈øcerne any eua≈øi≈øion from the≈øe intricate euils, yet that the eye of diuine prouidence had de≈øcryed it long before; and that though no humane power could make way for his ≈øafety, yet that the ouerruling hand of his God, could doe it with ea≈øe; His experience had a≈ø≈øured him of the fidelity of his Guardian in heauen; and therfore he comforted him≈øelfe in the Lord his God.

In uaine is comfort expected from God, if wee con≈øult not with him. Abiathar the Prie≈øt is called for; Dauid was not in the court of Achi≈øh, without the
Prie≈øt by his ≈øide; nor the Prie≈øt without the Ephod; Had the≈øe beene left behinde in Ziglag, they had beene mi≈øcarried with the re≈øt, and Dauid had now beene hopele≈ø≈øe. How well it ≈øucceedes to the great, when they take God with them in his Mini≈øters, in his ordinances? As contrarily, when the≈øe are layd by, as ≈øuperfluous, there can be nothing but vncertainty of ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, or certainty of mi≈øcheefe. The pre≈øence of the Prie≈øt and Ephod, would haue little auailed him without their v≈øe; by them he askes coun≈øell of the Lord in the≈øe ≈øtraits. The mouth and eares of God, which were ≈øhut vnto Saul, are open
vnto Saul, are open vnto Dauid; no ≈øooner can he aske, then hee receiues an≈øwer; and the an≈øwer that he receiues is full of courage and comfort. (Follow, for thou ≈øhalt ≈øurely ouertake them, and recouer all) That God of truth, neuer di≈øappoynted any mans tru≈øt. Dauid now findes, that the eye which waited vpon God, was not ≈øent away weeping.

Dauid therfore, and his men, are now vpon their march after the Amalekite: It is no lingring, when God bids vs goe; They which had promi≈øed re≈øt to their weary limbs, after their returne from Achi≈øh, in their harbour of Ziglag, are glad to forget their hopes, and to put their ≈øtiffe
joynts vnto a new taske of motion; It is no maruell, if two hundred of them were ≈øo ouertyred, with their former toyle, that they were not able to pa≈ø≈øe ouer the riuer Be≈øor. Dauid was a true type of Chri≈øt. We follow him in the≈øe holy wars, again≈øt the ≈øpirituall Amalekites. All of vs are not of an equall ≈øtrength; Some are carried by the vigour of their faith, through all difficulties; Others, after long pre≈ø≈øure, are ready to langui≈øh in the way; Our Leader is not more ≈øtrong then pittifull; neither doth hee ≈øcornfully ca≈øhier tho≈øe, who≈øe de≈øires are hearty, whiles their abilities are vnan≈øwerable; How much more
≈øhould our charity pardon the infirmities of our brethen; and allow them to ≈øit by the ≈øtuffe, who cannot endure the march?

The ≈øame Prouidence, which appoynted Dauid to follow the Amalekites; had al≈øo ordered an Aegyptian to be ca≈øt behinde them. This ca≈øt ≈øeruant, whom his cruell Ma≈øter, had left to faintne≈ø≈øe and famine, ≈øhall bee v≈øed as the meanes of the recouery of the I≈øraelites lo≈ø≈øe; and of the reuenge of the Amalekites. Had not his Ma≈øter neglected him, all the≈øe rouers of Amalek, had gone away with their life and booty; It is not ≈øafe to de≈øpi≈øe the meane≈øt va≈ø≈øal
vpon earth. There is a mercy and care due to the mo≈øt de≈øpicable peice of all humanity; wherein wee cannot bee wanting without the offence, without the puni≈øhment of God.

Charity di≈øtingui≈øheth an I≈øraelite from an Amalekite. Dauids followers are ≈øtrangers to this Aegyptian; an Amalekite was his Ma≈øter; His Ma≈øter leaues him to dye (in the field) of ≈øickne≈ø≈øe and hunger; the≈øe ≈øtrangers releeued him: and ere they know, whether they might by him receiue any light in their pur≈øuit, they refre≈øh his dying ≈øpirits with bread and water, with figs and rai≈øins; Neither can the ha≈øte of their way bee
any hindrance to their compa≈ø≈øion; Hee hath no I≈øraeliti≈øh blood in him, that is vtterly mercile≈ø≈øe; Perhaps, yet Dauids Followers might al≈øo, in the hope of ≈øome intelligence, ≈øhew kindne≈ø≈øe to this forlorne Aegyptian. Worldly wi≈ødome teacheth vs, to ≈øow ≈ømall courte≈øies, where we may reape large harue≈øts of recompence: No ≈øooner are his ≈øpirits recalled, then hee requites his food with information. I cannot blame the Aegyptian, that hee was ≈øo ea≈øily induced, to de≈øcry the≈øe vnkind Amalekites, to merciful I≈øraelites; tho≈øe that gaue him ouer vnto death, to the re≈øtorers of his life; much le≈ø≈øe, that ere
he would de≈øcry them; hee requires an oath of ≈øecurity, from ≈øo bad a Ma≈øter; Well doth hee match death with ≈øuch a ≈øeruitude; Wonderfull is the Prouidence of God; euen ouer tho≈øe, which are not in the neere≈øt bonds, his owne; Three dayes, and three nights, had this poore Aegyptian Slaue lyen ≈øicke and hunger-≈øtarued in the fields, and lookes for nothing but death, when God ≈øends him ≈øuccour from the hands of tho≈øe I≈øraelites, whom hee had helped to ≈øpoile; though not ≈øo much for his ≈øake, as for I≈øraels, is this heatheni≈øh Stragler pre≈øerued.

It plea≈øes God, to extend his common fauors to all his creatures;
but in miraculous preferuations; he hath ≈øtill wont to haue re≈øpect to his owne. By this means therfore, are the I≈øraelites brought to the ≈øight of their late ≈øpoylers, whom they finde ≈øcattered abroad, vpon all the earth, eating, and drinking, and dancing in triumph, for the great prey they had taken.

The Amalekites haue paid a deare lone for the goods of I≈ørael, which they now re≈øtore with their owne liues; and now their ≈øpoyle hath made Dauid richer then he expected; that booty which they had ≈øwept from all other parts accrewed to him.

Tho≈øe I≈øralites that could not goe on to fight for their ≈øhare, are comne to meete their brethren with gratulation. How partiall are wee wont to be vnto our owne cau≈øes? Euen very I≈øraelites will bee ready to fall out for matter of profit: where
≈øelfe-loue hath bred a quarrell, euery man is ≈øubiect to flatter his owne ca≈øe. It ≈øeemed plau≈øible, and but iu≈øt to the actors in this re≈øcue, that tho≈øe which had taken no part in the paine, and hazard of the journey, ≈øhould receiue no part of the commodity. It was fauour enough for them to recouer their wiues & children, though they ≈øhared not in the goods. Wi≈øe and holy Dauid (who≈øe prai≈øe was no le≈ø≈øe, to ouercome his owne in time of peace, then his enimies in warre) calls his contending followers from law to equity, and ≈øo orders the matter, that ≈øince the plaintifes were detained not by will, but
by nece≈ø≈øity; and ≈øince their forced ≈øtay, was v≈øe-full in garding the ≈øtuffe, they ≈øhould partake equally of the prey with their fellowes. A ≈øentence well-be≈øeeming the ju≈øtice of Gods anoynted. Tho≈øe that repre≈øent God vpon earth, ≈øhould re≈øemble him in their proceeding. It is the ju≈øt mercy of our God, to mea≈øure vs by our wills not by our abilities; to recompence vs gratiou≈øly, according to the truth of our de≈øires, and endeauors; and to account that performed by vs, which hee only letteth vs from performing. It were wide with vs, if ≈øomtimes purpo≈øe did not ≈øupply actions. Whiles our heart faulteth not,
we that through ≈øpirituall ≈øickne≈ø≈øe are faine to abide by the ≈øtuffe, ≈øhall ≈øhare both in grace and glory with the victors.

div.head: The death of Saul.
div.p:
THe Witch of Endor, had halfe ≈ølaine Saul before the battell: It is iu≈øt, that they who con≈øult with deuils, ≈øhould goe away with di≈øcomfort: He hath eaten his la≈øt bread, at the hand of a Sorcere≈ø≈øe: and now nece≈ø≈øitie drawes him into that field, where he ≈øees nothing but de≈øpaire. Had not Saul beleeued the ill newes of the counterfait Samuel, he had not beene ≈øtrook downe on the ground with
words: Now his beleefe made him de≈øperate; Tho≈øe actions which are not ≈øu≈øtained by hope; mu≈øt needs langui≈øh: and are only promoted by outward compul≈øion: Whiles the minde is vncertaine of ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, it relieues it ≈øelfe with the po≈ø≈øibilities of good: in doubts there is a comfortable mixture: but when it is a≈ø≈øured of the wor≈øt euent, it is vtterly di≈øcouraged, and deiected. It hath therefore plea≈øed the wi≈ødome of God to hide from wicked men, his determination of their finall e≈øtate, that their remainders of hope, may harten them to good;

In all likelyhood on ≈øelfe-≈øame
day, ≈øaw Dauid a victor ouer the Amalakites, and Saul di≈øcomfited by the Phili≈øtims; How ≈øhould it bee otherwi≈øe? Dauid con≈øulted with God, and preuailed; Saul with the Witch of Endor and peri≈øheth; The end is commonly an≈øwerable to the way; It is an idle iniu≈øtice when we do ill to look to ≈øpeed well. The ≈ølaughter of Saul and his ≈øonnes, was not in the fir≈øt ≈øcene of this Tragicall field, that was rather re≈øerued by God, for the la≈øt act, that Saules mea≈øure might be full: God is long ere he ≈øtrikes, but when he doth, it is to purpo≈øe; Fir≈øt, I≈ørael flees and falls downe wounded in mount Gilboa;
They had their part in Sauls ≈øinne: they were actors in Dauids per≈øecution: Iu≈øtly therfore doe they ≈øuffer with him, whom they had ≈øeconded in offence. As it is hard to be good vnder an euill Prince, ≈øo it is as rare, not to be enwrapped in his iudgements: It was no ≈ømall addition to the angui≈øh of Sauls death, to ≈øee his ≈øonnes dead, to ≈øee his people fleeing, and ≈ølaine before him; They had ≈øinned in their King, and in them‚ñ™ is their King puni≈øhed. The re≈øt were not ≈øo worthy of pittie; but who≈øe heart would it not touch to ≈øee Ionathan, the good Sonne of a wicked Father, inuolued in the common de≈øtruction.
Death is not partiall: All di≈øpo≈øitions, all merits are alike to it: If valour, if holines, if ≈øyncerity of heart could haue beene any defence again≈øt mortality, Ionathan had ≈øuruiued: Now by their wounds and death, no man can di≈øcerne which is Ionathan; The ≈øoule only findes the difference, which the body admitteth not; Death is the coÃÑmon gate both to heauen and hell; we all pa≈ø≈øe that, ere our turning to either hand: The ≈øword of the Phili≈øtims, fetcheth Ionathan through it with his fellowes: no ≈øooner is his foot ouer that thre≈øhold, then God conducteth him to glory: The be≈øt cannot bee
happy but through their di≈ø≈øolution; Now therefore hath Ionathan no cau≈øe of complaint, he is by the rude and cruel hand of a Phili≈øtim, but remoued to a better Kingdome, then hee leaues to his brother: and at once is his death both a temporall affliction to the Sonne of Saul, and an entrance of glory to the frend of Dauid.

The Phili≈øtim-archers ≈øhot at random: God directs their arrowes into the body of Saul; Lea≈øt the di≈øcomfiture of his people, and the ≈ølaughter of his ≈øonnes ≈øhould not bee griefe enough to him, hee feeles him≈øelfe wounded, and ≈øees nothing before him but horror
and death; and now as a man for≈øaken of all hopes, hee begs of his armor-bearer that deaths-blow, which els he mu≈øt (to the doubling of his indignation) receiue from a Phili≈øtim. Hee begs this bloody fauour of his ≈øeruant, and is denyed: Such an awefulnes hath God placed in ≈øoueraigntie, that no intreaty, no extremity, can moue the hand again≈øt it: What mettall are tho≈øe men made of, that can ≈øugge≈øt or re≈øolue, and attempt the violation of maie≈øty? Wicked men care more for the ≈øhame of the world, then the danger of their ≈øoule: De≈øperate Saul will now ≈øupply his armor-bearer; and as a man that bore
armes again≈øt him≈øelfe, hee falls vpon his owne ≈øword. What if he had dyed by the weapon of a Phili≈øtim? So did his Son Ionathan, and lo≈øt no glory: The≈øe conceites of di≈øreputation preuaile with carnall hearts aboue all ≈øpirituall re≈øpects: There is no greater murderer then vainglory: Nothing more argues an heart voyd of grace, then to be tran≈øported by ydle popularity into actions preiudiciall to the Soule.

Euill examples, e≈øpecially of the great neuer e≈øcaped imitation; the armour-bearer of Saul followes his ma≈øter: and dares do that to him≈øelfe, which to his King he dur≈øt not: as if
their owne ≈øwords had beene more familiar executioners, they yelded vnto them, what they grudged to their pur≈øuers. From the beginning was Saul euer his owne enemy, neither did any hands hurt him but his owne: and now his death is ≈øutable to his life: his owne hand payes him the reward of all his wickedne≈ø≈øe, The end of hypocrites, and enuious men is commonly fearefull: Now is the blood of Gods Prie≈øts, which Saul ≈øhed, and of Dauid, which he would haue ≈øhed, required, & requited. The euil ≈øpirit had ≈øaid the euening before, To morrow thou ≈øhalt be with mee: and now Saul ha≈øteth to make
the diuell no lyer: rather then fayle, he giues him≈øelfe his own mittimus: Oh the wofull extremities of a di≈øpayring Soule, plundging him euer into a greater mi≈øchiefe, to auoyd the le≈ø≈øe. Hee might haue beene a patient in anothers violence, and faultle≈ø≈øe; now whiles hee will needs act the Phili≈øtims part vpon him≈øelfe, hee liued and dyed a murderer; The ca≈øe is deadly, when the pri≈øoner breakes the Iayle, and will not ≈øtay for his deliuery: & though wee may not pa≈ø≈øe ≈øentence vpon ≈øuch a Soule, yet vpon the fact we may: the Soule may po≈ø≈øibly repent in the parting, the act is haynous, and ≈øuch as
without repentance, kills the Soule.

It was the next day, ere the Phili≈øtims knew how much they were victors; then finding the dead corpes of Saul and his Sonnes, they begin their triumphs: The head of King Saul is cut off in lieu of Goliahs, and now all their Idoll temples ring of their ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; Fooli≈øh Phili≈øtims, If they had not beene more beholden to Sauls ≈øinnes, then their Gods, they had neuer carryed away the honor of tho≈øe trophees: In ≈øteed of magnifying the iu≈øtice of the true God, who puni≈øhed Saul with de≈øerued death, they magnifie the power of the fal≈øe: Super≈øtition
is extemely iniurious to God: It is no better then theft, to a≈øcribe vnto the ≈øecond cau≈øes that honor which is due vnto the fir≈øt: but to giue Gods glory to tho≈øe things which neither act, nor are, it is the highe≈øt degree of ≈øpirituall robbery.

Saul was none of the be≈øt Kings: yet ≈øo impatient are his ≈øubiects of the indignity offered to his dead corps, that they will rather leaue their owne bones among≈øt the Phili≈øtims, then the carca≈ø≈øe of Saul. Such a clo≈øe relation there is betwixt a Prince and ≈øubiect, that the di≈øhonor of either is in≈øeparable from both: How willing
≈øhould wee bee to hazard our bodyes or ≈øub≈øtance fo the vindication either of the per≈øon, or name of a good King, whiles he liues to the benefit of our protection: It is an vniu≈øt ingratitude in tho≈øe men, which can endure the di≈øgrace of them, vnder who≈øe ≈øhelter they liue; but how vnnaturall is the villany of tho≈øe mi≈øcreants, that can be content to bee actors in the capitall wrongs offred to ≈øoueraigne authority:

It were a wonder, if after the death of a Prince, there ≈øhould want ≈øome Pick-thanke, to in≈øinuate him≈øelfe into his Succe≈ø≈øour: An Amalekite young manrides po≈øt to Ziklag, to find
out Dauid, whom euen common rumor had notified for the anoynted heyre to the Kingdome of I≈ørael; to bee the fir≈øt me≈ø≈øenger of that newes, which hee thought could bee no other then acceptable; the death of Saul: and that the tydings might be ≈øo much more meritorious, he addes to the report, what he thinkes might carry the greate≈øt retribution: In hope of reward, or honour, the man is content to bely him≈øelfe to Dauid: It was not the ≈øpeare, but the ≈øword of Saul, that was the in≈øtrument of his death: neither could this ≈øtranger finde Saul, but dying, ≈øince the Armour-bearer of Saul ≈øaw him dead, ere
he offred that violence to him≈øelfe: The hand of this Amalekite therfore was not guilty, his tongue was: Had not this me≈ø≈øenger mea≈øur'd Dauids foot, by his owne la≈øt, hee had forborne this peece of the newes; and not hoped to aduantage him≈øelfe by this fal≈øhood: Now he thinks; The tydings of a Kingdome cannot but plea≈øe: None but Saul and Ionathan ≈øtood in Dauids way: Hee cannot chu≈øe, but like to heare of their remouall: E≈øpecially, ≈øince Saul did ≈øo tyrannou≈øly per≈øecute his innocence. If I ≈øhall onely report the fact done by another, I ≈øhall goe away but with the recompence of a lucky Po≈øt; wheras,
if I take vpon mee the action, I am the man, to whom Dauid is beholden for the Kingdome: he cannot but honour and requite me, as the author of his deliuerance and happine≈ø≈øe. Worldly mindes thinke no man can be of any other, then their owne diet; and becau≈øe they finde the re≈øpects of ≈øelfe-loue, and priuate profit, ≈øo ≈øtrongly preuailing with them≈øelues, they cannot conceiue, how the≈øe ≈øhould bee capable of a repul≈øe from others.

How much was this Amalekite mocked of his hopes: whiles he imagined, that Dauid would now triumph, and fea≈øt in the a≈ø≈øured expectation of the
Kingdome, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Crowne of I≈ørael, hee findes him renting his clothes, and wringing his hands, and weeping, and mourning: as if all his comfort had been dead with Saul and Ionathan: and yet perhaps he thought: This ≈øorrow of Dauid is but fa≈øhionable, ≈øuch as great heyres make ≈øhew of in the fatall day they haue longed for; The≈øe teares will ≈øoone be dry; the ≈øight of a Crowne will ≈øoon breed a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of other pa≈ø≈øions: But this error is ≈øoon corrected: For when Dauid had entertained this Bearer, with a ≈øad fa≈øt all the day: he cals him forth in the euening to executioÃÑ: (How wa≈øt thou not afrayd (≈øaith
he) to put forth thy hand, to de≈øtroy the Anoynted of the Lord:) Doubtle≈ø≈øe, the Amalekite made many faire pleas for him≈øelfe, out of the grounds of his owne report: Alas, Saul was before falne vpon his owne ≈øpeare. It was but mercy to kill him, that was halfe dead, that he might die the ≈øhorter: Be≈øides, his entreaty and importunate prayers, moued mee to ha≈øten him, through tho≈øe painfull gates of death: had I ≈øtriken him as an enemy, I had de≈øerued the blow I had giuen; now I ≈øent him the hand of a frend: why am I puni≈øhed for obeying the voyce of a King? and for perfiting what him≈øelfe begun, and could not fini≈øh:
And if neither his own wound, nor mine, had di≈øpatched him, the Phili≈øtims were at his heeles, ready to doe this ≈øame act with in≈øultation, which I did in fauour: and if my hand had not preuented them, wherehad been the Crowne of I≈ørael, which I now haue here pre≈øented to thee: I could haue deliuered that to King Achi≈øh, and haue beene rewarded with honour: let mee not dye for an act well meant to thee, how euer con≈øtrued by thee: But no pretence can make his owne tale not deadly. (Thy bloud bee vpon thine owne head, for thine owne mouth hath te≈øtified again≈øt thee ≈øaying, I haue ≈ølaine the Lords Anoynted.) It is a
iu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øition, that euery man is ≈øo great a Fauourer of him≈øelfe, that he will not mi≈ø-report his owne actions, nor ≈øay the wor≈øt of him≈øelfe: In matter of confe≈ø≈øion, men may without iniury be taken at their words: If he did it, his fact was capitall, If he did it not, his lye: It is pittyany other recompence ≈øhould befall tho≈øe fal≈øe flatterers, that can be content to father a ≈øinne, to get thankes. Euery drop of royall bloud is ≈øacred: For a man to ≈øay that he hath ≈øhed it, is mortall. Of how farre different ≈øpirits from this of Dauid, are tho≈øe men, which ≈øuborne the death of Princes, and celebrate and canonize the murtherers.
Into their ≈øecret, let not my ≈øoule come, my glory, be thou not joyned to their a≈ø≈øembly.

div.head: Abner and Joab.
div.p:
HOw mercifull and ≈øea≈øonable are the proui≈øions of God? Ziglag was now nothing but ruines and a≈øhes: Dauid might returne to the ≈øoyle where it ≈øtood, to the roofes and walls he could not: No ≈øooner is he di≈øapointed of that harbour, then God prouides him Cities of Hebron: Saul ≈øhall dye to giue him elbow-roome: Now doth Dauid finde the comfort that his extremity
≈øought in the Lord his God: Now are his clowdes for a time pa≈ø≈øed ouer: and the Sun breaks gloriou≈øly forth: Dauid ≈øhall raigne after his ≈øufferings. So ≈øhall we, if we indure to the end, finde a Crowne of righteou≈ønes, which the Lord the righteous Iudge, ≈øhall giue vs at that day: But though Dauid well knew that his head was long before anoynted, and had heard Saul him≈øelfe confidently auouching his ≈øucce≈ø≈øion: yet he will not ≈øtirre from the heapes of Ziglag, till hee haue con≈øulted with the Lord: It did not content him, that he had Gods warrant for the kingdome, but hee mu≈øt haue his in≈øtructions for
the taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it: How ≈øafe and happie is the man that is re≈øolued to do nothing without God? Neither will generalities of direction be ≈øufficient; euen particular circum≈øtances mu≈øt looke for a word: ≈øtill is God a piller of fire, and cloude to the eye of euery I≈øraelite: neither may there be any motion or ≈øtay but from him; That action cannot but ≈øucceed, which proceeds vpon ≈øo ≈øure a warrant:

God ≈øends him to Hebron a city of Iudah: Neither will Dauid goe vp thither alone, but he takes with him all his men with their whole hou≈øholds: they ≈øhall take ≈øuch part as him≈øelfe:
As they had ≈øhared with him in his mi≈øery, ≈øo they ≈øhall now in his pro≈øperity: Neither doth he take aduantage of their late mutinye (which was yet fre≈øh and greene) to ca≈øhier tho≈øe vnthankefull, and vngracious followers, but pardoning their ≈øecret rebellions, he makes them partakers of his good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe. Thus doth our heauenly leader (whom Dauid prefigured) take vs to raigne with him who haue ≈øuffered with him: pa≈ø≈øing by our manyfold infirmities, as if they had not beene, he remoueth vs from the land of our bani≈øhment, and the a≈øhes of our forlorne Ziklag, to the Hebron of our peace, and glory:
The expectation of this day mu≈øt (as it did with Dauids ≈øoldiers) dige≈øt all our ≈øorrows.

Neuer any calling of God was ≈øo con≈øpicuous, as not to finde ≈øome oppo≈øites: What I≈øraelite did not know Dauid, appointed by God to the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the kingdome? Euen the Amalekite, could carry the Crowne to him as the true owner: yet there wants not an Abner to re≈øi≈øt him, and the title of an I≈øhbo≈øheth to colour his re≈øi≈øtance: If any of Sauls hou≈øe could haue made challenge to the Crowne, it ≈øhould haue beene Mephibo≈øheth the Sonne of Ionathan: Who, it ≈øeemes had too much of his Fathers blood
to be a competitor with Dauid: the que≈øtion is not who may claime the mo≈øt right, but who may be≈øt ≈øerue the faction; Neither was I≈øhbo≈øheth any other then Abners ≈øtale: Saul could not haue a fitter Courtier: whether in imitation of his ma≈øters enuy, or the ambition of ruling vnder a borrowed name, hee ≈øtrongly oppo≈øeth Dauid: there are tho≈øe who ≈øtriue again≈øt their owne hearts, to make a ≈øide, with whom con≈øcience is oppre≈ø≈øed by affection: An ill quarrell once vndertaken ≈øhall be maintained, although with blood: Now, not ≈øo much the blood of Saul, as the ingagement of Abner makes the warre.
The Sonnes of Zeruiah ≈øtand fa≈øt to Dauid: It is much, how a man placeth his fir≈øt intere≈øt: If Abner had beene in Ioabs roome, when Sauls di≈øplea≈øure droue Dauid from the Court, or Ioab in Abners, the≈øe actions, the≈øe euents had beene changed with the per≈øons: It was the only happines of Ioab that he fell on the better ≈øide:

Both the Commaunders vnder Dauid and I≈øhbo≈øheth were equally cruell: both are ≈øo inured to blood, that they make but a ≈øport of killing‚ñ™ Cu≈øtome makes ≈øinne ≈øo familiar, that the horror of it, is to ≈øome turned into plea≈øure. (Come let the young men play before vs.) Abner is

the Challenger, and ≈øpeeds therafter: for though in the matches of duell both ≈øides mi≈øcaried, yet in the following conflict, Abner and his men are beaten: By the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe ≈øingle combats no man knows the better of the cau≈øe: Both ≈øides peri≈øh, to ≈øhow, how little God liked either the offer, or the acceptation of ≈øuch a triall, but when both did their be≈øt, God puni≈øheth the wrong part with di≈øcomfiture.

Oh, the mi≈øery of ciuill di≈ø≈øention: I≈ørael and Iudah were brethren: One carryed the name of the Father, the other of the Sonne: Iudah was but a branch of I≈ørael, I≈ørael was the
root of Iudah: yet Iudah and I≈ørael mu≈øt fight, and kill each other; only vpon the quarrell of an ill leaders ambition. The ≈øpeed of A≈øahel was not greater then his courage: It was a minde fit for one of Dauids worthies, to ≈øtrike at the head, to match him≈øelfe with the be≈øt: He was both ≈øwift and ≈øtrong: but the race is not to the ≈øwift, nor the battle to the ≈øtrong: If he had gone neuer ≈øo ≈ølowly, he might haue ouertaken death: now he runnes to fetch it. So little lu≈øt had Abner to ≈øhed the blood of a Son of Zeruiah, that he twice adui≈øes him to retreat from pur≈øuing his owne perill: A≈øahels cau≈øe was ≈øo much better
as Abners ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: Many a one mi≈ø-carries in the ra≈øh pro≈øecution of a good quarrell, when the Abettors of the wor≈øt part goe away with victory. Heat of zeale, ≈øometimes in the vndi≈øcreet pur≈øuit of a ju≈øt aduer≈øary, prooues mortall to the agent, preiudiciall to the ≈øeruice.

Abner, whiles he kils, yet hee flyes, and runs away from his owne death, whiles hee inflicts it vpon another: Dauids followers had the better of the field and day; The Sun, as vnwilling to ≈øee any more I≈øraeliti≈øh bloud ≈øhed by brethren, hath withdrawne him≈øelfe: and now both parts hauing got the
aduantage of an hil vnder them, haue ≈øafe conuenience of parley: Abner beginnes, and per≈øwades Ioab to ≈øurcea≈øe the fight (Shall the ≈øword deuoure for euer? Knowe≈øt thou not, that it will bee bitterne≈ø≈øe in the end? How long ≈øhall it bee, ere thou bid the people returne from following their brethren?) It was his fault, that the ≈øword deuoured at all: and why was not the beginning of a ciuill war bitterne≈ø≈øe? why did he call forth the people to skirmi≈øh, and inuite them to death? Had Abner been on the winning hand, this motion had beene thank-worthy: It is a noble di≈øpo≈øition in a Victor, to call for a ce≈ø≈øatum of armes: wheras nece≈ø≈øity wrings
this ≈øuit from the ouer-ma≈øtered. There cannot bee a greater prai≈øe, to a valiant and wi≈øe Commander, then a propen≈øion to all ju≈øt termes of peace: For warre, as it is ≈øometimes nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øo it is alwayes euill; and if fighting haue any other end propo≈øed be≈øides peace, it proues murder. Abner ≈øhall find him≈øelfe no le≈ø≈øe ouercome, by Ioab in clemency, then power; He ≈øayes not, I will not ≈øo ea≈øily leaue the aduantage of my victory: ≈øince the dice of war run on my ≈øide, I will follow the chace of my good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe: Thou ≈øhoulde≈øt haue con≈øidered of this before thy prouocation: It is now too late, to moue
vnto forbearance: but, as a man that meant to approue him≈øelfe equally free from cowardi≈øe, in the beginning of the conflict, and from cruelty in the end; he profe≈ø≈øeth his forwardne≈ø≈øe, to entertaine any pretence of ≈øheathing vp the ≈øwords of I≈ørael; and ≈øweares to Abner, that if it had not beene for his proud irritation, the people had in the morning before cea≈øed from that bloudy pur≈øuit of their brethren: As it becomes publique per≈øons to bee louers of peace, ≈øo they mu≈øt ≈øhew it vpon all good occa≈øions: letting pa≈ø≈øe no opportunity of making ≈øpare of bloud.

I≈øhbo≈øheth was (it ≈øeemes) a
man of no great ≈øpirits, for being no le≈ø≈øe then forty yeeres old, when his father went into his la≈øt field again≈øt the Phili≈øtims, he was content to ≈øtay at home; Abner hath put ambition vnto him; and hath ea≈øily rai≈øed him to the head of a faction, again≈øt the anoynted Prince of Gods people. If this v≈øurped Crowne of Sauls ≈øon, had any worth or glory in it, hee cannot but acknowledge, to owe it all vnto Abner, yet how forward is vnthankfull I≈øhbo≈øheth to receiue a fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtion again≈øt his cheefe Abettor: (Wherfore ha≈øt thou gone in, to my fathers Concubine?) He that made no con≈øcience of an vniu≈øt claime of the
Crowne, and a maintenance of it with bloud, yet ≈øeemes ≈øcrupulous of a le≈ø≈øe ≈øinne, that carried in it the color of a di≈øgrace; The touch of her, who had beene honoured by his fathers bed, ≈øeemed an intolerable pre≈øumption, and ≈øuch as could not be ≈øeuered from his owne di≈øhonour: Selfe-loue ≈øometimes borrowes the face of hone≈øt zeale. Tho≈øe, who out of true grounds, di≈ølike ≈øins, doe hate them all indifferently, according to their haynou≈øne≈ø≈øe; hypocrites are partiall in their dete≈øtation; bewraying euer mo≈øt bitterne≈ø≈øe, again≈øt tho≈øe offences, which may mo≈øt preiudice their per≈øons and reputations.

It is as dangerous as vniu≈øt for Princes, to giue both their eares and their heart to mi≈øgrounded rumors of their innocent followers: This wrong hath ≈øtript I≈øhbo≈øheth of the Kingdome; Abner in the meane time cannot be excu≈øed from a trecherous incon≈øtancy; If Sauls ≈øon had no true title to the Crowne, why did he maintaine it; If hee had, why did hee for≈øake the cau≈øe and per≈øon? Had Abner out of remor≈øe, for furthering a fal≈øe claime taken off his hand, I know not wherein hee could be blamed, except for not doing it ≈øooner; But now to withdraw his profe≈ø≈øed allegegeance, vpon a priuate reuenge,
was to take a lewd leaue of an ill action: If I≈øhbo≈øheth were his lawfull Prince, no iniury could warrant a reuolt; Euen betwixt priuate per≈øons, a returne of wrongs is both vncharitable, and vniu≈øt, how euer this goe currant for the common ju≈øtice of the world, how much more ≈øhould we learn from a ≈øupreme hand, to take hard mea≈øures with thankes? It had been Abuers duty, to haue giuen his King a peaceable and humble ≈øatisfaction, and not to fly out in a ≈ønuffe. If the ≈øpirit of the ruler ri≈øe vp again≈øt thee, leaue not thy place, for yeelding, pacifieth great offences; now, his impatient falling, although to the
right ≈øide, makes him no better then trayterou≈øly hone≈øt.

So ≈øoone as Abner hath entertained a re≈øolution of his rebellion; hee per≈øwades the Elders of I≈ørael to accompany him in the change: & whence doth he fetch his main motiue, but from the Oracle of God? (The Lord hath ≈øpoken of Dauid, ≈øaying, By the hand of my ≈øeruant Dauid, will I ≈øaue my people I≈ørael, out of the hand of the Phili≈øtims, and out of the hand of all their enemies;) Abner knew this full well before, yet then was well content to ≈ømother a knowne truth for his owne turne, and now the publication of it may ≈øerue for his aduantage, he wins the heart of I≈ørael,
by ≈øhewing Gods Charter for him, whom he had ≈øo long oppo≈øed: Hypocrites make v≈øe of God for their owne purpo≈øes; and care onely to make diuine authority a colour for their owne de≈øignes; No man euer heard Abner godly till now; neither had hee beene ≈øo at this time, if hee had not intended a reuengefull departure from I≈øhbo≈øheth: Nothing is more odious, then to make religion a ≈øtalking hor≈øe to policy.

THE FIFTEENTH BOOKE:

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE MY VERY GOOD LORD, WILLIAM Lord Burleigh All grace and happines.
div.p:
THere are but two Bookes wherein we can read God; The one is his word, his workes the other; This is the bigger volume, that the more exqui≈øite. The Characters of this are more large, but dimme; of that, ≈ømaller but clearer. Philo≈øophers haue turned ouer this, and erred; That, Diuines and ≈øtudious Chri≈øtians, not without full and certaine information. In the workes of God wee ≈øee the ≈øhadow, or foot-≈øteps of the Creator, in his word we ≈øee the face of God in a gla≈ø≈øe. Happines con≈øi≈øts in the vi≈øion of that infinite Maie≈øtie: and if wee bee perfectly happy
aboue in ≈øeeing him face to face, our happines is well forward below, in ≈øeeing the liuely repre≈øentation of his face in the gla≈ø≈øe of the Scriptures. Wee cannot ≈øpend our eyes too much vpon this obiect; For mee, the more I ≈øee, the more I am amazed, the more I am raui≈øhed with this glorious beauty: With the hone≈øt lepers, I cannot bee content to inioy this happy ≈øight alone; there is but one way to euery mans felicity; May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip to take part with many your Peeres in the≈øe my weake; but not vnprofitable Contemplations; which ≈øhall hold them≈øelues not a little graced with your Honorable name; Whereto, together with your right noble and mo≈øt worthy Lady, I haue gladly deuoted my ≈øelfe; to be

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips in all dutifull ob≈øeruance IOS: HALL.

div.head: ∆≤zzah and the Arke remoued.
div.p:
THe hou≈øe of Saul is quiet, the Phili≈øtims beaten, victory cannot end better then in deuotion; Dauid is no ≈øooner ≈øetled in his hou≈øe at Ieru≈øalem, then hee fetcheth God to be his gue≈øt there; the thou≈øands of I≈ørael goe now in an holy march, to bring vp the Ark of God, to the place of his re≈øt: The tumults of warre afforded
no oportunity of this ≈øeruice; only peace is a frend to religion, neither is peace euer our frend, but when it is a ≈øeruant of piety: The v≈øe of warre is not more pernicious to the body, then the abu≈øe of peace is to the Soule; Alas, the ryot bred of our long ea≈øe, rather driues the Ark of God from vs; ≈øo the ≈øtill ≈øedentary life, is ≈øubiect to di≈øea≈øes, and ≈øtanding waters putrifie. It may bee iu≈øt with God, to take away the ble≈ø≈øing which wee doe ≈øo much abu≈øe, and to ≈øcoure off our ru≈øt with bloody warre, &c.

The Ark of God had now many yeares, re≈øted in the ob≈øcure lodge of Abinadab, without
the honor of a Tabernacle. Dauid will not indure him≈øelfe glorious, and the Ark of God contemptible, his fir≈øt care is to prouide a fit roome for God; in the head of the Tribes, in his owne city; The chiefe care of good Princes, mu≈øt be the aduancement of religion; What ≈øhould the deputies of God rather do, then honor him whom they repre≈øent? It was no good that I≈ørael could learne of Phili≈øtims; Tho≈øe Pagans had ≈øent the Ark backe in a new cart; the I≈øraelites ≈øaw God ble≈ø≈øed that conduct, and now they practi≈øe it at home: But that which God will take from Phili≈øtims, he will not brook from
I≈ørael; Aliens from God are no fit patternes for children: Diuine in≈øtitution had made this a cariage for the Leuites, not for Oxen: Neither ≈øhould tho≈øe Sons of Abinadab haue driuen the cart, but caryed that ≈øacred burden. Gods bu≈øine≈ø≈øes mu≈øt be done after his owne formes, which if we doe with the be≈øt intentions alter, wee pre≈øume:

It is long, ≈øince I≈ørael ≈øaw ≈øo faire a day as this, wherein they went in this holy triumph to fetch the Ark of God; Now their warlike trumpets are turned into Harpes and Timbrils; and their hands in ≈øteed of weilding the Sword and Speare, ≈øtrike vpon tho≈øe mu≈øicall
≈øtrings whereby they might expre≈ø≈øe the ioy of their hearts; heere was no noy≈øe but of mirth, no motion but plea≈øant: oh happy I≈ørael that had a God to reioyce in, that had this occa≈øion of reioycing in their God, and an hart that embraced this occa≈øion. There is nothing but this wherein wee may not ioy immoderately, vn≈øea≈øonably; this ≈øpirituall ioy can neuer be either out of time, or out of mea≈øure‚ñ™ let him that reioyceth, reioyce in the Lord. But now when the I≈øraelites were in the mid≈øt of this Angel-like iolity, their hearts lifted vp, their hands playing, their feete mouing, their tongues ≈øinging and
≈øhouting, God ≈øees good to ≈øtrike them into a ≈øudden dumpe by the death of Vzzah: They are ≈øcarce ≈øet into the tune when God mars their Mu≈øicke, by a fearefull iudgement; and changes their mirth into a≈øtoni≈øhment, and confu≈øion; There could not bee more excellent worke then this they were about; there could not be more cheerefull hearts in the performing of it, yet will the mo≈øt holy God rather da≈øh all this ≈øolemne ≈øeruice, then indure an act of pre≈øumption or infidelity. Abinadab had bene the faithfull ho≈øt of Gods Ark, for the ≈øpace of twenty yeares: euen in the mid≈øt of the terrors of I≈ørael,
who were iu≈øtly affrighted with the vengance inflicted vpon Beth-≈øheme≈øh, did he giue harbour vnto it; Yet euen the Son of Abinadab is ≈øtriken dead, in the fir≈øt departing of that ble≈ø≈øed gue≈øt: The Sanctity of the Parent cannot beare out the ≈øinne of his Sonne: The holy one of I≈ørael will bee ≈øanctified in all that come neare him: He will be ≈øerued like him≈øelfe.

What then was the ≈øinne of Vzzah? What was the capitall crime, for which he ≈øo fearefully peri≈øhed? That the Arke of God was coÃÑmitted to the Cart, it was not his deuice only, but the common act of many, That it was not caryed on the
≈øhoulders of Leuites, was no le≈ø≈øe the fault of Ahio, and the re≈øt of their brethren; only Vzzah is ≈øtriken: The re≈øt ≈øinned in negligence, he in pre≈øumption; the Ark God ≈øhakes with the agitation of that cariage; he puts forth his hand to hold it ≈øteddy; Humane iudgement would haue found heerein nothing haynous: God ≈øees not with the eyes of men; None but the Prie≈øts ≈øhould haue dared to touch the Ark; It was enough for the Leuites to touch the bars that carryed it; An vnwarranted hand cannot ≈øo lightly touch the Ark, but hee ≈øtrikes the God that dwels in it: No maruell if God ≈øtrike that man
with death, that ≈øtrikes him with pre≈øumption; There was wel-neare the ≈øame quarell again≈øt the thou≈øands of Beth≈øheme≈øh, and again≈øt Vzzah; They dyed for looking into the Ark, he for touching it; lea≈øt I≈ørael ≈øhould grow into a contemptuous familiarity with this Te≈øtimony of Gods pre≈øence, he will hold them in awe with iudgements: The reuenging hand of the Almighty, that vpon the returne of the Ark ≈øtayed at the hou≈øe of Ahinadab, vpon the remoue of the Ark begins there againe: Where are tho≈øe that thinke God will take vp with a carele≈ø≈øe and ≈ølubbred ≈øeruice? He who≈øe infinite mercy
v≈øes to pa≈ø≈øe by our ≈øinnes of infirmity, puni≈øheth yet ≈øeuerely our bold faults: If wee cannot doe any thing in the degrees that he requireth, yet wee mu≈øt learne to doe all things in the forme that he requireth; Doubtle≈ø≈øe Vzzah meant no otherwi≈øe then well in putting forth his hand to ≈øtay the Ark; He knew the ≈øacred vten≈øills that were in it, the pot of Manna, the Tables of the Law, the rod of Aaron, which might bee wronged by that ouer-rough motion: to the≈øe hee offers his ayd, and is ≈øtriken dead; The be≈øt intentions cannot excu≈øe; much le≈ø≈øe warrant vs in vnlawfull actions; where wee doe ought in
faith, it plea≈øeth our good God to wink at, and pitty our weakne≈ø≈øes; but if we dare to pre≈øent God with the well-meant ≈øeruices of our owne making, wee runne into the indignation of God; There is nothing more dangerous, then to be our owne caruers in matter of deuotion.

I maruell not if the countenance of Dauid were ≈øuddenly changed, to ≈øee the pale face of death in one of the cheefe actors in this holy proce≈ø≈øion: Hee that had found God ≈øo fauourable to him in actions of le≈ø≈øe worth, is troubled to ≈øee this ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe ≈øo heartily directed vnto his God; and now he begins to look thorow
Vzzah at him≈øelfe, and to ≈øay, (How ≈øhall the Arke of the Lord come to mee?)
