Then onely ≈øhall we make a right v≈øe of the judgments of God vpon others, when we ≈øhall feare them in our ≈øelues, and finding our ≈øins at lea≈øt equall, ≈øhall tremble at the expectation of the ≈øame de≈øerued puni≈øhments. God intends not onely reuenge in his executions, but reformation; As good Princes regard not ≈øo much the ≈ømart of the euill pa≈øt, as the preuention of the future; which is neuer attained, but when wee make applications of Gods hand; and draw common ca≈øes out of Gods particular proceedings.

I doe not heare Dauid ≈øay; Surely, this man is guilty of ≈øome ≈øecret ≈øin, that the world knowes not; God hath met with him; there is no danger to vs; why ≈øhould I bee di≈øcouraged to ≈øee God iu≈øt? Wee may goe on ≈øafely and pro≈øper; but here his foot ≈øtaies, and his hand fals from his in≈øtrument, and his tongue is ready to tax his owne vnworthine≈ø≈øe, (How ≈øhall the Arke of the Lord come vnto mee?) That heart is carnall and proud, that thinkes any man wor≈øe then him≈øelfe; Dauids feare ≈øtayes his progre≈ø≈øe; Perhaps, he might haue proceeded with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, but hee dares not venture, where hee ≈øees ≈øuch a
deadly checke: It is better to bee too fearefull, then too forward in tho≈øe affaires, which do immediately concerne God; As it is not good to refrain from holy bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, ≈øo it is wor≈øe to doe them ill; Awfulne≈ø≈øe is a ≈øafe interpreter of Gods ≈øecret actions, and a wi≈øe guide of ours.

This euent hath holpen Obed-Edom to a gue≈øt he lookt not for, God ≈øhall now ≈øoiourne in the hou≈øe of him, in who≈øe heart he dwelt before by a ≈øtrong faith; el≈øe the man dur≈øt not haue vndertaken, to receiue that dreadfull Arke, which Dauid him≈øelfe feared to harbour; Oh the courage of an hone≈øt and faithfull heart; Obed-Edom knew well enough
what ≈ølaughter the Arke had made among the Phili≈øtims, and after that among≈øt the Beth ≈øhemites, and now hee ≈øaw Vzzah lye dead before him, yet doth hee not make any ≈øcruple of entertaining it, neither doth he ≈øay, My neigbour Abinadab was a carefull and religious ho≈øt to the Ark, and is now payed with the bloud of his ≈øon; how ≈øhall I hope to ≈øpeede better; but he opens his doores with a bold cheerefulne≈ø≈øe, and notwith≈øtanding all tho≈øe terrors, bids God welcome: Nothing can make God not amiable to his owne; Euen his very Iu≈øtice is louely: Holy men know how to reioyce in the
Lord with trembling, and can feare without di≈øcouragement.

The God of Heauen will not receiue any thing from men on free co≈øt; hee will pay liberally for his lodging, a plentifull ble≈ø≈øing vpon Obed-Edom, and all his hou≈øhold. It was an honour to that zealous Gittite, that the Arke would come vnder his roofe; yet God rewards that honour with benediction: Neuer man was a lo≈øer by true godline≈ø≈øe; The hou≈øe of Obed-Edom cannot this while want ob≈øeruation; the eyes of Dauid, and all I≈ørael are neuer off from it, to ≈øee how it fared with this entertainment. And now, when they finde nothing, but a
gracious acceptation and ≈øen≈øible ble≈ø≈øing, the good King of I≈ørael takes new heart, and ha≈øtens to fetch the Arke into his royall City. The view of Gods fauours vpon the godly, is no ≈ømall encouragement to confidence and obedience; Doubtle≈ø≈øe, Obed-Edom was not free from ≈øome weakne≈ø≈øes; If the Lord ≈øhould haue taken the aduantage of judgement again≈øt him, what I≈øraelites had not been di≈øhartned from attending the Arke? Now Dauid & I≈ørael was not more affrighted with the vengeance vpon Vzzah, then encouraged by the ble≈ø≈øing of Obed-Edom; The wi≈øe God doth ≈øo order his iu≈øt and mercifull
proceedings, that the awefulne≈ø≈øe of men may be tempered with loue. Now the ≈øweet ≈øinger of I≈ørael reuiues his holy Mu≈øicke; and addes both more ≈øpirit and more pompe to ≈øo deuout a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe‚ñ™ I did not before heare of trumpets, nor dancing, nor ≈øhouting, nor ≈øacrifices, nor the linnen Ephod; The ≈øen≈øe of Gods pa≈ø≈øed di≈øplea≈øure, doubles our care to plea≈øe him, and our ioy in his recouered approbation; wee neuer make ≈øo much of our health, as after ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, nor neuer are ≈øo officious to our frend, as after an vnkindne≈ø≈øe. In the fir≈øt ≈øetting out of the Ark, Dauids feare was at lea≈øt an equall match to
his ioy; therefore after the fir≈øt ≈øixe paces hee offred a ≈øacrifice, both to pacifie God, and thank him: but now when they ≈øaw no ≈øigne of di≈ølike, they did more freely let them≈øelues loo≈øe to a fearele≈ø≈øe ioy; and the body ≈øtroue to expre≈ø≈øe the holy affection of the Soule; there was no limme, no part that did not profe≈ø≈øe their mirth by motion, no noy≈øe of voyce, or in≈øtrument wanted to a≈ø≈øi≈øt their ≈øpirituall iollity; Dauid led the way, dauncing with all his might in his linnen Ephod; Vzzah was ≈øtill in his eye; he dur≈øt not v≈øurpe vpon a garment of Prie≈øts; but hee will borrow their colour to grace the ≈øolemnity,
though he dare not the fa≈øhion; White was euer the colour of ioy, and linnen was light for v≈øe; therfore he couers his Princely robes with white linnin, and meanes to honor him≈øelfe by his conformity to Gods mini≈øters. Tho≈øe that thinke there is di≈øgrace in the Ephod, are farre from the Spirit of the man after Gods owne hart; Neither can there bee a greater argument of a foule Soule, then a di≈ølike of the glorious calling of God: Barren Mical hath too many Sons that ≈øcorne the holy habit and exerci≈øes: ≈øhee lookes through her window, and ≈øeeing the attyre and ge≈øtures of her deuout husband,
de≈øpi≈øeth him in her hart, neither can ≈øhee conceale her contempt, but like Sauls daughter ca≈øt it proudly in his face (Oh how glorious was the King of I≈ørael this day; which was vncouered to day in the eyes of the Maidens of his ≈øeruants, as a foole vncouereth him≈øelfe.) Worldly harts can ≈øee nothing in actions of zeale, but folly and madne≈ø≈øe: Piety hath no reli≈øh to their palate but di≈øta≈øtfull.

Dauids hart did neuer ≈øwell ≈øo much at any reproch, as this of his wife; his loue was for the time lo≈øt in his anger; and as a man impatient of no affront ≈øo much as in the way of his deuotion, hee returnes a bitter
checke to his Micall; (It was before the Lord, which cho≈øe me rather then thy Father, & all his hou≈øe, &c.) Had not Mical twitted her husband with the ≈øhame of his zeale, ≈øhe had not heard of the ≈øhamefull reiection of her Father; now ≈øince ≈øhee will be forrgetting, who≈øe wife ≈øhe was, ≈øhe ≈øhall be put in minde who≈øe daughter ≈øhe was. Contumelyes that are ca≈øt vpon vs in the cau≈øes of God, may ≈øafely bee repayed: If we be meal-mouthed in the ≈øcornes of religion, wee are not patient, but zeale-le≈ø≈øe: Heere we may not forbeare her, that lies in our bo≈øome. If Dauid had not loued Mical dearely, he had neuer ≈øtood vpon tho≈øe
points with Abner; Hee knew that if Abner came to him, the Kingdome of I≈ørael would accompany him, and yet he ≈øends him the charge of not ≈øeeing his face, except he brought Mical, Sauls daughter with him; as if he would not regard the Crowne of I≈ørael, whiles hee wanted that wife of his; Yet heere hee takes her vp roundly, as if ≈øhe had bene an enimy, not a partener of his bed; All relations are a loofe off, in compari≈øon of that betwixt God, and the Soule; He that loues Father, or Mother, or wife, or childe, better then me (≈øaith our Sauiour) is not worthy of me. Euen the highe≈øt delights of our harts
mu≈øt be trampled vpon, when they will ≈øtand out in riuality with God. Oh happy re≈øolution of the royall Prophet, and propheticall King of I≈ørael, (I will bee yet more vile then thus, and will bee low in mine owne ≈øight) he knew this very aba≈øement heroycall; and that the only way to true glory, is not to be a≈øhamed of our lowe≈øt humiliation vnto God: Well might he promi≈øe him≈øelfe honor from tho≈øe, who≈øe contempt ≈øhee had threatned; The hearts of men are not their owne, hee that made them, ouer-rules them, and inclines them to an honorable conceit of tho≈øe that honor their
maker; So as holy men haue oft-times inward reuerence, euen where they haue outward indignities. Dauid came to ble≈ø≈øe his hou≈øe, Mical brings a cur≈øe vpon her ≈øelfe; Her ≈øcornes ≈øhall make her childele≈ø≈øe to the day of her death; Barrenne≈ø≈øe was held in tho≈øe times, none of the lea≈øt iudgements; God doth ≈øo reuenge Dauids quarrell vpon Mical, that her ≈øudden di≈øgrace, ≈øhall bee recompenced with perpetuall: Shee ≈øhall not bee held worthy to beare a Sonne, to him whom ≈øhe vniu≈øtly contemned; How iu≈øt is it with God to prouide whips for the back ≈øcorners? It is no maruell if
tho≈øe that mocke at goodne≈ø≈øe, bee plagued with continuall fruitle≈øne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Mephibo≈øheth and Ziba.
div.p:
SO ≈øoone as euer Dauid can but breathe him≈øelfe from the publique cares, hee ca≈øts backe his thoughts to the deare remembrance of his Ionathan. Sauls ≈øeruant is likely to giue him the be≈øt intelligence of Sauls ≈øons; The que≈øtion is therfore moued to Ziba; Remaineth there yet none of the hou≈øe of Saul? and le≈øt ≈øu≈øpition might
conceale the remainders of an emulous line in feare of reuenge intended, he addes: On whom I may ≈øhew the mercy of God for Ionathans ≈øake. O frend≈øhip worthy of the monuments of eternity; fit onely to requite him, who≈øe loue was more then the loue of women; Hee doth not ≈øay, Is there any of the hou≈øe of Ionathan, but of Saul; that for his frends ≈øake hee may ≈øhew fauour to the po≈øterity of his Per≈øecutor. Ionathans loue could not bee greater then Sauls malice, which al≈øo ≈øuruiued long in his i≈ø≈øue; from whom Dauid found a bu≈øie and ≈øtubborne riuality for the Crowne of I≈ørael; yet as one that gladly buried all the
ho≈øtility of Sauls hou≈øe in Ionathans graue, he askes, Is there am man left of Sauls hou≈øe, that I may ≈øhew him mercy for Ionathans ≈øake? It is true loue that ouer-liues in the per≈øon of a frend, will be inherited of his ≈øeed‚ñ™ but to loue the po≈øterity of an enemy in a frend, it is the miracle of frend≈øhip: The formall amity of the world is confined to a face; or to the po≈ø≈øibility of recompence, langui≈øhing in the di≈øability, and dying in the decea≈øe of the party affected: That loue was euer fal≈øe, that is not euer con≈øtant, and then mo≈øt operatiue, when it cannot bee either knowne, or requited.

To cut of all vnquiet competition
for the Kingdome of I≈ørael, the prouidence of God had ≈øo ordered, that there is none left to the hou≈øe of Saul (be≈øides the ≈øons of his Concubines) ≈øaue onely young and lame Mephibo≈øheth; ≈øo young, that he was but fiue yeeres of age, when Dauid entred vpon the gouernment of I≈ørael; ≈øo lame, that if his age had fitted, his impotence had made him vnfit for the throne. Mephibo≈øheth was not borne a Cripple, it was an heedle≈ø≈øe nur≈øe that made him ≈øo: Shee hearing of the death of Saul and Ionathan, made ≈øuch ha≈øte to flee, that her young Ma≈øter was lamed with the fall: Ywis there needed no ≈øuch ≈øpeed to run
away from Dauid; who≈øe loue pur≈øues the hidden ≈øon of his brother Ionathan: How often doth our ignorant mi≈øtaking, cau≈øe vs to run from our be≈øt frends, and to catch knocks and maymes of them that profe≈ø≈øe our protection?

Mephibo≈øheth could not come otherwi≈øe then fearefully, into the pre≈øence of Dauid, whom he knew ≈øo long; ≈øo ≈øpitefully oppo≈øed by the hou≈øe of Saul: he could not be ignorant, that the fa≈øhion of the world is, to build their owne ≈øecurity vpon the bloud of the oppo≈øite faction; neither to thinke them≈øelues ≈øafe, whiles any branch remains ≈øpringing out of that root of
their emulation: Sea≈øonably doth Dauid therfore fir≈øt, expell all tho≈øe vniu≈øt doubts, ere hee admini≈øter his further cordials; (Feare not; for I will ≈øurely ≈øhew thee kindne≈ø≈øe, for Ionathan thy fathers ≈øake, and will re≈øtore thee all the fields of Saul thy father, and thou ≈øhalt eat bread at my table continually:)

Dauid can ≈øee neither Sauls bloud, nor lame legs in Mepibo≈øheth, whiles hee ≈øees in him the features of his frend Ionathan; how much le≈ø≈øe ≈øhall the God of mercies regard our infirmities, or the corrupt bloud of our ≈øinfull progenitors, whiles hee beholds vs in the face of his ≈øon, in whom he is well plea≈øed.

Fauors are wont ≈øo much
more to affect vs, as they are le≈ø≈øe expected by vs; Mephibo≈øheth as ouer-ioyed with ≈øo comfortable a word, and confounded in him≈øelfe at the remembrance of the contrary de≈øeruings of his family, bowes him≈øelfe to the earth, and ≈øayes (What is thy ≈øeruant, that thou ≈øhould≈øt looke vpon ≈øuch a dead dog as I am?) I finde no defect of wit, (though of limmes) in Mephibo≈øheth, he knew him≈øelfe the grand-childe of the King of I≈ørael, the Son of Ionathan, the lawfull heyre of both, yet in regard of his owne impotency, and the tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe and reiection of his hou≈øe, hee thus aba≈øeth him≈øelfe vnto Dauid; Humiliation
is a right v≈øe of Gods afflictions; What if wee were borne great? If the ≈øinne of his grandfather hath lo≈øt his e≈øtate, and the hand of his Nur≈øe hath deformed and di≈øabled his per≈øon, hee now forgets what hee was, and calls him≈øelfe wor≈øe then hee is a, A dogge; Yet a liuing dogge, is better then a dead Lyon; there is dignity and comfort in life; Mephibo≈øheth is therefore a Dead Dog vnto Dauid: It is not for vs to nouri≈øh the ≈øame Spirits in our aduer≈øe e≈øtate, that wee found in our highe≈øt pro≈øperity; What v≈øe haue we made of Gods hand, if wee bee not the lower with our fall? God intends
wee ≈øhould carry our cro≈ø≈øe, not make a fire of it to warme vs; It is no bearing vp our ≈øailes in a tempe≈øt; Good Dauid cannot di≈ø-e≈øteeme Mephibo≈øheth euer the more for di≈øparaging him≈øelfe; he loues and honors this humility, in the Son of Ionathan; There is no more certaine way to glory and aduancement, then a lowly deiection of our ≈øelues: Hee that made him≈øelfe a dog, and therefore fit only to lye vnder the table, Yea a dead dog, and therefore fit only for the ditch, is ray≈øed vp to the Table of a King; his ≈øeate ≈øhall bee honorable, yea, royall, his fare delicious, his attendance noble. How
much more will our gracious God, lift vp our heads, vnto true honor before men and Angels, if wee can bee ≈øyncerely humbled in his ≈øight? If wee mi≈øcall our ≈øelues in the meanene≈ø≈øe of our conceits to him, he giues vs a new name, and ≈øets vs at the table of his glory; It is contrary with God and men; if they reckon of vs as wee ≈øet out our ≈øelues, hee values vs according to our aba≈øements. Like a Prince truly munificent and faithfull, Dauid promi≈øes and performes at once; Ziba Sauls ≈øeruant hath the charge giuen him, of the execution of that royall word; He ≈øhall be the Bayliffe of this great husbandry of
his ma≈øter Mephibo≈øheth; The land of Saul, how euer forfaited, ≈øhall know no other ma≈øter then Sauls grand-childe; As yet, Sauls ≈øeruant had ≈øped better then his Son‚ñ™ I read of twenty ≈øeruants of Ziba, none of Mephibo≈øheth; Earthly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, doe not alwayes admit of equall diui≈øions; The wheele is now turned vp; Mephibo≈øheth is a Prince, Ziba is his officer; I cannot but pitty the condition of this good Son of Ionathan; Into how ill hands did hone≈øt Mephibo≈øheth fall, fir≈øt, of a carele≈ø≈øe Nur≈øe, then of a trecherous ≈øeruant; She maymed his body, hee would haue ouerthrowne his e≈øtate; After ≈øome yeares of eye ≈øeruice to
Mephibo≈øheth, wicked Ziba intends to giue him a wor≈øe fall then his nur≈øe. Neuer any Court was free from detractors, from delators, who if they ≈øee a man to be a creeple, that hee cannot goe to ≈øpeake for him≈øelfe, will be telling tales of him, in the eares of the great; ≈øuch a one was this perfidious Ziba; who taking the oportunity of Dauids flight from his Son Ab≈øalom, followes him with a faire pre≈øent, and a fal≈øe tale, accu≈øing his impotent ma≈øter of a foule and trayterous ingratitude; labouring to tread vpon his lame Lord to ray≈øe him≈øelfe to honor: True-harted Mephibo≈øheth had as good a will as the be≈øt;
if he could haue commanded legges, he had not beene left behinde Dauid: now that he cannot goe with him; hee will not be well without him; and therfore puts him≈øelfe to a wilfull and ≈øullen penance, for the ab≈øence and danger of his King; hee will not ≈øo much as put on cleane clothes for the time, as he that could not haue any ioy in him≈øelfe, for the want of his Lord Dauid; Vncon≈øcionable mi≈øcreants care not how they collogue, whom they ≈ølander for a priuate aduantage; Lewd Ziba comes with a gifte in his hand, and a ≈ømooth tale in his mouth; Oh ≈øir, you thought you had a Ionathan at home; but
you will finde a Saul, It were pitty but hee ≈øhould bee ≈øet at your table, that would ≈øit in your throne; you thought Sauls land would haue contented Mephibo≈øheth, but he would haue all yours; though hee bee lame yet hee would bee climbing; would you haue thought that this creple could be plotting for your kingdome, now that you are but gone a≈øide? I≈øhbo≈øheth will neuer die whiles Mephibo≈øheth liues: How did hee now forget his impotence, and ray≈øed vp his ≈øpirits in hope of a day; and dur≈øt ≈øay, that now the time was comne, wherein the Crowne ≈øhould reuert to Sauls true heyre, Oh viper: If a
Serpent bite in ≈øecret when hee is not charmed, no better is a ≈ølanderer; Hone≈øt Mephibo≈øheth in good manners made a dead dog of him≈øelfe, when Dauid offred him the fauour of his board; but Ziba would make him a very dog indeed, an illnatur'd curre, that when Dauid did thus kindely feed him at his owne table, would not only bite his fingers, but flye at his throat.

But what ≈øhall we ≈øay to this? Neither earthly ≈øoueraignty, nor holyne≈ø≈øe can exempt men from humane infirmities. Wi≈øe and good Dauid hath now but one eare; and that mi≈øled; with credulity; His charity in beleeuing
Ziba, makes him vncharitable in di≈øtru≈øting, in cen≈øuring Mephibo≈øheth. The detractor hath not only ≈øudden credit giuen him, but Sauls land, Ionathans Son hath lo≈øt (vnheard) that inheritance, which was giuen him vn≈øought. Heare-≈øay is no ≈øafe ground of any iudgement; Ziba ≈ølaunders, Dauid beleeues, Mephibo≈øheth ≈øuffers.

A diui≈øion was due here indeed; but of Ziba's eares from his head, or his head from his ≈øhoulders, for going about ≈øo maliciou≈øly, to diuide Dauid from the ≈øon of Ionathan; An eye for an eye, was Gods rule; If that had beene true, which Ziba ≈øugge≈øted again≈øt Mephibo≈øheth, he had been worthy to lo≈øe his head with his lands, being fal≈øe, it had beene but rea≈øon, Ziba ≈øhould haue changed heads with Mephibo≈øheth; Had not holy Dauid him≈øelfe beene ≈øo ≈øtung
with venomous tongues, that he cryes out in the bitterne≈ø≈øe of his ≈øoule; What reward ≈øhall be giuen to thee, √¥ thou fal≈øe tongue? euen ≈øharp arrowes with hot burning coles. Hee that was ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of him≈øelfe in Doegs wrong, doth he feele ≈øo little of Mephibo≈øheth in Ziba's? Are the≈øe the arrowes of Dauids quiuer? are the≈øe his hot burning coles (Thou & Ziba diuide?) He that had ≈øayd, Their tongue isa ≈øharp ≈øword, now that hee had the ≈øword of ju≈øt reuenge in his hand, is this the blow hee giues, Diuide the po≈ø≈øe≈øsions? I know not whether, exce≈ø≈øe, or want of mercy, may proue mo≈øt dangerous in the great; the one may
di≈øcourage good intentions with feare; the other may encourage wicked practices through pre≈øumption; Tho≈øe that are in eminent place, mu≈øt learne the mid-way betwixt both; ≈øo pardoning faults, that they may not prouoke them; ≈øo puni≈øhing them, that they may not di≈øhearten vertuous and wel-meant actions; they mu≈øt learne to ≈øing that ab≈øolute ditty (whereof Dauid had here forgotten one part) of Mercy & Iudgement.

div.head: Hanun and Dauids Amba≈ø≈øadours.
div.p:
IT is not the meaning of religion, to make men vnciuill; If the King of Ammon were heatheni≈øh, yet his kindnes may be acknowledged, may bee returned by the King of I≈ørael. I ≈øay not, but that perhaps Dauid, might maintaine too ≈øtrayt a league with that forbidden nation; A little frend≈øhip is enough to an Idolater; but euen the ≈øauage
Cannibals may receiue an an≈øwer of outward courte≈øie: If a very dog fawne vpon vs, wee ≈øtroke him on the head, and clap him on the ≈øide; much le≈ø≈øe is the common band of humanity vntyed by Grace: Di≈øparity in ≈øpirituall profe≈ø≈øions, is no warrant for ingratitude: Hee therfore, who≈øe good nature proclaimed to ≈øhew mercy to any branch of Sauls hou≈øe, for Ionathans ≈øake, will now al≈øo ≈øhew kindne≈ø≈øe to Hanun, for the ≈øake of Naha≈øh his father.

It was the ≈øame Naha≈øh, that offered the cruell condition to the men of Iabe≈øh Gilead, of thru≈øting out their right eyes for the admi≈ø≈øion into his couenant.
He that was thus bloudy in his de≈øignes again≈øt I≈ørael, yet was kinde to Dauid; perhaps for no cau≈øe ≈øo much, as Sauls oppo≈øition; And yet euen this fauour is held worthy both of memory; & retribution: where we haue the acts of courte≈øie, it is not nece≈ø≈øary wee ≈øhould enter into a ≈øtrict examination of the grounds of it; whiles the benefit is ours, let the intention be their owne; What euer the hearts of men are, we mu≈øt look at their hands, and repay, not what they meant, but what they did;

Naha≈øh is dead, Dauid ≈øends Amba≈ø≈øadours to condole his lo≈ø≈øe, and to comfort his ≈øonne
Hanun. No Ammonite, but is ≈øadly affected with the death of a father, though it gaine him a Kingdome: Euen E≈øau could ≈øay, the dayes of mourning for my father will come; No earthly aduantage can fill vp the gap of nature: Tho≈øe children are wor≈øe then Ammonites, that can thinke either gaine, or liberty, worthy to counteruaile a parents lo≈ø≈øe.

Carnall men are wont to mea≈øure anothers foot, by their owne la≈øt; their owne fal≈øhood makes them vniu≈øtly ≈øu≈øpitious of others. The Princes of Ammon, becau≈øe they are guilty to their owne hollowne≈ø≈øe, and doublene≈ø≈øe of heart, are ready
≈øo to iudge of Dauid and his me≈ø≈øengers (Thinke≈øt thou that Dauid doth honour thy father, that hee hath ≈øent comforters vnto thee. Hath not Dauid rather ≈øent his owne ≈øeruants to thee, to ≈øearch the City, and to ≈øpye it out, to ouerthrow it;) It is hard for a wicked heart to think well of any other; becau≈øe it can thinke none better then it ≈øelfe, and knowes it ≈øelfe euill: The freer a man is from vice him≈øelfe, the more charitable he v≈øes to be vnto others.

What≈øoeuer Dauid was particularly in his owne per≈øon, it was ground enough of preiudice, that he was an I≈øraelite; It was an hereditary and deep ≈øetled hatred, that the Ammonites
had conceiued again≈øt their brethren of I≈ørael: neither can they forget that ≈øhamefull and fearefull foyle, which they receiued from the re≈øcuers of Iabe≈øh-Gilead; and now ≈øtill doe they ≈øtomach at the name of I≈ørael; Malice once conciued in worldly hearts, is not ea≈øily extingui≈øhed, but vpon all occa≈øions, is ready to break forth into a flame of reuengefull actions.

Nothing can be more dangerous, then for young Princes, to meet with ill coun≈øell in the entrance of their gouernment; for both then are they mo≈øt prone to take it, and mo≈øt difficultly recouered from it; If we be ≈øet out of our way in the beginning
of our journey, wee wander all the day; How happy is that ≈øtate, where both the Coun≈øellors are faithfull, to giue only good aduice; and the King wi≈øe to di≈øcerne good aduice from euill: The young King of Ammon is ea≈øily drawne to beleeue his Peeres, and to mi≈øtru≈øt the me≈ø≈øengers; and hauing now in his conceit turned them into Spies, entertaines them with a ≈øcornefull di≈øgrace; hee ≈øhaues off, one halfe of their beards, & cuts off one halfe of their garments; expo≈øing them to the deri≈øion of all beholders. The I≈øraelites were forbidden either a ≈øhauen beard, or a ≈øhort garment; in de≈øpight, perhaps, of
their Law, the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadours are ≈øent away with both: Certainly in a de≈øpight of their Ma≈øter, and a ≈øcorne of their per≈øons.

It is lawfull for publique per≈øons, to feele their owne indignities, and to endeauour their
reuenge. Now Dauid ≈øends all the ho≈øt of the mighty men to puni≈øh Ammon, for ≈øo foule an abu≈øe; Tho≈øe that receiued the Me≈ø≈øengers of his loue, with ≈øcorne and in≈øolency, ≈øhall now bee ≈øeuerely ≈øaluted with the Me≈ø≈øengers of his wrath. It is ju≈øt both with God and men, that they, who know not how to take fauours aright, ≈øhould ≈ømart with judgements. Kindne≈ø≈øe repul≈øed, breakes forth into indignation, how much more when it is repayd with an iniurious affront?

Dauid cannot but feele his owne cheekes ≈øhauen, and his owne cotes cut in his Amba≈ø≈øadors; They did but carry his
per≈øon to Hanun; neither can hee therfore but appropriate to him≈øelfe the kindne≈ø≈øe, or iniury offered vnto them; He that did ≈øo take to heart the cutting off, but the lap of King Sauls garment, when it was layd a≈øide from him, how mu≈øt hee needes bee affected with this di≈ødainefull haluing of his haire and robes, in the per≈øon of his Deputies. The name of Amba≈ø≈øadours hath beene euer ≈øacred, and by the vniuer≈øall Law of Nations, hath carried in it ≈øufficient protection, from all publique wrongs, nether hath it euer beene violated, without a reuenge. Oh God, what ≈øhall wee ≈øay to tho≈øe
notorious contempts which are dayly ca≈øt vpon thy ≈øpirituall me≈ø≈øengers? Is it po≈ø≈øible thou ≈øhould≈øt not feele them, thou ≈øhould≈øt not auenge them? Wee are made a gazing ≈øtocke to the world, to Angels and to men, wee are de≈øpi≈øed and trodden downe in the du≈øt; Who hath beleeued our report, and to whom is the arme of the Lord reuealed?

How ob≈øtinate are wicked men in their peruer≈øe re≈øolutions. The≈øe fooli≈øh Ammonites had rather hyre Syrians to maintaine a warre again≈øt I≈ørael in ≈øo foule a quarrell, be≈øides the hazard of their owne liues,
then confe≈ø≈øe the error of their iealous mi≈ø-con≈øtruction.

It is one of the madde principles of wickedne≈ø≈øe, that it is a weakene≈ø≈øe to relent, and rather to Dye then yeild; Euen ill cau≈øes once vndertaken, mu≈øt bee vpheld although with bloud; whereas the gracious hart finding his owne mis-taking, doth not only remit of an vngrounded di≈øplea≈øure, but ≈øtudies to bee reuenged of it ≈øelfe; and to giue ≈øatisfaction to the offended.

The mercenary Syrians are drawne to venture their liues for a fee; twenty thou≈øand of them are hyred into the field again≈øt I≈ørael; Fond Pagans that
know not the value of a man; their bloud co≈øt them nothing, and they care not to ≈øell it good cheape; How can wee thinke tho≈øe men haue Soules, that e≈øteeme a little white earth aboue them≈øelues? that neuer inquire into the iu≈øtice of the quarell, but the rate of the pay, that can rifle for drams of ≈øiluer, in the bowels of their owne fle≈øh, and either kill or die for a dayes wages?

Ioab the wi≈øe Generall of I≈ørael ≈øoone findes, where the ≈øtrength of the battle lay, and ≈øo mar≈øhalls his troupes, that the choyce of his men ≈øhall incounter the vantgard of the Syrians. His brother Abi≈øhai leads the
re≈øt again≈øt the children of Ammon; with this couenant of mutuall a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, (If the Syrians be too ≈øtrong for mee, then thou ≈øhalt helpe mee; but if the children of Ammon be too ≈øtrong for thee, then will I come and helpe thee;) It is an happy thing, when the captains of Gods people ioyne together as brethren, and lend their hand to the ayde of each other again≈øt the common aduer≈øary. Concord in defence, or a≈ø≈øault is the way to victory; as contrarily, the deui≈øion of the Leaders is the ouerthrow of the army.

Set a≈øide ≈øome particular actions, Ioab was a worthy Captaine, both for wi≈ødome and valour. Who could either exhort
or re≈øolue better then he, (Be of good courage, and let vs play the men, for our people, and for the cities of our God; and the Lord doe that which ≈øeemeth him good?) It is not either priuate glory or profit that whets his fortitude, but the re≈øpect to the cau≈øe of God, and his people; That Souldier can neuer an≈øwer it to God, that ≈øtrikes not more as a Iu≈øticer, then as an enemy; Neither doth hee content him≈øelfe with his owne courage, but he animates others. The tongue of a Commander fights more then his hand; it is enough for priuate men to exerci≈øe what life and limmes they haue, a good Leader mu≈øt out of his owne abundance,
put life and ≈øpirits into all others; If a Lyon lead ≈øheep into the field, there is hope of victory: La≈øtly, when he hath done his be≈øt, he re≈øolues to depend vpon God for the i≈ø≈øue: not tru≈øting to his ≈øword, or his bowe, but to the prouidence of the Almightie for ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; as a man religiou≈øly awfull, and awfully confident, whiles there ≈øhould bee no want in their owne indeuours: he knew well that the race was not to the ≈øwift, nor the battle to the ≈øtrong, therefore hee lookes vp aboue the hills whence commeth his ≈øaluation; All valour is cowardi≈øe to that, which is built vpon religion.

I maruel not to ≈øee Ioab victorious, whiles he is thus godly; The Syrians flee before him, like flocks of ≈øheepe; the Amonites follow them; The two Sons of Zeruiah haue nothing to doe, but to pur≈øue and execute; The throates of the Amonites are cut, for cutting the beards and cotes of the I≈øraeliti≈øh me≈ø≈øengers; Neither doth this reuenge end in the field; Rabba the royall city of Ammon is ≈øtrongly beleguered by Ioab; the City of waters (after well-neare a yeares ≈øiege) yeildeth; the re≈øt can no longer hold out; now Ioab, as one that de≈øired more to approue him≈øelfe a loyall and carefull ≈øubiect,
then a happy Generall, ≈øends to his ma≈øter Dauid that he ≈øhould come per≈øonally, and encampe again≈øt the City and take it; Lea≈øt (≈øaith he) I take it and it be called after my name. Oh noble and imitable fidelity of a dutifull ≈øeruant, that prefers his Lord to him≈øelfe, and is ≈øo farre from ≈øtealing honor from his ma≈øters de≈øerts, that he willingly remits of his owne, to adde vnto his. The warre was not his; he was only imployed by his Soueraigne; The ≈øame per≈øon that was wronged in the Amba≈ø≈øadors, reuengeth by his ≈øoldiers; the prai≈øe of the act ≈øhall (like fountaine water) returne to the ≈øea, whence it originally
came: To ≈øeeke a mans owne glory is not glory. Alas, how many are there, who being ≈øent to ≈øue for God, wooe for them≈øelues. Oh God, it is a fearfull thing to robbe thee of that which is deare≈øt to thee, glory; which as thou wilt not giue to any creature, ≈øo much l ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe wilt thou indure that any creature ≈øhould filtch it from thee, and giue it to him≈øelfe. Haue thou the honor of all our actions, who giue≈øt a beeing to our actions and vs, and in both ha≈øt mo≈øt iu≈øtly regarded thine owne prai≈øe.

div.head: Dauid with Bath≈øheba and ∆≤RIAH.
div.p:
WIth what vnwillingnes, with what feare, do I ≈øtill look vpon the mi≈øcariage of the man after Gods owne hart? O holy Prophet, who can promi≈øe him≈øelfe alwayes to ≈øtand, when he ≈øees thee falne and maimed in the fall? Who can a≈ø≈øure him≈øelfe of an immunity from the foule≈øt ≈øins, when hee ≈øees the offending ≈øo haynou≈øly,
≈øo bloudily? Let profane eyes behold thee contentedly, as a patterne, as an excu≈øe of ≈øinning; I ≈øhall neuer looke at thee but through teares, as a wofull ≈øpectacle of humane infirmity:

Whiles Ioab and all I≈ørael were bu≈øie in the warre again≈øt Ammon, in the ≈øiege of Rabbah, Satan findes time to lay ≈øiege to the ≈øecure hart of Dauid; Who euer found Dauid thus tempted, thus foyled in the dayes of his bu≈øie warres? Now only doe I ≈øee the King of I≈ørael, ri≈øing from his bed in the euening; The time was, when he ro≈øe vp in the morning to his early deuotions; when hee brake his
nightly re≈øt with publique cares, with the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of e≈øtate; all that while he was innocent, he was holy; but now that he wallowes in the bed of idlene≈ø≈øe, he is fit to inuite a tentation. The indu≈øtrious man hath no lea≈øure to ≈øinne. The idle hath neither lea≈øure nor power to auoyd ≈øinne; Exerci≈øe is not wore whol≈øome for the body, then for the Soule, the remi≈ø≈øion whereof breeds matter of di≈øea≈øe in both: The water that hath beene heated, ≈øoone≈øt freezeth; the mo≈øt actiue Spirit ≈øoone≈øt ty ‚Ä¢ eth with ≈ølackning; The earth ≈øtands ≈øtill, and is all dregs; the heauens euer moue, and are pure. We haue no rea≈øon
to complaine of the a≈ø≈øiduity of work; the toyle of action is an≈øwered by the benefit; If wee did le≈ø≈øe wee ≈øhould ≈øuffer more; Satan like an idle companion, if he finde vs bu≈øie, flies backe and ≈øees it no time to entertaine vaine purpo≈øes with vs; Wee cannot plea≈øe him better then by ca≈øting away our work, to hold chat with him; wee cannot yeild ≈øo farre and bee guiltle≈ø≈øe.

Euen Dauids eyes haue no ≈øooner the ≈øleepe rubbed out of them, then they roue to wanton pro≈øpects; He walkes vpon his roofe, and ≈øees Bath≈øheba wa≈øhing her ≈øelfe; inquires after her, ≈øends for her, ≈øolicits her to
vncleanene≈ø≈øe. The ≈øame Spirit that ≈øhut vp his eyes in an vn≈øea≈øonable ≈øleepe, opens them vpon an inti≈øing obiect; whiles ≈øinne hath ≈øuch a Solicitor, it cannot want either meanes or opportunitie‚ñ™ I cannot thinke Bath≈øheba could bee ≈øo immode≈øt, as to wa≈øh her ≈øelfe openly, e≈øpecially from her naturall vncleanene≈ø≈øe; Lu≈øt is quick-≈øighted; Dauid hath e≈øpyed her, where ≈øhe could e≈øpye no beholder: His eyes recoyle vpon his hart, and haue ≈ømitten him with a ≈øinfull de≈øire.

There can bee no ≈øafety to that Soule, where the ≈øen≈øes are let loo≈øe. He can neuer keep his couenant with God, that makes
not a couenant with his eyes: It is an Idle pre≈øumption to thinke the outward man may be free, whiles the inward is ≈øafe: He is more then a man, who≈øe hart is not led by his eies, he is no regenerate man who≈øe, eyes are not re≈øtrayned by his hart.

Oh Bath≈øheba, how wert thou wa≈øhed from thine vncleanene≈ø≈øe, when thou yeilded≈øt to goe into an adulterous bed? Neuer wert thou ≈øo foule: as now when thou wert new wa≈øhed; The wor≈øt of nature, is cleanline≈ø≈øe, to the be≈øt of ≈øinne: thou had≈øt beene cleane if thou had≈øt not wa≈øhed; yet for thee, I know how to plead infirmity
of ≈øexe; and the importunity of a King; But what ≈øhall I ≈øay for thee, O thou royall Prophet, and propheticall King of I≈ørael; where ≈øhall I finde ought to extenuate that crime, for which God him≈øelfe hath noted thee? Did not thine holy profe≈ø≈øion teach thee to abhorre ≈øuch a ≈øin more then death? Was not thy iu≈øtice wont to puni≈øh this ≈øin with no le≈ø≈øe then death? Did not thy very calling call thee to a protection and pre≈øeruation of iu≈øtice, of cha≈øtity in thy ≈øubiects? Did≈øt thou want ≈øtore of wines of thine owne? wert thou re≈øtrayned from taking more? was there no beauty in I≈ørael, but in a ≈øubiects mariage-bed?
Wert thou ouercome by the vehement ≈øolicitations of an adultere≈ø≈øe? wert thou not the tempter, the pro≈øecutor of this vncleanene≈ø≈øe? I ≈øhould accu≈øe thee deeply, if thou had≈øt not accu≈øed thy ≈øelfe; Nothing wanted to greaten thy ≈øinne, or our wonder, and feare. O God, whither doe wee goe if thou ≈øtay vs not? Who euer among≈øt the millions of thy ≈øeruants could finde him≈øelfe furni≈øhed with ≈øtronger pre≈øeruatiues again≈øt ≈øinne? Again≈øt whom could ≈øuch a ≈øinne finde le≈ø≈øe pretence of preuailing? Oh keep thou vs, that pre≈øumtuous ≈øins preuaile not ouer vs; So only ≈øhall wee be free from great offences.

The ≈øuites of Kings are imperatiue; Ambition did now proue a bawd to lu≈øt. Bath≈øheba yeildeth to offend God, to di≈øhonour her husband, to clogge and wound her owne Soule, to abu≈øe her body: Di≈øhone≈øty growes bold, when it is countenanced with greatne≈ø≈øe. Eminent per≈øons had need be carefull of their demaunds; they ≈øinne by authority, that are ≈øolicited by the mighty.

Had Bath≈øheba beene mindefull of her matrimonial fidelity, perhaps Dauid had beene ≈øoone checked in his inordinate de≈øire; her facility furthers the ≈øinne. The fir≈øt motioner of euill is mo≈øt faulty, but as in
quarels, ≈øo in offences, the ≈øecond blow (which is the con≈øent) makes the fray. Good Io≈øeph was moued to folly, by his great and beautifull mi≈øtres, this fire fell vpon wet tinder, and therefore ≈øoone went out. Sinne is not acted alone; if but one party bee wi≈øe, both e≈øcape. It is no excu≈øe to ≈øay, I was tempted, though by the great, though by the holy and learned; Almo≈øt all ≈øinners are mi≈øled by that transformed Angel of light; The action is that wee mu≈øt regard, not the per≈øon; Let the mouer be neuer ≈øo glorious, if he ≈øtirre vs to euill, hee mu≈øt be intertained with defiance.

The God that knowes how
to rai≈øe good out of euill, ble≈ø≈øes an adulterous copulation with that increa≈øe, which hee denyes to the cha≈øt imbracements of hone≈øt wedlock: Bath≈øheba hath conceiued by Dauid; and now at once conceiues a ≈øorrow and care how to ≈ømother the ≈øhame of her conception; He that did the fact, mu≈øt hide it. Oh Dauid, where is thy repentance? Where is thy tenderne≈ø≈øe and compunction of hart? Where are tho≈øe holy meditations, which had wont to take vp thy Soule? Alas, in ≈øteed of clearing thy ≈øinne, thou laboure≈øt to cloke it; and ≈øpende≈øt tho≈øe thoughts in the concealing of thy wickedne≈ø≈øe, which thou ≈øhould≈øt
rather haue be≈øtowed in preuenting it: The be≈øt of Gods children may not onely bee drenched in the waues of ≈øin, but lye in them for the time, and perhaps ≈øinke twice to the bottome; What hypocrite could haue done wor≈øe, then ≈øtudy how to couer the face of his ≈øin from the eyes of men, whiles heregarded not the ≈øting of ≈øin in his ≈øoule. As there are ≈øome acts, wherein the Hypocrite is a Saint, ≈øo there are ≈øome, wherin the greate≈øt Saint vpon earth may be an Hypocrite; Saul did thus goe about to colour his ≈øin, and is cur≈øed; The ve≈ø≈øels of mercy and wrath, are not euer di≈øtingui≈øhable by their actions.
Hee makes the difference, that will haue mercy on whom he will, and whom he will, hee hardeneth.

It is rare and hard to commit a ≈øingle ≈øinne; Dauid hath abu≈øed the wife of Vriah, now hee would abu≈øe his per≈øon, in cau≈øing him to father a fal≈øe ≈øeede: That worthy Hittite is ≈øent for from the wars; and now after ≈øome cunning, and far-fetcht que≈øtions; is di≈ømi≈ø≈øed to his hou≈øe, not without a pre≈øent of fauour; Dauid could not but imagine, that the beauty of his Bath≈øheba, mu≈øt needes be attractiue enough to an husband, whom long ab≈øence in wars, had with-held all that while
from ≈øo plea≈øing a bed; neither could he thinke, that ≈øince that face, and tho≈øe bre≈øts had power to allure him≈øelfe to an vnlawfull lu≈øt, it could bee po≈ø≈øible, that Vriah ≈øhould not bee inuited by them, to an allowed and warrantable fruition.

That Dauids heart might now the rather ≈øtrike him, in comparing the cha≈øte re≈øolutions of his ≈øeruant, with his owne light incontinence; good Vriah ≈øleeps at the doore of the Kings palace, making choyce of a ≈øtony pillow, vnder the canopy of Heauen, rather then the delicate bed of her, whom hee thought as hone≈øt, as he knew faire. The Arke (≈øaith he) and I≈ørael, and Iudah,
dwell in tents, and my Lord Ioab, and the ≈øeruants of my Lord, abide in the open fields; ≈øhall I then goe into mine hou≈øe, to eat, and drinke, and lye with my wife; by thy life, and by the life of thy ≈øoule, I will not doe this thing. Who can but bee a≈øtoni≈øhed at this change, to ≈øee a Souldier au≈øtere, and a Prophet wanton? And how doth that Souldiers au≈øterity, ≈øhame the Prophets wantonne≈ø≈øe? Oh zealous and mortified ≈øoule, worthy of a more faithfull wife, of a more iu≈øt ma≈øter, how did≈øt thou ouer-looke all ba≈øe ≈øen≈øuality, and hated≈øt to be happy alone? War and lu≈øt had wont to bee reputed frends; thy bre≈øt is not more full of courage then cha≈øtity,
and is ≈øo far from wandring after forbidden plea≈øures, that it refu≈øeth lawfull.

There is a time to laugh, and a time to mourne; a time to embrace, and a time to be far from embracing; euen the be≈øt actions are not alwayes ≈øea≈øonable, much le≈ø≈øe the indifferent: He that euer takes liberty to doe what he may, ≈øhall offend no le≈ø≈øe, then he that ≈øometimes takes liberty to doe what he may not.

If any thing, the Arke of God is fitte≈øt to lead our times; according as that is either di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, or pro≈øpereth, ≈øhould we frame our mirth, or mourning. To dwell in ≈øieled hou≈øes, whiles the Temple lyes
wa≈øte, is the ground of Gods iu≈øt quarrell. How ≈øhall wee ≈øing a ≈øong of the Lord in a ≈øtrange land; If I forget thee, √¥ Ieru≈øalem, let my right hand forget her cunning; If I do not remember thee, let my tongue cleaue to the roofe of my mouth; yea, if I prefer not Hieru≈øalem to my cheefe ioy.

As euery man is a limme of the community, ≈øo mu≈øt hee be affected with the e≈øtate of the vniuer≈øal body, whether healthfull, or langui≈øhing; It did not more aggrauate Dauids ≈øin, that whiles the Arke and I≈ørael was in hazard and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, he could finde time to loo≈øe the reynes to wanton de≈øires, and actions,
then it magnifies the religious zeale of Vriah, that he abandons comfort, till he ≈øee the Arke and I≈ørael victorious.
Common dangers, or calamities mu≈øt (like the rapt motion) carry our hearts contrary to to the wayes of our priuate occa≈øions.

Hee that cannot bee mooued with words, ≈øhall be tryed with wine, Vriah had equally prote≈øted again≈øt fea≈øting at home, and ≈øociety with his wife; To the one, the authority of a King forces him abroad, in hope that the exce≈ø≈øe thereof ≈øhall force him to the other: It is like, that holy Captaine intended onely to yeeld ≈øo much obedience, as
might con≈øi≈øt with his cour≈øe of au≈øterity. But wine is a mocker, when it goes plau≈øibly in, no man can imagine how it will rage and tyrannize; he that receiues that Traytor within his gates, ≈øhall too late complaine of a ≈øurprizall. Like vnto that ill ≈øpirit, it in≈øinuates ≈øweetly, but in the end, it bites like a Serpent, & hurts like a Cockatrice. Euen good Vrias is made drunk; the holye≈øt ≈øoule may bee ouertaken; It is hard gaine-≈øaying, where a King begins an health to a ≈øubiect; Where, oh where, will this wickedne≈ø≈øe end? Dauid will now procure the ≈øin of another, to hide his owne; Vriahs drunkenne≈ø≈øe is more Dauids
offence, then his. It is weakly yeelded to of the one, which was wilfully intended of the other. The one was as the ≈øinner, the other as the tempter.

Had not Dauid knowne, that wine was an inducement to lu≈øt, he had ≈øpared tho≈øe ≈øuperfluous cups. Experience had taught him, that the eye debauched with wine, will looke vpon ≈øtrange women: The Drunkard may bee any thing ≈øaue good. Yet in this the ayme failed; Grace is ≈øtronger then wine; Whiles that with-holds, in vaine ≈øhall the fury of the grape attempt to carry Vriah to his own bed. Sober Dauid is now wor≈øe then drunken Vriah. Had not
the King of I≈ørael beene more intoxicate with ≈øin, then Vriah with drinke, he had not in a ≈øober intemperance climbed vp into that bed, which the drunken temperance of Vriah refu≈øed.

If Dauid had beene but him≈øelf, how had he loued, how had he honoured this hone≈øt and religious zeale, in his ≈øo faithfull ≈øeruant; whom now he cruelly ≈øeekes to reward with death? That fact which wine cannot hide, the ≈øword ≈øhall; Vriah ≈øhall beare his owne Mittimus vnto Ioab; Put yee Vriah in the fore front of the ≈øtrength of the battle, and recule backe from him, that he may bee ≈ømitten, and die.) What is becomne of
thee, √¥ thou good Spirit, that had≈øt wont to guide thy cho≈øen ≈øeruant in his former wayes? Is not this the man, whom wee lately ≈øaw ≈øo heart-≈ømitten, for but cutting off the lap of the garment of a wicked Ma≈øter, that is now thus laui≈øh of the bloud, of a gracious and well-de≈øeruing Seruant? Could it be likely, that ≈øo worthy a Captaine could fall alone? Could Dauid haue expiated this ≈øinne with his owne bloud, it had beene but well ≈øpent, but to couer his ≈øinne with the innocent bloud of others, was a crime aboue a≈øtoni≈øhment. Oh the deepe deceitfulne≈ø≈øe of ≈øinne; If the Deuill ≈øhould haue comne
to Dauid, in the mo≈øt louely forme of Bath≈øheba her ≈øelfe, and at the fir≈øt ≈øhould haue directly, and in termes, ≈øolicited him to murder his be≈øt ≈øeruant; I doubt not, but hee would haue ≈øpat ≈øcorne in that face, on which he ≈øhould otherwi≈øe haue doted; now, by many cunning windings, Satan ri≈øes vp to that tentation, & preuailes; that ≈øhall be done for a colour of guiltine≈ø≈øe, whreof the ≈øoule would haue hated to be immediately guilty; Euen tho≈øe, that find a iu≈øt horrour, in leaping downe from ≈øome hie tower, yet may be per≈øwaded to de≈øcend by ≈øtayres to the bottome. Hee knowes not where hee ≈øhall ≈øtay, that hath
willingly ≈ølipt into a knowne wickedne≈ø≈øe.

How many doth an eminent offender draw with him into euill? It could not be, but that diuers of the attendants both of Dauid and Bath≈øheba mu≈øt be con≈øcious to that adultery; Great mens ≈øinnes are ≈øeldome ≈øecret; And now Ioab mu≈øt bee fetcht in, as acce≈ø≈øary to the murder: How mu≈øt this example needes harden Ioab again≈øt the con≈øcience of Abners blood? Whiles he cannot but thinke, Dauid cannot auenge that in me, which he acteth him≈øelfe.

div.head: Nathan and Dauid.
div.p:
Dauid was a Prophet of God, yet he hath not only ≈øtept into the≈øe foule ≈øinnes, but ≈øoiournes with them; If any profe≈ø≈øion or ≈øtate of life could haue priuiledged from ≈øinne; the Angels had not ≈øinned in heauen, nor man in Paradi≈øe: Nathan the Prophet is ≈øent to the Prophet Dauid, for reproofe, for conuiction, Had it beene any other mans ca≈øe, none could haue
bene more quick-≈øighted then the Princely Prophet, in his owne he is ≈øo blinde, that God is fayne to lend him others eyes. Euen the Phi≈øition him≈øelfe when he is ≈øicke, ≈øends for the coun≈øell of tho≈øe whom his health did mutually ayde with adui≈øe. Let no man think him≈øelfe too good to learne; Teachers them≈øelues may be taught that in their owne particular, which in a generality they haue often taught others; It is not only ignorance that is to be remoued, but mi≈ø-affection.

Who can pre≈øcribe a iu≈øt period to the be≈øt mans repentance? About ten moneths are pa≈ø≈øed ≈øince Dauids ≈øinne; in all
which time I finde no newes of any ≈øerious compunction; It could not be but ≈øome glaunces of remor≈øe mu≈øt needes haue pa≈ø≈øed thorough his Soule long ere this; but a due and ≈øolemne contrition was not heard of till Nathans me≈ø≈øage; and perhaps had bene further adiourned, if that Monitor had beene longer deferred; Alas, what long and dead ≈øleepes may the holye≈øt Soule take in fearefull ≈øinnes; Were it not for thy mercy, O God, the be≈øt of vs ≈øhould end our ≈øpirituall lethargie in a ≈øleep of death:

Had not Nathan bene v≈øed to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Dauids eare; this complaint had beene ≈øu≈øpected. It well be≈øeemes a King to take information by a Prophet. Whiles wi≈øe Nathan was querulou≈øly di≈øcour≈øing, of the cruell rich man that had forceably taken away the only
Lambe of his poore neighbour, how willingly doth Dauid li≈øten to the ≈øtory, and how ≈øharply (euen aboue law) doth he cen≈øure the fact? As the Lord liueth the man that hath done this thing ≈øhall ≈øurely dye.) Full little did he thinke that he had pronounced ≈øentence again≈øt him≈øelfe; It had not bene ≈øo heauy, if he had knowne on whom it ≈øhould haue light; We haue open eares & quick tongues to the vices of others; How ≈øeuere Iu≈øticers we can be to our very owne crimes in others per≈øons? how flattering para≈øites to anothers crime in our ≈øelues? The life of doctrine is in application; Nathan might haue beene long enough
in his narration, in his inuectiue, ere Dauid would haue bene touched with his owne guiltine≈ø≈øe; but now that the Prophet brings the word home to his bo≈øome, he cannot but be affected. Wee may take plea≈øure, to heare men ≈øpeake in the clouds, we neuer take profit till we finde a propriety in the exhortation, or reproofe; There was not more cunning in the parable, then courage in the application (Thou art the man) If Dauid be a King, hee may not look, not to heare of his faults; Gods me≈ø≈øages may be no other then vnpartial. It is a trecherous flattery in diuine errands to regard greatne≈ø≈øe: If Prophets
mu≈øt be mannerly in the forme, yet in the matter of reproofe, re≈øolute: The words are not their owne, They are but the Heralds of the King of heauen, Thus ≈øaith the Lord God of I≈ørael.

How thunder-≈øtriken do we thinke Dauid did now ≈øtand? how did the change of his colour bewray the confu≈øion in his Soule; whiles his con≈øcience ≈øaid the ≈øame within, which the Prophet ≈øounded in his eare? And now lea≈øt ought ≈øhould be wanting to his humiliation, all Gods former fauours ≈øhall bee layd before his eyes, by way of exprobration: He is worthy to be vpbraided with mercies, that hath abu≈øed mercyes vnto wantonne≈ø≈øe;
whiles we doe well, God giues and ≈øayes nothing, when we doe ill, hee layes his benefits in our di≈øh, and ca≈øts them in our teeth, that our ≈øhame may bee ≈øo much the more; by how much our obligations haue bene greater. The ble≈ø≈øings of God in our vnworthy caryage proue but the aggrauations of ≈øinne, and additions to iudgement.

I ≈øee all Gods children falling into ≈øinne, ≈øome of them lying in ≈øinne; none of them maintayning their ≈øinne; Dauid cannot haue the hart, or the face to ≈øtand out again≈øt the me≈ø≈øage of God, but now as a man confounded, and condemned in
him≈øelfe, hee cryes out in the bitterne≈ø≈øe of a wounded Soule, (I haue ≈øinned again≈øt the Lord) It was a ≈øhort word, but pa≈ø≈øionate; and ≈øuch as came from the bottome of a contrite hart; The greate≈øt griefes are not mo≈øt verball: Saul confe≈ø≈øed his ≈øinne more largely, le≈ø≈øe effectually; God cares not for phra≈øes, but for affections. The fir≈øt peece of our amends to God for ≈øinning, is the acknowledgement of ≈øinne; He can do little that in a iu≈øt offence cannot accu≈øe him≈øelfe: If we cannot be ≈øo good as we would, it is rea≈øon we ≈øhould do God ≈øo much right, as to ≈øay, how euill we are. And why was not this don ≈øooner?
It is ≈øtrange to ≈øee how ea≈øily ≈øin gets into the hart, how hardly it gets out of the mouth; Is it becau≈øe ≈øinne, like vnto Satan, where it hath got po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is de≈øirous to hold it; and knowes that it is fully eiected by a free confe≈ø≈øion? or, becau≈øe in a guiltine≈ø≈øe of deformity, it hides it ≈øelfe in the bre≈øt where it is once intertained, and hates the light? or becau≈øe the tongue is ≈øo fee'd with ≈øelfe-loue, that it is loath to bee drawne vnto any verdict again≈øt the hart, or hands? or, is it out of an idle mi≈øpri≈øion of ≈øhame, which whiles it ≈øhould bee placed in offending, is mi≈øplaced in di≈øclo≈øing of our offence?
Howeuer, ≈øure I am, that God hath need euen of racks to draw out confe≈ø≈øions, and ≈øcarce in death it ≈øelfe, are we wrought to a di≈øcouery of our errors.

There is no one thing, wherin our folly ≈øhewes it ≈øelfe more, then in the≈øe hurtfull concealements: Contrary to the proceedings of humane Iu≈øtice, it is with God, Confe≈ø≈øe and liue; no ≈øooner can Dauid ≈øay, I haue ≈øinned, then Nathan infers, The Lord al≈øo hath put away thy ≈øin. He that hides his ≈øins ≈øhall not pro≈øper, but hee that confe≈ø≈øeth and for≈øaketh them, ≈øhall finde mercy Who would not accu≈øe him≈øelfe, to be acquitted of God? O God, who would not tell his
wickednes to thee, that know≈øt it better then his owne heart, that his heart may bee ea≈øed of that wickedne≈ø≈øe, which being not told, killeth? Since we haue ≈øinned, why ≈øhould we be niggardly of that action, wherein wee may at once giue glory to thee, and releefe to our ≈øoules?

Dauid had ≈øworne in a zeale of Iu≈øtice, that the rich Oppre≈ø≈øour, for but taking his poore neighbours lambe, ≈øhould dye the death; God, by Nathan, is more fauourable to Dauid, then to take him at his word; Thou ≈øhalt not dye: O the maruellous power of repentance; Be≈øides adultery, Dauid had ≈øhed the bloud of innocent Vriah; The
≈øtrict law was eye for tye, tooth for tooth; He that ≈ømiteth with the ≈øword, ≈øhall peri≈øh with the ≈øword; Yet, as if a penitent confe≈ø≈øion had di≈øpen≈øed with the rigor of Iu≈øtice, now God ≈øaies, Thou ≈øhalt not dye. Dauid was the voyce of the Law, awarding death vnto ≈øin; Nathan was the voyce of the Go≈øpell, awarding life vnto the repentance for ≈øin. What≈øoeuer the ≈øore bee, neuer any ≈øoule applyed this remedy, and dyed; neuer any ≈øoule e≈øcaped death, that applyed it not.

Dauid him≈øelfe ≈øhall not dye for this fact; but his mi≈ø-begotten childe ≈øhall dye for him; He that ≈øayd, The Lord hath put away thy ≈øin, yet ≈øayd al≈øo, The ≈øword ≈øhall
not depart from thine hou≈øe.

The ≈øame mouth, with one breath, pronounces the ≈øentence both of ab≈øolution, and death, Ab≈øolution to the per≈øon, death to the i≈ø≈øue. Pardon may well ≈øtand with temporall afflictions. Where God hath forgiuen, though he doe not puni≈øh, yet he may cha≈øtize, and that vnto bloud; neither doth he alwaies forbeare correction, where hee remits reuenge. So long as he ≈ømites vs not as an angry Iudge, wee may indure to ≈ømart from him, as a louing father.

Yet euen this rod did Dauid deprecate with teares: how faine would he ≈øhake off ≈øo ea≈øie a lode? The childe is ≈øtricken;
the father fa≈øts and prayes, and weepes, and lyes all night vpon the earth, and abhors the noy≈øe of comfort; That childe, which was the fruit and monument of his odious adultery, whom hee could neuer haue looked vpon, without a recognition of his ≈øin; in who≈øe face he could not but haue ≈øtill read the records of his own ≈øhame, is thus mourned for, thus ≈øued for; It is ea≈øie to ob≈øerue that good man ouerpa≈ø≈øionately affected to his children. Who would not haue thought, that Dauid might haue held him≈øelfe well appayd, that his ≈øoule e≈øcaped an eternall death, his body a violent: though God ≈øhould puni≈øh his
≈øin, in that childe, in whom hee ≈øinned: Yet euen again≈øt this cro≈ø≈øe, he bends his prayers, as if nothing had been forgiuen him: There is no childe that would be ≈øcourged, if he might e≈øcape for crying; No affliction is for the time other then greeuous; neither is therfore yeelded vnto, without ≈øome kinde of reluctation. Far yet was it from the heart of Dauid, to make any oppo≈øition to the will of God; he ≈øued, he ≈øtrugled not; There is no impatience in entreaties; He wel knew, that the threats of teÃÑ poral euils, ran commonly with a ≈øecret condition; and therfore might perhaps bee auoyded by humble importunity: If any
meanes vnder Heauen can auert judgements, it is our prayers.

God Could not chu≈øe, but like well the boldne≈ø≈øe of Dauids faith, who after the apprehen≈øion of ≈øo heauy a di≈øplea≈øure, is ≈øo far from doubting of the forgiuene≈ø≈øe of his ≈øin, that hee dares become a Sutor vnto God for his ≈øicke childe. Sinne doth not make vs more ≈øtrange, then faith, confident.

But, it is not in the power of the ≈øtronge≈øt faith, to pre≈øerue vs from all afflictions; After all Dauids prayers and teares, the childe mu≈øt dye. The carefull ≈øeruants dare but whi≈øper this ≈øad newes: They, who had found their Ma≈øter ≈øo auer≈øe
from the motion of comfort, in the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe of the childe, feared him vncapable of comfort in his death.

p.hi: (Whiles the childe was yet aliue, I fa≈øted and wept, for I ≈øayd, Who can tell whether the Lord will bee gracious to mee, that the childe may liue, but now hee is dead, Wherefore ≈øhould I fa≈øt? Can I bring him backe againe?)

div.p:
The greefe that goes before an euill for remedy, can hardly bee too much, but that which followes an euill, pa≈øt remedy, cannot bee too little: Euen in the ≈øadde≈øt accident, death, we may yeeld ≈øomething to nature, nothing to impatience: Immoderation of ≈øorrow, for lo≈ø≈øes pa≈øt hope of recouery, is
more ≈øullen, then v≈øe-full; our ≈øtomach may be bewrayed by it, not our wi≈ødome.

div.head: Amnon and Tamar.
div.p:
IT is not po≈ø≈øible, that any word of God ≈øhould fall to the ground: Dauid is not more ≈øure of forgiuene≈ø≈øe, then ≈ømart: Three maine ≈øins pa≈ø≈øed him in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of Vriah; Adultery, murder, di≈ø≈øimulation: for all which, he receiues pre≈øent payment, for adultery, in the deflouring of his daughter Thamar; for murder, in the killing of his ≈øon Amnon; for di≈ø≈øimulation in
the contriuing of both. Yet all this was but the beginning of euils. Where the father of the family, brings ≈øinne home to the hou≈øe, it is not ea≈øily ≈øwept out: Vnlawfull lu≈øt propagates it ≈øelfe by example; How iu≈øtly is Dauid ≈øcourged by the ≈øin of his ≈øons, whom his act taught to offend?

Maacah was the daughter of an Heatheni≈øh King; By her, had Dauid that beautifull, but vnhappy i≈ø≈øue; Ab≈øalom, and his no le≈ø≈øe faire ≈øi≈øter, Thamar: Perhaps, thus late doth Dauid feele the puni≈øhment of that vnfit choyce: I ≈øhould haue maruelled, if ≈øo holy a man had not found cro≈ø≈øes in ≈øo vnequall
a match, either in his per≈øon, or at lea≈øt in his ≈øeed.

Beauty, if it be not well di≈øciplin'd, proues not a frend, but a traytour; three of Dauids children are vndone by it at once; What els was guilty of Amnons ince≈øtuous loue, Thamars raui≈øhment, Ab≈øaloms pride? It is a ble≈ø≈øing to bee faire, yet ≈øuch a ble≈ø≈øing, as if the ≈øoule an≈øwer not to the face, may lead to a cur≈øe; How commonly haue we ≈øeene the foule≈øt ≈øoule dwell faire≈øt? It was no fault of Thamars, that ≈øhe was beautifull; the candle offends not in burning, the fooli≈øh flye offends in ≈øcorching it ≈øelfe in the flame; yet it is no ≈ømall mi≈øery to become a tentation
vnto another; and to be made but the occa≈øion of others ruine. Amnon is loue-≈øicke of his ≈øi≈øter Tamar, and langui≈øhes of that vnnaturall heat. Whither will not wanton lu≈øt, carry the inordinate mindes of pampered and vngouerned youth; None but his halfe-≈øi≈øter, will plea≈øe the eyes of the young Prince of I≈ørael: Ordinary plea≈øures will not content tho≈øe, whom the conceit of greatne≈ø≈øe, youth, and ea≈øe, haue let loo≈øe to their appetite.

Perhaps, yet this vnkindely flame might, in time, haue gone out alone, had not there beene a Ionadab, to blow the≈øe coles with ill coun≈øell. It were ≈øtrange, if
great Princes ≈øhould want ≈øome para≈øiticall followers, that are ready to feede their ill humours. Why art thou, the Kings ≈øon ≈øo leane from day to day? As if it were vnworthy the heyre of a King, to ≈øuffer either law, or con≈øcience, to ≈øtand in the way of his de≈øires: Whereas wi≈øe Princes know well, that their places giue them no priuiledge of ≈øinning: but call them in rather to ≈øo much more ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe, as their example may be more preiudiciall.

Ionadab was the cozen german of Amnon; Ill adui≈øe is ≈øo much more dangerous, as the intere≈øt of the giuer is more; Had he been a true frend, he had
bent all the forces of his di≈ø≈øwa≈øion, again≈øt the wicked motions of that ≈øinfull lu≈øt; and had ≈øhewed the Prince of I≈ørael how much tho≈øe lewd de≈øires prouoked God, and blemi≈øhed him≈øelfe; and had lent his hand to ≈øtrangle them in their fir≈øt conception. There cannot bee a more worthy improuement of frend≈øhip, then in a feruent oppo≈øition to the ≈øinnes of them; whom wee profe≈ø≈øe to loue: No enemy can be ≈øo mortall to great Princes, as tho≈øe officious clients, who≈øe flattery ≈øoothes them vp in wickedne≈ø≈øe; The≈øe are traytors to the Soule, and by a plea≈øing violence kill the be≈øt part eternally.

How redy at hand is an euill ≈øugge≈øtion? Good coun≈øell is like vnto well water, that mu≈øt be drawne vp with a Pumpe, or bucket; Ill coun≈øell is like to Conduit-water, which if the cocke be but turned, runs out alone; Ionadab hath ≈øoone proiected how Amnon ≈øhall accompli≈øh his lawle≈ø≈øe purpo≈øe. The way mu≈øt bee to fayne him≈øelfe ≈øicke in body, who≈øe minde was ≈øicke of lu≈øt; and vnder this pretence to procure the pre≈øence of her, who had wounded, and only might cure him.

The daily-increa≈øing languor, and leanene≈ø≈øe, and palene≈ø≈øe of loue-≈øicke Amnon might well giue colour to a kercheife,
and a pallet. Now it is ≈øoone told Dauid that his elde≈øt Sonne is ca≈øt vpon his ≈øickebed; there needs no ≈øuit for his vi≈øitation; The carefull father ha≈øtens to his bed-≈øide, not without doubts and feares‚ñ™ He that was lately ≈øo afflicted with the ≈øickne≈ø≈ø of a childe that ≈øcarce liued to ≈øee the light, how ≈øen≈øible mu≈øt we needs thinke he would be, of the indi≈øpo≈øition of his fir≈øt borne Sonne, in the prime of his age and hopes; It is not giuen to any Prophet to fore≈øee all things; Happy had it beene for Dauid, if Amnon had beene truly ≈øicke, and ≈øick vnto death; yet who could haue per≈øwaded this pa≈ø≈øionate father to haue
beene content with this ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of lo≈ø≈øes, this early lo≈ø≈øe of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor: How glad is hee to heare, that his daughter Tamars skill might be likely to fit the dyet of ≈øo deare a patient. Conceit is wont to rule much both in ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and the cure. Tamar is ≈øent by her father to the hou≈øe of Amnon; Her hand only mu≈øt dre≈ø≈øe that di≈øh, which may plea≈øe the nice Palate of her ≈øicke brother. Euen the children of Kings, in tho≈øe homelyer times, did not ≈øcorne to put their fingers, to ≈øome workes of hu≈øwifrie: (She tooke floure and did knead it, and did make cakes in his ≈øight, and did bake the cakes, and tooke a panne, and poured
them out before him.) Had ≈øhe not beene ≈øometimes v≈øed to ≈øuch dome≈øtique imployments, ≈øhee had bene now to ≈øeeke; neither had this bene required of her, but vpon the knowledge of her skill: She doth not plead, the impayring of her beauty by the ≈øcorching of the fire; nor thinkes her hand too dainty for ≈øuch meane ≈øeruices; but fettles to the worke, as one that had rather regard the nece≈ø≈øities of her brother, then her owne ≈øtate: Only pride and idlene≈ø≈øe, haue bani≈øht hone≈øt and thrifty diligence, out of the hou≈øes of the great.

This was not yet the di≈øh that Amnon longed for. It was the
Cooke, and not the cates which that wanton eye affected. Vnlawfull acts ≈øeeke for ≈øecrecy; The company is di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, Tamar only ≈øtayes; Good meaning ≈øu≈øpects nothing; Whiles ≈øhee pre≈øents the meat ≈øhe had prepared, to her ≈øicke brother, her ≈øelfe is made a pray to his outragious lu≈øt. The mode≈øt virgin intreats, and per≈øwades in vain; ≈øhe layes before him the ≈øinne, the ≈øhame, the danger of the fact; and ≈øince none of the≈øe can preuaile, faine would win time by the ≈øugge≈øting of vnpo≈ø≈øible hopes; Nothing but violence can ≈øtay a re≈øolued ≈øinner; What he cannot by intreaty, he will haue by force. If the
Diuell were not more ≈øtrong in men, then nature, they would neuer ≈øeeke plea≈øure in violence. Amnon hath no ≈øooner fulfilled his bea≈øtly de≈øires, then he hates Tamar more then he loued her. Inordinate lu≈øt neuer ends but in di≈øcontentment; Lo≈ø≈øe of ≈øpirits, and remor≈øe of ≈øoule make the remembrance of that act tedious, who≈øe expectation promi≈øed delight. If we could ≈øee the back of ≈øinfull plea≈øures, ere wee behold their face, our harts could not but bee for≈øtalled with a iu≈øt dete≈øtation. Bruti≈øh Amnon, it was thy ≈øelfe whom thou ≈øhould≈øt haue hated for this villany; not thine innocent ≈øi≈øter; Both of you
lay together; only one committed ince≈øt: What was ≈øhe but a patient, in that impotent fury of lu≈øt? How vniu≈øtly doe carnall men mi≈ø-place their affections? No man can ≈øay whether that loue, or this hatred were more vnrea≈øonable: Fraud drew Thamar into the hou≈øe of Amnon, force intertained her within; and droue her out. Faine would ≈øhe haue hid her ≈øhame where it was wrought, and may not bee allowed it; That roofe vnder which, ≈øhee came with honor, and in obedience and loue, may not be lent her for the time as a ≈øhelter of her ignominy. Neuer any ≈øauage could be more barbarous: Shechem had raui≈øhed
Dinah, his offence did not make her odious; his affection ≈øo continued, that he is willing rather to draw blood of him≈øelfe and his people, then forgoe her whom he had abu≈øed; Amnon in one houre is in the exce≈ø≈øe of loue and hate; and is ≈øicke of her, for whom he was ≈øicke; She that lately kept the keyes of his hart, is now lockt out of his doores. Vnruly pa≈ø≈øions runne euer into extremities, and are then be≈øt apayd, when they are furthe≈øt off from rea≈øon and moderation.

What could Amnon thinke, would be the euent of ≈øo foule a fact, which as he had not the grace to preuent, ≈øo he hath not
the care to conceale? If he lookt not ≈øo hie as heauen, what could he imagine would follow herevpon, but the di≈øplea≈øure of a father, the danger of law, the indignation of a brother, the ≈øhame and out-cryes of the world; All which hee might haue hoped to auoyd by ≈øecre≈øie, and plau≈øible cour≈øes of ≈øatisfaction. It is the iu≈øt iudgement of God vpon pre≈øumptuous offenders, that they lo≈øe their wit, together with their hone≈øty; and are either ≈øo blinded, that they cannot fore-≈øee the i≈ø≈øue of their actions, or ≈øo be≈øotted that they doe not regard it.

Poore Thamar can but bewaile
that which ≈øhe could not keepe, her virginty, not lo≈øt, but torne from her by a cruell violence: She rends her princely robe, and layes a≈øhes on her head, and laments the ≈øhame of anothers ≈øinne; and liues more de≈øolate then a widdow, in the hou≈øe of her brother Ab≈øalom.

In the meane time, what a coro≈øiue mu≈øt this newes needs be to the heart of good Dauid, who≈øe fatherly command had out of loue, ca≈øt his daughter into the iawes of this Lyon? What an in≈øolent affront mu≈øt hee needs con≈øtrue this, to bee offred by a Sonne to a father; that the father ≈øhould be made the Pandar of his owne daughter
to his ≈øonne? He that lay vpon the ground weeping for, but the ≈øicknes of an infant, how vexed doe wee thinke he was with the villany of his heyre, with the raui≈øhment of his daughter, both of them wor≈øe then many deaths? What reuenge can he thinke of, for ≈øo haynous a crime le≈ø≈øe then death; and what le≈ø≈øe then death is it to him, to thinke of a reuenge? Rape was by the law of God, capitall, how much more, when it is ≈øeconded with ince≈øt? Anger was not puni≈øhment enough for ≈øo hye an offence; Yet this is all that I heare of, from ≈øo indulgent a father, ≈øauing that he makes vp the re≈øt
with ≈øorrow; puni≈øhing his ≈øons outrage in him≈øelfe; The better-naturd, and more gracious a man is, the more ≈øubiect he is to the danger of an ouer remi≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe, and the exce≈ø≈øe of fauour and mercy: The milde iniu≈øtice is no le≈ø≈øe perilous to the common-wealth, then the cruell.

If Dauid (perhaps out of the con≈øcience of his owne late offence) will not puni≈øh this fact, his ≈øonne Ab≈øalom ≈øhall: not out of any care of iu≈øtice, but in a de≈øire of reuenge. Two whole yeares, hath this ≈ølie Courtier ≈ømothered his indignation, and fayned kindene≈ø≈øe; els his inuitation of Amnon in ≈øpeciall, had
beene ≈øu≈øpected. Euen gallant Ab≈øalom was a great ≈øheep-ma≈øter; The brauery and magnificence of a Courtier, mu≈øt bee built vpon the grounds of frugality; Dauid him≈øelfe is bidden to this bloody ≈øheep-≈øhearing; It was no otherwi≈øe meant, but that the fathers eyes, ≈øhould be the witne≈ø≈øes, of the tragicall execution of one ≈øon by another; Only Dauids loue kept him from that horrible ≈øpectacle: He is carefull not to be chargeable to that ≈øon, who cares not to ouer-charge his fathers ≈øtomach with a fea≈øt of blood.

Amnon hath ≈øo quite forgot his ≈øinne, that hee dares goe to fea≈øt in that hou≈øe where Tamar
was mourning; and ≈øu≈øpects not the kindenes of him, whom he had de≈øerued, of a brother to make an enemy; Nothing is more vn≈øafe to be tru≈øted, then the faire looks of a fe≈øtered hart: Where true charity or iu≈øt ≈øati≈øfaction, haue not wrought a ≈øound reconciliation, malice doth but lurk for the opportunity of an aduantage.

It was not for nothing, that Ab≈øalom deferred his reuenge; which is now ≈øo much the more exqui≈øite, as it is longer protracted: What could be more feareful, then when Amnons hart was merry with wine, to be ≈øuddenly ≈øtriken with death? As if this execution had bene no le≈ø≈øe
intended to the Soule, then to the body; How wickedly ≈øoeuer this was ‚Ä¢ one by Ab≈øalom, yet how iu≈øt was it with God, that he, whom in two yeares impunity would finde no lea≈øure o ‚Ä¢ repentance, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ould now receiue a puni≈øhment without po≈ø≈øibility of repentance.

O God, thou art righteous to reckon for tho≈øe ≈øinnes, which humane partiality or negligence hath omitted, and whiles th ‚Ä¢ u puni≈øhe≈øt ≈øinne with ≈øin, to puni≈øh ≈øinne with death; If either Dauid had called Amnon to account for this villany, or Amnon had called him≈øelfe, the reuenge had not beene ≈øo de≈øperate; Happy is the man that by
an vnfayned repentance acquits his ≈øoule from his known euils, and improues the dayes of his peace to the preuention of future vengeance; ‚Ä¢ hi ‚Ä¢ h if it be not d ‚Ä¢ ne, the hand of God ≈øhall as ≈øurely oue ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ake vs in iudgement, as the hand of Satan hath ouertaken vs in mi≈øcariage vnto ≈øin.

div.head: Ab≈øaloms returne and con≈øpiracy.
div.p:
ONE act of iniu≈øtice drawes on another; The iniu≈øtice of Dauid, in not puni≈øhing the rape of Amnon, procures the iniu≈øtice of Ab≈øalom, in puni≈øhing Amnon with murder: That which the father ≈øhould haue iu≈øtly reuenged, and did not; the ≈øon reuenges vniu≈øtly; The rape of a ≈øi≈øter was no le≈ø≈øe worthy of death; then the murder
of a brother; Yea, this latter ≈øin was therefore the le≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe that brother was worthy of death, though by another hand; whereas that ≈øi≈øter was guilty of nothing but mode≈øt beauty: yet he that knew this rape pa≈ø≈øed ouer (whole two yeeres) with impunity, dares not tru≈øt the mercy of a father, in the pardon of his murder; but for threeyeers, hides his head in the Court of his Grand-father, the King of Ge≈øhur. Doubtle≈ø≈øe, that heatheni≈øh Prince gaue him a kinde welcome, for ≈øo meritorious a reuenge of the di≈øhonour done to his owne loynes. No man can tell, how Ab≈øalom ≈øhould haue ≈øped from the hands of his
otherwi≈øe ouer-indulgent Father, if he had beene apprehended in the heat of the fact. Euen the large≈øt loue may bee ouer≈øtrayned, and may giue a fall in the breaking; The≈øe fearefull effects of lenity, might perhaps haue whetted the ≈øeuerity of Dauid, to ≈øhut vp the≈øe outrages in bloud; Now this di≈øplea≈øure was weakned with age: Time and thoughts haue dige≈øted this hard mor≈øell; Dauids heart told him, that his hands had a ≈øhare in this offence; that Ab≈øalom did but giue that ≈øtroke, which him≈øelfe had wrongfully forborne; that the vnrecouerable lo≈ø≈øe of one ≈øon, would bee but wofully releiued with the lo≈ø≈øe of another;
Hee therefore, that in the newes of the decea≈øed infant could change his clothes, and wa≈øh him≈øelfe, and cheere vp his ≈øpirits, with the re≈øolution of, I ≈øhall goe to him, he ≈øhall not returne to mee, comforts him≈øelfe concerning Amnon; and begins to long for Ab≈øolom.

Tho≈øe three yeeres bani≈øhment ≈øeemed not ≈øo much a puni≈øhment to the ≈øon, as to the father; Now Dauid begins to forgiue him≈øelfe; yet out of his wi≈ødome, ≈øo inclines to fauour, that he conceales it; and yet ≈øo conceales it, that it may bee de≈øcryed by a cunning eye; If hee had ca≈øt out no glances of affection, there had beene no hopes
for his Ab≈øalom, if hee had made profe≈ø≈øion of loue after ≈øo foule an act, there had beene no ≈øafety for others; now hee lets fall ≈øo much ≈øecret grace, as may both hold vp Abfalom in the life of his hopes, and not hearten the pre≈øumption of others.

Good eyes ≈øee light thorow the ≈ømalle≈øt chinke; The wit of Ioab hath ≈øoone di≈øcerned Dauids re≈øerued affection; and knowes how to ≈øerue him in that which hee would, and would not accompli≈øh: and now deui≈øes how to bring into the light, that birth of de≈øire, wherof he knew Dauid was both big, and a≈øhamed. A woman of Tekoah (that ≈øex hath beene euer held
more apt for wiles) is ≈øuborned to per≈øonate a mourner, and to ≈øay that, by way of parable, which in plaine termes would haue ≈øounded too har≈øhly; and now whiles ≈øhe lamentably laies forth the lo≈ø≈øe & danger of her ≈øons, ≈øhe ≈øhewes Dauid his owne; and whiles ≈øhe moues compa≈ø≈øion to her pretended i≈ø≈øue, ≈øhee wins Dauid to a pitty of him≈øelfe, and a fauourable ≈øentence for Ab≈øalom. We loue our ≈øelues better then others, but wee ≈øee others better then our ≈øelues; who ≈øo would perfectly know his owne ca≈øe, let him view it in anothers per≈øon.

Parables ≈øped well with Dauid; One drew him to repent of
his owne ≈øin; another, to remit Ab≈øaloms puni≈øhment; And now, as glad to heare this plea, and willing to bee per≈øwaded vnto that, which if he dur≈øt, he would haue ≈øought for, he gratifies Ioab with the grant of that ≈øuit, which Ioab more gratified him in ≈øuing for; Goe bring againe the young man Ab≈øalom.

How glad is Ioab, that hee hath light vpon one act, for which the Sunne, both ≈øetting and ri≈øing, ≈øhould ≈øhine vpon him? and now he ≈øpeeds to Ge≈øhur, to fetch back Ab≈øalom to Ieru≈øalem: he may bring the long-bani≈øhed Prince to the City; but to the Court hee may not bring him. (Let him turne to his owne
hou≈øe, and let him not ≈øee my face.)

The good King hath ≈øo ≈ømarted with mercy; that now hee is re≈øolued vpon au≈øterity; and will relent but by degrees; It is enough for Ab≈øalom that hee liues, and may now breathe his natiue ayre; Dauids face is no obiect for the eyes of a murtherer: What a Dearling this ≈øon was to his father, appeares in that, after an vnnaturall and barbarous rebellion, pa≈ø≈øionate Dauid wi≈øhes to haue changed liues with him; yet now, whiles his bowels yearned, his brow frowned; The face may not be ≈øeen, where the heart is ≈øet. The be≈øt of Gods Saints may be blinded with affection; but when they
≈øhall once ≈øee their errors, they are carefull to correct them. Wherfore ≈øerues the power of Grace, but to ≈øubdue the in≈øolencies of nature? It is the wi≈ødome of parents, as to hide their hearts from their be≈øt children, ≈øo to hide their countenances from the vngracious: Fle≈øhly re≈øpects may not abate their rigor to the ill de≈øeruing. For the childe to ≈øee all his fathers loue, it is enough to make him wanton, and of wanton, wicked: For a wicked childe, to ≈øee any of his fathers loue, it emboldens him in euill, and drawes on others.

Ab≈øaloms hou≈øe is made his pri≈øon; Iu≈øtly is he confined to
the place which hee had ≈øtained with blood; Two yeeres doth hee liue in Ieru≈øalem, without the happine≈ø≈øe of his fathers ≈øight; It was enough for Dauid and him, to ≈øee the ≈ømoke of ech others chimnies. In the meane time, how impatient is Ab≈øalom of this ab≈øence? Hee ≈øends for Ioab, the Solicitor of his returne; So hard an hand, doth wi≈øe and holy Dauid carry ouer his reduced ≈øonne, that his frendly Interce≈ø≈øor, Ioab, dares not vi≈øit him. Hee, that afterwards kindled that ≈øeditious fire ouer all I≈ørael, ≈øets fire now on the field of Ioab; whom loue cannot draw to him, feare and anger ≈øhall; Continued di≈øplea≈øure hath made
Ab≈øalom de≈øperate; Fiue yeeres are pa≈ø≈øed, ≈øince hee ≈øaw the face of his father; and now he is no le≈ø≈øe weary of his life, then of this delay; (Wherefore am I comne downe from Ge≈øhur? It had beene better for mee, to haue beene there ≈øtill: Now therefore let mee ≈øee the Kings face, and if there bee any iniquity in me, let him kill me.) Either bani≈øhment, or death, ≈øeemed as tolerable to him, as the debarring of his fathers ≈øight. What a torment ≈øhall it bee to the wicked, to be ≈øhut out for euer, from the pre≈øence of a God, without all po≈ø≈øible hopes of recouery? This was but a father of the fle≈øh, by whom, if Ab≈øalom liued at fir≈øt, yet in him he liued not, yea,
not without him onely, but again≈øt him that ≈øon found hee could liue; God is the Father of Spirits, in whom wee ≈øo liue, that without him can be no life, no being; to bee euer excluded from him, in whom wee liue and are, what can it be but an eternall dying, an eternall peri≈øhing? If in thy pre≈øence, √¥ God, be the fulnes of ioy, in thine ab≈øence, mu≈øt needs be the fulnes of horror and torment; Hide not thy face from vs, √¥ Lord, but ≈øhew vs the light of thy countenance, that we may liue, and prai≈øe thee.

Euen the fire of Ioabs field, warmed the heart of Dauid, whiles it gaue him proofe of the
heat of Ab≈øaloms filiall affection. As a man therefore inwardly weary of ≈øo long di≈øplea≈øure, at la≈øt hee receiues Ab≈øalom to his ≈øight, to his fauour; and ≈øeales his pardon with a ki≈ø≈øe: Naturall parents, know not how to retaine an euerla≈øting anger towards the fruit of their loynes; how much le≈ø≈øe ≈øhall the God of mercies, be vnreconcileably di≈øplea≈øed with his owne; and ≈øuffer his wrath to burne like fire that cannot be quenched? Hee will not alwayes chide, neither will he keepe his anger for euer; His wrath endureth but a moment, in his fauour is life; weeping may endure for a night, but ioy commeth in the morning.

Ab≈øalom is now as great, as faire; beauty and greatne≈ø≈øe make him proud; pride works his ruine; Great ≈øpirits will not re≈øt content with a moderate pro≈øperity: Ere two yeeres bee run out, Ab≈øalom runs out into a de≈øperate plot of rebellion; None but his owne father was aboue him in I≈ørael; None was ≈øo likely, in humane expectation, to ≈øucceed his father; If his ambition could but haue contained it ≈øelfe for a few yeeres, (as Dauid was now neere his period) dutifull carrige might haue procured, that by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, which now he ≈øought by force. An a≈øpiring minde is euer impatient, and holds Time it ≈øelfe
an enemy, if it thru≈øt it ≈øelfe importunately betwixt the hopes and fruition: Ambition is neuer but in trauell, and can finde no intermi≈ø≈øion of painefull throwes, till ≈øhee haue brought forth her abortiue de≈øires: How happy were we, if our affectation could be ≈øo eager of ≈øpiritual and heauenly promotions; Oh that my ≈øoule could finde it ≈øelfe ≈øo re≈øtle≈ø≈øe, till it feele the weight of that crowne of glory.

Outward pompe, and vnwonted ≈øhews of magnificence, are wont much to affect the light mindes of the vulgar. Ab≈øalom therefore to the incomparable comeline≈ø≈øe of his per≈øon, addes the vnu≈øuall ≈øtate of a
more-then-princely equipage His Charets rattle, and his hor ≈øes trample proudly in the ≈øtreets; Fifty foot-men runne before their glittering ma≈øter; Ieru≈øalem rings of their glorious Prince; and is ready to adore the≈øe continuall triumphs of peace. Exce≈ø≈øe and nouelty, of expen≈øiue brauery and o≈øtentation in publique per≈øons, giues iu≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect either vanity, or a plot; True-harted Dauid can mi≈ødoubt nothing in him, to whom hee had both giuen life, and forgiuen death‚ñ™ Loue con≈øtrued all this, as meant to the honor of a fathers Court, to the expre≈ø≈øion of ioy and thankfulnes for his reconcilement:
