The eyes and tongues of men are thus taken vp; now hath Ab≈øalom laid ≈ønares for their hearts al≈øo; Hee ri≈øes early, and ≈øtands be≈øide the way of the gate; Ambition is no niggard of her paynes; ≈øeldome euer is good meaning ≈øo indu≈øtrious; The more hee ≈øhined in beauty and royall attendance, ≈øo much more glory it was to neglect him≈øelfe, and to prefer the care of iu≈øtice to his owne ea≈øe; Neither is Ab≈øalom more painefull then plau≈øible, his eare is open to all plaintiues, all petitioners: there is no cau≈øe Which he flatters not, See thy matters are good and right; his hand flatters euery commer with a ≈øalutation, his
lips with a ki≈ø≈øe. All men, all matters are ≈øoothed, ≈øauing the ≈øtate and gouernment; the cen≈øure of that is no le≈ø≈øe deep, then the applau≈øe of all others, (There is none deputed of the King to heare thee.) What in≈øinuations could be more powerfull; No mu≈øick can be ≈øo ≈øweet to the eares of the vn≈øtable multitude, as to heare well of them≈øelues, ill of their gouernours; Ab≈øalom needs not to wi≈øh him≈øelfe vpon the Bench; Euery man ≈øayes, Oh what a curteous Prince is Ab≈øalom? What a iu≈øt and carefull ruler would Ab≈øalom be? How happy were wee, if wee might bee iudg'd by Ab≈øalom? Tho≈øe qualities which are wont ≈øingle

„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
to grace others, haue con≈øpired to meet in Ab≈øalom; goodlines of per≈øon, magnificence of ≈øtate, gracious affability, vnwearied diligence, humility in greatnes, feeling pitty, loue of iu≈øtice, care of the Commonwealth; The world hath not ≈øo complete a Prince as Ab≈øalom; Thus the harts of the people are not won, but ≈øtolne by a clo≈øe traytor from their lawfully-anointed Soueraigne. Ouer-faire ≈øhowes are a iu≈øt argument of vn≈øoundnes; no naturall face hath ≈øo cleare a white and red, as the painted: Nothing wants now but a cloke of religion, to perfect the trechery of that vngracious Sonne, who carryed
peace in his name, warre in his hart: and how ea≈øily is that put on? Ab≈øalom hath an holy vow to be paid in Hebron; The deuout man had made it long ≈øince, whiles hee was exiled in Syria, and now hee ha≈øts to performe it, (If the Lord ≈øhall bring me backe againe to Ieru≈øalem, then I will ≈øerue the Lord;) wicked hypocrites, care not to play with God that they may mock men. The more deformed any act is, the fayrer vi≈øor it ≈øtill ≈øeeketh.

How glad is the good old King, that he is ble≈ø≈øed with ≈øo godly a Son; whom he di≈ømi≈ø≈øeth laden with his cau≈øele≈ø≈øe ble≈ø≈øings: What tru≈øt is there in fle≈øh and blood when Dauid is
not ≈øafe from his owne loynes? The con≈øpiracy is now fully forged, there lacked nothing but this guilt of piety to win fauor and value in all eyes; and now it is a wonder, that but two hundred hone≈øt Citizens goe vp with Ab≈øalom from Ieru≈øalem: The true-harted lie mo≈øt open to credulity: How ea≈øie it is to beguile harmele≈ø≈øe intentions? The name of Dauids Son carryes them again≈øt the father of Ab≈øalom, and now the≈øe ≈øimple I≈øraelites, are vnwittingly made loyall rebells. Their harts are free from a plot, and they meane nothing, but fidelity in the attendance of a traytor. How many thou≈øands are thus
ignorantly mi≈øled into the train of error; Their ≈øimplicity is as worthy of pitty, as their mi≈øguidance of indignation. Tho≈øe that will ≈øuffer them≈øelues to be carryed with ≈øemblances of truth and faithfulne≈ø≈øe, mu≈øt needs be as farre from ≈øafety, as innocence.

THE SECOND BOOKE:

div.head: TO THE HONORABLE GENERALL Sir EDWARD CECILL Knight, all honor and happines,
div.p:
THE ≈øtore of a good Scribe is (according to our Sauiour) both old and new; I would (if I dur≈øt) be ambitions of this onely honor; hauing therefore drawne forth the≈øe not-friuolous thoughts, out of the old Te≈øtament, I fetch the≈øe following from the new; God is the ≈øame in both; as the body differs not with the age of the ≈øute, with the change of robes: The old and new wine of holy Truth, came both out of one vineyard; yet heere may wee ≈øafely ≈øay to the word of his father, as was ≈øaid to the Bride-groome of Cana,
Thou ha≈øt kept the be≈øt wine till the la≈øt; The authority of both is equally ≈øacred, the v≈øe admits no le≈ø≈øe difference, then is betwixt a Sauiour fore-≈øhadowed, and comne. The intermis≈øion of tho≈øe military imployments, which haue won you iu≈øt honor, both in forraine nations, and at home, is in this only gainefull, that it yeilds you lea≈øure to the≈øe happy thoughts, which ≈øhall more fully acquaint you with him that is at once the God of ho≈øts, and the Prince of Peace: To the furtherance whereof the≈øe my poore labors, ≈øhall doe no thankele≈ø≈øe offices. In lieu of your noble fauors to me both at home, and where you haue merited command, nothing can be returned but humble acknowledgements, and harty prayers for the increa≈øe of your Honor, and all happines to your ≈øelfe, and your thrice-worthy and vertuous Lady, by him that is deepely obliged, and truely deuoted to you both.

div.head: CHRIST among the Doctors.
div.p:
EVEN the ≈øpring ≈øhowes vs what we may hope for of the tree in Summer; In his nonage therfore, would our Sauiour giue vs a ta≈øte of his future proofe, lea≈øt if his perfection ≈øhould haue ≈øhewed it ≈øelfe without warning to the world, it ≈øhould haue beene intertained with more wonder, then beleefe; now this act of
his Childe-hood ≈øhall prepare the faith of men by fore-expectation; notwith≈øtanding all this early demon≈øtration of his diuine graces, the incredulous Iewes could afterwards ≈øay, whence hath this man this wi≈ødome and great workes? What would they haue ≈øaid, if he had ≈øuddenly leapt forth into the cleare light of the world? The Sunne would dazle all eyes, if hee ≈øhould breake forth at his fir≈øt ri≈øing into his full ≈øtrength; now he hath both the day-≈øtar to goe before him, and to bid men looke for that glorious body, and the liuely colours of the day, to publi≈øh his approch, the eye is comforted, not hurt
by his appearance.

The Parents of Chri≈øt went vp yearely to Ieru≈øalem at the fea≈øt of the Pa≈ø≈øouer; the law was onely for the males, I doe not finde the ble≈ø≈øed virgin bound to this voyage, the weaker ≈øexe receiued indulgence from God: yet ≈øhee knowing the ≈øpirituall profit of that iourney, takes paines voluntarily to mea≈øure that long way euery yeare; Piety regards not any di≈øtinction of ≈øexes or degrees, nether yet doth Gods acceptation; rather doth it plea≈øe the mercy of the highe≈øt, more to reward that ≈øeruice, which, though he like in all, yet out of fauour he will not impo≈øe vpon
all! It could not be but that ≈øhe whom the holy gho≈øt ouer≈øhadowed, ≈øhould bee zealous of Gods ≈øeruice: tho≈øe that will go no further then they are dragged in their religious exerci≈øes, are no whit of kinne to her whom all generations ≈øhall call ble≈ø≈øed.

The childe Ie≈øus in the minority of his age, went vp with his Parents to the holy ≈øolemnity, not this yeare onely, but in all likelyhood others al≈øo; hee in the power of who≈øe God-head, and by the motion of who≈øe Spirit, all others a≈øcended thither, would not him≈øelfe ≈øtay at home. In al his examples he meant our In≈øtruction: this
pious act of his nonage intended to lead our fir≈øt yeares into timely deuotion. The fir≈øt liquor ≈øea≈øons the ve≈ø≈øell for a long time after: It is euery way good for a man, to beare Gods yoke euen from his Infancy: it is the policie of the deuill to di≈øcourage early holynes: hee that goes out betimes in the morning, is more like to di≈øpatch his iourney, then he that lingers till the day bee ≈øpent. This ble≈ø≈øed Family, came not to looke at the fea≈øt & be gone; but they duely ≈øtayd out all the appointed dayes of vnleauened bread: they and the re≈øt of I≈ørael could not want hou≈øhold bu≈øine≈ø≈øes at home; tho≈øe ≈øecular
affaires could not either keepe them from repayring to Ieru≈øalem, or ≈øend them away immaturely; Worldly cares mu≈øt giue place to the ≈øacred: Except wee will depart vnble≈ø≈øed, we mu≈øt attend Gods ≈øeruices till wee may receiue his di≈ømi≈ø≈øion:

It was the fa≈øhion of tho≈øe times and places, that they went vp, and ≈øo returned by troupes, to tho≈øe ≈øet meetings of their holy fe≈øtiuals. The whole pari≈øh of Nazareth went and came together, Good-fellow≈øhip doth no way ≈øo well, as in the pa≈ø≈øage to Heauen: much comfort is added by ≈øociety to that iourney, which is of it ≈øelfe plea≈øant; It is an happy word,
Come let vs go vp to the hou≈øe of the Lord: Mutual incouragement is none of the lea≈øt benefits of our holy a≈ø≈øemblies: Many ≈øticks layd together, make a good fire, which if they lye ≈øingle, lo≈øe both their light and heat.

The fea≈øt ended, what ≈øhould they do, but return to Nazareth? Gods ≈øeruices may not bee ≈øo attended, as that wee ≈øhould neglect our particular callings: Him≈øelfe cals vs from his owne hou≈øe to ours: and takes plea≈øure to ≈øee a painfull Client: They are fouly mi≈øtaken, that thinke God cares for no other trade, but deuotion: Piety & diligence mu≈øt keep meet changes
with each other; neither doth God le≈ø≈øe acept of our returne to Nazareth, then our going vp to Ieru≈øalem.

I cannot thinke that the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, or good Io≈øeph, could be ≈øo negligent of their diuine charge, as not to call the childe Ie≈øus, to their ≈øetting forth from Ieru≈øalem: But their backe was no ≈øooner turned vpon the Temple, then his face was towards it; hee had bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in that place, when theirs was ended: there hee was both wor≈øhipped and repre≈øented: hee, in whom the God-head dwelt bodily, could do nothing without God: his true father led him away from his ≈øuppo≈øed:
Sometimes the affaires of our ordinary vocation, may not grudge to yeeld vnto ≈øpirituall occa≈øions: The Parents of Chri≈øt knew him well, to be of a di≈øpo≈øition, not ≈øtrange, nor ≈øullen and ≈øtoycall, but ≈øweet and ≈øociable: and therfore they ≈øuppo≈øed, he had ≈øpent the time and the way, in the company of their frends and neighbours: They doe not ≈øu≈øpect him wandred into the ≈øolitary fields, but when euening came, they go to ≈øeeke him among their kinsfolk and acquaintance: If hee had not wonted to conuer≈øe formerly with them, hee had not now beene ≈øought among≈øt them: Neither as God, nor man
doth he take plea≈øure in a ≈øterne froward au≈øterity, and wilde retiredne≈ø≈øe: but in a milde affablene≈ø≈øe, and amiable conuer≈øa≈øation.

But, √¥ ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, who can expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øorrowes of thy perplexed ≈øoule; when all that euening-≈øearch could affoord thee no newes of thy Son Ie≈øus‚ñ™ Was not this one of tho≈øe ≈øwords of Simeon, which ≈øhould pierce thorow thy tender bre≈øt? How did≈øt thou chide thy credulous neglect, in not ob≈øeruing ≈øo precious a charge, and blame thine eyes, for once looking be≈øide this obiect of thy loue? How did≈øt thou, with thy carefull husband, ≈øpend that re≈øtle≈ø≈øe
night, in mutuall expo≈øtulations, and bemonings of your lo≈ø≈øe? How many ≈øu≈øpicious imaginations did that while racke thy greeued ≈øpirit? Perhaps thou might≈øt doubt, le≈øt they which layd for him, by Herods command, at his birth, had now by the ≈øecret in≈øtigation of Archelaus, ≈øurprized him in his child-hood: or it may be, thou thought≈øt thy diuine Son had now withdrawne him≈øelfe from the earth, and returned to his heauenly glory, without warning: or peraduenture, thou ≈øtudyed≈øt with thy ≈øelfe, whether any careles on thy behalfe, had not giuen occa≈øion to this ab≈øence.

Oh deare Sauiour, who can mi≈ø≈øe and not mourne for thee? Neuer any ≈øoule conceiued thee by faith, that was le≈ø≈øe afflicted with the ≈øen≈øe of thy di≈ø≈øertion, then comforted with the ioy of thy pre≈øence: Iu≈øt is that ≈øorrow, and tho≈øe teares ≈øea≈øonable, that are be≈øtowed vpon thy lo≈ø≈øe; What comfort are we capable of, whiles we want thee? What reli≈øh is there in the≈øe earthly delights without thee? What is there to mitigate our pa≈ø≈øionate di≈øcomforts, if not from thee? Let thy ≈øelfe loo≈øe, √¥ my ≈øoule, to the fulne≈ø≈øe of ≈øorrow, when thou finde≈øt thy ≈øelfe bereeued of him, in who≈øe pre≈øence is the fulne≈ø≈øe
of ioy, and deny to receiue comfort from any thing, ≈øaue from his returne.

In vaine is Chri≈øt ≈øought among his kinred, according to the fle≈øh: So far are they ≈øtill from giuing vs their ayd, to find the true Me≈øsias, that they lead vs from him: Backe againe therefore are Io≈øeph and Mary gone, to ≈øeeke him at Hieru≈øalem; Shee goes about in the City, by the ≈øtreets, and by the open places, and ≈øeekes him whom her ≈øoule loueth: She ≈øought him, for the time, and found him not. Doe we thinke ≈øhe ≈øpared her ≈øearch, the euening of her returne, ≈øhee ha≈øtes to the Inne, where ≈øhe la≈øt left him; where mi≈ø≈øing him,
≈øhee inquires of euery one ≈øhee met, Haue you not ≈øeene him, whom my ≈øoule loueth? At la≈øt, the third day, ≈øhee findes him in the Temple: One day was ≈øpent in the journey towards Galile; another in the returne to Ieru≈øalem: The third day recouers him: Hee, who would ri≈øe againe the third day, and be found among≈øt the liuing, now al≈øo would the third day bee found of his Parents, after the ≈øorrow of his ab≈øence. But where wert thou, √¥ ble≈ø≈øed Ie≈øu, for the ≈øpace of the≈øe three daies? Where did≈øt thou be≈øtow thy ≈øelfe, or who tended thee, whiles thou wert thus alone at Hieru≈øalem? I know, if Hieru≈øalem
≈øhould haue beene as vnkinde to thee, as Bethelem, thou could≈øt haue commanded the Heauens to harbour thee, and if men did not mini≈øter to thee, thou could≈øt haue commanded the ≈øeruice of Angels, but ≈øince the forme of a ≈øeruant, called thee to a voluntary homeline≈ø≈øe, whether it plea≈øed thee to exerci≈øe thy ≈øelfe thus early, with the difficulties of a ≈øtranger, or to prouide miraculou≈øly for thy ≈øelfe; I inquire not, ≈øince thou reueale≈øt not, only this I know, that hereby thou intende≈øt to teach thy parents, that thou coulde≈øt liue without them, and that not of any indigency, but out of a gracious di≈øpen≈øation,
thou would≈øt ordinarily depend vpon their care.

In the meane time, thy diuine wi≈ødome could not but fore-know all the≈øe corroding thoughts, wherewith the heart of thy deare mother mu≈øt needs bleed, through this ≈øudden dereliction; yet would≈øt thou leaue her for the time to her ≈øorrow: Euen ≈øo, √¥ Sauior, thou thoughte≈øt fit to vi≈øit her, that bore thee with this earely affliction; Neuer any loued thee, whom thou doe≈øt not ≈øometimes exerci≈øe with the greefe of mi≈ø≈øing thee, that both we may be more carefull to hold thee, and more ioyfull in recouering thee. Thou ha≈øt ≈øayd, and can≈øt not lye, I
am with you to the end of the world: but euen whiles thou art really pre≈øent, thou thinke≈øt good to be ab≈øent vnto our apprehen≈øions: yet if thou leaue vs, thou wilt not for≈øake vs; if thou leaue vs for our humiliation, thou wilt not for≈øake vs to our finall di≈øcomfort; thou may≈øt for three dayes hide thy ≈øelfe; but then wee ≈øhall finde thee in the Temple; None euer ≈øought thee with a ≈øincere de≈øire, of whom thou wert not found: Thou wilt not bee either ≈øo little ab≈øent, as not to whet our appetites, nor ≈øo long, as to fainten the heart. After three dayes wee ≈øhall finde thee; and where ≈øhould wee
rather hope to finde thee then in the Temple? There is the habitation for the God of I≈ørael, there is thy re≈øting place for euer; Oh all yee that are greeued with the want of your Sauiour, ≈øee where yee mu≈øt ≈øeeke him: In vaine ≈øhall yee hope to finde him in the ≈øtrects, in the Tauernes, in the Theaters, ≈øeek him in his holy Temple: Seeke him with piety, ≈øeeke him with faith, there ≈øhall yee meet him, there ≈øhall yee recouer him. Whiles children of that age were playing in the ≈øtreets, Chri≈øt was found ≈øitting in the Temple, not to gaze on the outward glory of that hou≈øe, or on the golden Candle≈øticks, or tables, but
to heare and appo≈øe the Doctors; Hee, who as God, gaue them all the wi≈ødome they had, as the Son of man hearkens to the wi≈ødom he had giuen them: He, who ≈øate in their hearts, as the Author of all learning and knowledge, ≈øets in the mid≈øt of their ≈øchoole, as an humble Di≈øciple: That by learning of them, he might teach all the younger ≈øort humility, and due attendance vpon their In≈øtructours, he could at the fir≈øt haue taught the great Rabbins of I≈ørael, the deepe my≈øteries of God; but becau≈øe hee was not yet called by his Father, to the publique function of a Teacher, hee contents to heare with diligence,
and to aske with mode≈øty, & to teach onely by in≈øinuation. Let tho≈øe con≈øider this, which will needes run as ≈øoone as they can go: and when they find ability, thinke they need not ≈øtay for a further vocation of God, or men; Open your eyes, yee rathe ripe Inuaders of Gods Chaire: and ≈øee your Sauior in his younger yeeres, not ≈øitting in the eminent pulpits of the Doctors, but in the lowly floores of the Auditors: See him that could haue taught the Angels, li≈øtning in his minority, to the voyce of men; Who can think much, to learne of his Ancients, when he looks vpon the Son of God, ≈øitting at the feet of the Doctors of
I≈ørael. Fir≈øt he hears, theÃÑ he asks: how much more doth it concern vsto be hearers, ere we offer to be teachers of others; hee gathers that hears, he ≈øpeÃÑds that teacheth; if we ≈øpend ere we gather, we ≈øhall ≈øoon proue bankrupts.

When he hath heard, he askes, and after that, hee an≈øwers: doubtle≈ø≈øe tho≈øe very que≈øtions were in≈øtructions, and meant to teach more then to learne: Neuer had the≈øe great Rabbins heard the voyce of ≈øuch a tutor: in whom they might ≈øee the wi≈ødome of God ≈øo concealing it ≈øelfe, that yet it would bee knowne to be there: No maruell then if they all wondred at his vnder≈øtanding and an≈øwers‚ñ™
Their eyes ≈øaw nothing but humane weakene≈ø≈øe, their eares heard diuine ≈øublimity of matter; betwixt what they ≈øaw, and what they heard, they could not but bee di≈øtracted with a doubting admiration. And why did ye not (√¥ ye Iewi≈øh teachers) remember That to vs a Childe is borne, and vnto vs a Son is giuen, and the gouernment is vpon his ≈øhoulder, and his name ≈øhall bee called Wonderfull, Coun≈øellor, the mighty God, the euerla≈øting Father, the Prince of peace? Why did ye not now bethinke your≈øelues, what the ≈øtarre, the Sages, the Angels, the Shepheards, Zachary, Simeon, Anna, had premoni≈øhed you. Fruitle≈ø≈øe is the wonder that
endeth not in faith; No light is ≈øufficient where the eyes are held through vnbeliefe or pre
‚Ä¢ udice.

The Doctors were not more amazed, to heare ≈øo profound a childe-hood, then the parents of Chri≈øt were to ≈øee him among the Doctors; the Ioy of finding him, did ≈øtriue with the a≈øtoni≈øhment of finding him thus, And now, not Io≈øeph (he knew how little right he had to that diuine Son) but Mary breakes forth into a louing expo≈øtulation (Son why ha≈øt thou dealt ≈øo with vs;) that ≈øhe might not ≈øceme to take vpon her as an imperious mother, it is like ≈øhe re≈øerued this que≈øtion till ≈øhee had him
alone: Wherein ≈øhe meant rather to expre≈ø≈øe griefe then co ‚Ä¢
reption: Onely heerein th ‚Ä¢ ble≈ø≈øed virgin offended, that he incon≈øideration did not ≈øuppo≈øe (as it was) that ≈øome hy ‚Ä¢ re≈øpects, then could be due to fle≈øh and bloud, called away th ‚Ä¢ Son of God from her, that wa ‚Ä¢ the daughter of man: She tha ‚Ä¢ was but the mother of his humanity, ≈øhould not hau ‚Ä¢ thought that the bu≈øines o ‚Ä¢ God mu≈øt for her ≈øake bee neglected: Wee are all partiall to our ≈øelues naturally, & prone to the regard of our owne rights; que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe this gracious ≈øaint would not for all the world, haue willingly preferd her own
attendance, to that of her God: through heedle≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øhee doth ≈øo: her Son and Sauiour is her monitor: out of his diuine loue reforming her naturall: How is ‚Ä¢ t that ye ≈øought me? Knew ye not ‚Ä¢ hat I mu≈øt goe about my Fathers bu≈øine≈ø≈øe? Immediately before the ble≈ø≈øed virgin had ≈øaid, thy father and I ≈øought thee with heauy hearts: Wherein both according to the ≈øuppo≈øition of the world, ≈øhe called Io≈øeph the father of Chri≈øt, and according to the fa≈øhion of a dutifull wife, ≈øhee names her Io≈øeph, before her ≈øelfe. She well knew that Io≈øeph had nothing but a name in this bu≈øines, ≈øhe knew how God had dignified her beyond him; yet,
≈øhe ≈øaies: Thy father and I ≈øough ‚Ä¢ thee; The Sonne of God ≈øtand not vpon contradiction to hi ‚Ä¢ mother, but leading he thoughts from his ≈øuppo≈øed father, to his true; from earth t ‚Ä¢ heauen, he an≈øwers (Knew ye no ‚Ä¢ that I mu≈øt goe about my Father ‚Ä¢ bu≈øine≈ø≈øe?) It was honor enough to her that hee had vouch≈øafed to take fle≈øh of her; It was his eternall honor, that hee wa ‚Ä¢ God of God; the euerla≈øting Son of the heauenly Father; good rea≈øon therefore was it that, the re≈øpects to fle≈øh: ≈øhould giue place to the God of Spirits‚ñ™ How well contented was holy Mary with ≈øo iu≈øt an an≈øwer, how doth ≈øhe now again in her
hart, renew her an≈øwer to the Angell (Behold the ≈øeruant of the Lord, be it according to thy word.

We are all the ≈øonnes of God in another kinde. Nature and the world thinkes wee ≈øhould attend them; we are not worthy to ≈øay, we haue a Father in heauen, if we cannot ≈øteale away from the≈øe earthly di≈øtractions, and imploy our ≈øelues in the ≈øeruices of our God.

div.head: Chri≈øts Bapti≈øme.
div.p:
IOHN did euery way fore-runne Chri≈øt, not ≈øo much in the time of his birth, as in his office; nether was there more vnlikene≈ø≈øe in their di≈øpo≈øition and carriage, then ≈øimilitude in their function; both did preach and bapti≈øe; only Iohn bapti≈øed by him≈øelfe, our Sauiour by his di≈øciples; our Sauiour wrought miracles by him≈øelfe, by his di≈øciples; Iohn wrought none by
either; Wherein Chri≈øt meant to ≈øhew him≈øelfe a Lord, and Iohn a ≈øeruant; and Iohn meant to approue him≈øelfe a true ≈øeruant to him, who≈øe harbinger he was; hee that leapt in the wombe of his mother, when his Sauiour (then newly conceiued) came in pre≈øence, be≈øtirred him≈øelfe when hee was brought forth into the light of the Church, to the honor and ≈øeruice of his Sauiour: he did the ≈øame before Chri≈øt, which Chri≈øt charged his di≈øciples to doe after him, preach and bapti≈øe. The Go≈øpell ran alwayes in one tenor, and was neuer but like it ≈øelfe; So it became the word of him in whom there is
no ≈øhadow by turning, and who≈øe word it is, I am Iehoua, I change not.

It was fit, that hee which had the Prophets, the ≈øtarre, the Angels to foretell his comming into the world, ≈øhould haue his V≈øher to goe before him, when he would notifie him≈øelfe to the world; Iohn was the voyce of a Cryer, Chri≈øt was the word of his Father; it was fit this voyce ≈øhould make a noy≈øe to the world, ere the word of the Father ≈øhould ≈øpeake to it; Iohns note was ≈øtill, repentance; the axe to the root, the fan to the flowre, the chaffe to the fire; as his rayment was rough, ≈øo was his tongue, and if his food were
wilde hony, his ≈øpeech was ≈øtinging locu≈øts: Thus mu≈øt the way be made for Chri≈øt in euery hart: Plau≈øibility is no fit preface to regeneration: if the hart of man had continued vpright, God might haue beene intertained without contradiction; but now violence mu≈øt be offered to our corruption, ere we can haue roome for grace; if the great way-maker doe not ca≈øt downe hills, and ray≈øe vp vallyes in the bo≈øomes of men, there is no pa≈ø≈øage for Chri≈øt; neuer will Chri≈øt come into that ≈øoule, where the herald of repentance hath not beene before him.

That Sauiour of ours, who
from eternity lay hid in the coun≈øell of God, who in the fulnes of time ≈øo came, that hee lay hid in the wombe of his mother, for the ≈øpace of forty weekes; after hee was come, thought fit to lye hid in Nazareth, for the ≈øpace of thirty yeares, now at la≈øt begins to ≈øhew him≈øelfe to the world, and comes from Galile to Iordan. He that was God alwayes, and might haue beene perfect man in an in≈øtant, would by degrees ri≈øe to the perfection both of his manhood, and execution of his mediator-≈øhip; to teach vs, the nece≈ø≈øity of lea≈øure in ≈øpirituall proceedings; that many ≈øuns, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øions of ≈øea≈øons, and
meanes mu≈øt be ≈øtayd for, ere we can attaine our maturity; and that when we are ripe for the imployments of God, wee ≈øhould no le≈ø≈øe willingly leaue our ob≈øcurity, then wee tooke the benefit of it for our preparation. He that was formerly circumci≈øed, would now bee bapti≈øed; what is bapti≈øme but an Euangelicall circumci≈øion? What was circumci≈øion but a legall bapti≈øme? One both ≈øupplyed and ≈øucceeded the other; yet the author of both will vndergoe both; He would be circumci≈øed to ≈øatisfie his Church that was, and bapti≈øed to ≈øanctifie his Church that ≈øhould bee; that ≈øo in both Te≈øtaments hee
might open away into heauen. There was in him neither filthines, nor fore-skin of corruption, that ≈øhould need either knife, or water; He came not to be a Sauiour for him≈øelfe, but for vs, we are all vncleanene≈ø≈øe, and vncircumci≈øion, he would therefore haue that done to his mo≈øt pure body, which ≈øhould be of force to cleare our impure ≈øoules; thus making him≈øelfe ≈øinne for vs, that we might be made the righteou≈ønes of God in him.

His bapti≈øme giues vertue to ours. His la≈øt action (or rather pa≈ø≈øion) was his bapti≈øing with blood, his fir≈øt was his baptization with water, both of them
wa≈øh the world from their ≈øins. Yea, this latter did not only wa≈øh the ≈øoules of men, but wa≈øheth that very water, by which wee are wa≈øhed; from hence is that made both cleane and holy, and can both clean≈øe and hallow vs; And if the very hadkerchiefe which touched his Apo≈øtles, had power of cure, how much more that Water, which the ≈øacred body of Chri≈øt touched? Chri≈øt comes far, to ≈øeeke his bapti≈øme: to teach vs (for who≈øe ≈øake he was bapti≈øed) to wait vpon the ordinances of God; and to ≈øue for the fauour of ≈øpirituall ble≈ø≈øings; They are worthle≈ø≈øe commodities, that are not worth ≈øeeking for; it is
rarely ≈øcene, that God is found of any man vn≈øought for: that de≈øire which only makes vs capable of good things, cannot ≈øtand with neglect.

Iohn dur≈øt not baptize vnbidden: his Ma≈øter ≈øent him to doe this ≈øeruice, and behold the Ma≈øter comes to his ≈øeruant, to call for the participation of that priuiledge, which he him≈øelfe had in≈øtituted, and enioyned; how willingly ≈øhould wee come to our ≈øpirituall Superiors, for our part in tho≈øe my≈øteries, which God hath left in their keeping; y ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , how gladly ≈øhould wee come to that Chri≈øt, who giues vs the≈øe ble≈ø≈øings; who is giuen to vs in them.

This ≈øeemed too great an honour for the mode≈øty of Iohn to receiue; If his mother could ≈øay, when her ble≈ø≈øed cozen the Virgin Mary, came to vi≈øit her (Whence is this to me, that the mother of my Lord ≈øhould come to me?) how much more might hee ≈øay ≈øo, when the diuine Son of that mother, came to call for a fauor from him? I haue neede to bee baptized of thee, and comme≈øt thou to me? O holy Bapti≈øt, if there were not a greater borne of women then thou; yet thou coulde≈øt not be borne of a woman, and not neede to be baptized of thy Sauiour. Hee baptized with fire, thou with water; Little would thy water haue auailed
thee without his fire, If he had not baptized thee, how wert thou ≈øanctified from the wombe? There can be no fle≈øh without filthine≈ø≈øe; neither thy ≈øupernaturall conception, nor thy au≈øtere life could exempt thee from the need of bapti≈øme: Euen tho≈øe, that haue not liued to ≈øin after the ≈øimilitude of Adam, yet are they ≈øo tainted with Adam, that vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øecond Adam clen≈øe them by his bapti≈øme they are hopele≈ø≈øe; There is no le≈ø≈øe v≈øe of bapti≈øme vnto all, then there is certainty of the need of bapti≈øme; Iohn baptized without; Chri≈øt within. The more holy a man is, the more ≈øen≈øible he is of his vnholine≈ø≈øe;
No carnall man could haue ≈øaid (I haue need to be baptized of thee;) neither can he finde, what he is the better for a little Font-water. The ≈øence of our wretchednes, and the valuation of our ≈øpirituall helps, is the be≈øt tryall of our regeneration: Our Sauiour doth not deny, that either Iohn hath need to be baptized of him, or that it is ≈øtrange, that he ≈øhould come to be baptized of Iohn, but he will needs thus far, both honor Iohn, and di≈øparage him≈øelfe, to be baptized of his Me≈ø≈øenger; he that would take fle≈øh of the Virgin, education from his Parents, ≈øu≈øtenance from his creatures, will take bapti≈øme from Iohn: It is the pray≈øe of his mer
cy, that hee will ≈øtoope ≈øo low, as to bee beholden to his creatures, which from him receiue their being and power, both to take and giue. Yet not ≈øo much re≈øpect to Iohn, as obedience to his Father, drew him to this poynt of humiliation, (Thus it behooues vs to fulfill all righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe.) The coun≈øels and appoyntments of God, are righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe; There needs no other motiue, either to the ≈øeruant, or the Son, then the knowledge of tho≈øe righteous purpo≈øes. This was enough to lead a faithfull man thorow all difficulties and inconueniences; neither will it admit of any reply, or any demurre: Iohn yeeldeth
to this honour, which his Sauiour puts vpon him, in giuing bapti≈øme to the Authour of it: Hee baptized others to the remi≈ø≈øion of their ≈øinnes: now hee baptizes him by them, they are remitted both to the Baptizer, and to others.

No ≈øooner is Chri≈øt baptized, then hee comes forth of the water: The element is of force, but during the v≈øe: It turnes common, when that is pa≈øt, neither is the water ≈øooner powred on his head, then the Heauens are opened, and the Holy Gho≈øt de≈øcendeth vpon that head which was baptized: The Heauens are neuer
≈øhut, whiles either of the Sacraments is duely admini≈øtred, and receiued: neither doe the Heauens euer thus open without the de≈øcent of the Holy Gho≈øt: But now that the God of Heauen is baptized, they open vnto him, which are opened to all the faithfull by him: and that Holy Gho≈øt which proceeded from him, together with the Father; ioynes with the Father in a ≈øen≈øible te≈øtimony of him; that now the world might ≈øee what intere≈øt hee had in the Heauens, in the Father, in the Holy Spirit, and might expect nothing but diuine, from the enttance of ≈øuch a Mediator.

div.head: CHRIST tempted.
div.p:
NO ≈øooner is Chri≈øt comne out of the water of Bapti≈øme, then he enters into the fire of Tentation: No ≈øooner is the Holy Spirit de≈øcended vpon his head, in the forme of a Doue, then hee is led by the ≈øpirit to be tempted. No ≈øooner doth God ≈øay (This is my Son) then Satan ≈øayes, (If thou bee the Son of God.) It is not in the power, either of the gtft or ≈øeales of
Grace, to deliuer vs from the a≈ø≈øaults of Satan; they may haue the force to repell euill ≈øugge≈øtions, they haue none to preuent them; yea, the more we are ingaged vnto God by our publique vowes, and his pledges of fauour, ≈øo much more bu≈øie and violent is the rage of that euill one, to encounter vs; Wee are no ≈øooner ≈øtept forth into the field of God, then hee labours to wre≈øt our weapons out of our hands, or to turne them again≈øt vs.

The voyce from Heauen, acknowledged Chri≈øt to bee the Son of God; this diuine Te≈øtimony did not allay the malice of Satan, but exa≈øperate it: Now
that venomous Serpent ≈øwels with inward poy≈øon, and ha≈øtes to a≈ø≈øayle him, whom God hath honored from Heauen. O God, how ≈øhould I looke to e≈øcape the ≈øugge≈øtious of that wicked one, when the Son of thy loue cannot bee free? when euen grace it ≈øelfe drawes on enmity? That Enemy, that ≈øpared not to ≈øtrike at the head, will he forbeare the weake≈øt and remote≈øt lim? Arme thou mee therefore, with an expectation of that euill I cannot auoyd, Make thou me as ≈øtrong, as he is malicious; Say to my ≈øoule al≈øo (Thou art my Son) and let Satan doe his wor≈øt.

All the time of our Sauiours
ob≈øcurity, I doe not finde him ≈øet vpon; Now, that hee looks forth to the publique execution of his diuine Office, Satan bends his forces again≈øt him: Our priuacy, perhaps, may ≈øit down in peace, but neuer man did endeauour a common good without oppo≈øition. It is a ≈øigne, that both the work is holy, & the Agent faithfull, when wee meet with ≈øtrong affronts.

We haue rea≈øon to bee comforted with nothing ≈øo much, as with re≈øi≈øtance, If we were not in a way to do good, we ≈øhould finde no rubs; Satan hath no cau≈øe to mole≈øt his owne, and that whiles they goe about his owne ≈øeruice; Hee de≈øires nothing
more, then to make vs ≈ømooth paths to ≈øin; but when we would turne our feet to holine≈ø≈øe, hee blocks vp the way with tentations.

Who can wonder enough at the ≈øawcines of that bold Spirit, that dares to ≈øet vpon the Son of the euerliuing God? who can wonder enough at thy meeknes & patience, √¥ Sauiour, that would≈øt be tempted? He wanted not malice and pre≈øumption to a≈ø≈øault thee, thou wanted≈øt not humility to endure tho≈øe a≈ø≈øaults. I ≈øhould ≈øtand amazed at this voluntary di≈øpen≈øation of thine, but that I ≈øee the ≈øu≈øception of our humane nature, layes thee open to this condition. It
is nece≈ø≈øarily incident to manhood, to be liable to tentations; Thou woulde≈øt not haue put no fle≈øh, if thou had≈øt meant vtterly to put off this con≈øequence of our infirmity: If the ≈øtate of innocence could haue beene any defence again≈øt euill motions, the fir≈øt Adam had not been tempted, much le≈ø≈øe the ≈øecond. It is not the pre≈øenting of tentation that can hurt vs, but their entertainment. Ill coun≈øell is the fault of the Giuer, not of the Refu≈øer, We cannot forbid leudeies to look in at our windowes, we may ≈øhut our dores again≈øt their entrance; It is no le≈ø≈øe our prai≈øe to haue re≈øi≈øted, then Satans blame to ≈øugge≈øt euill. Yea, √¥
ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour, how glorious was it for thee, how happy for vs, that thou wert tempted? Had not Satan tempted thee, how ≈øhoulde≈øt thou haue ouercomne? Without blowes there can be no victory, no triumph: How had thy power been manife≈øted; if no aduer≈øary had tried thee? The fir≈øt Adam was tempted & vanqui≈øhed, the ≈øecond Adam, to repay and repaire that foile, doth vanqui≈øh in being tempted. Now haue we not a Sauiour, and High-Prie≈øt, that cannot bee touched with the feeling of our infirmities, but ≈øuch an one, as was in all things tempted in like ≈øort, yet without ≈øin; how boldly therfore
may we goe vnto the Throne of grace, that wee may receiue mercy, and finde grace of help in time of neede: Yea, this Deuil was for vs; Now we ≈øee by this conflict of our Almighty Champion, what manner of Aduer≈øary we haue, how hee fights, how hee is re≈øi≈øted, how ouercomne. Now our very temptation affords vs comfort, in that wee ≈øee, the dearer we are vnto God, the more obnoxious we are to this trial; neither can wee be di≈øcouraged by the haynou≈øne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe euils, wherto we are moued, ≈øince we ≈øee the Son of God ≈øolicited to Infidelity, Couetou≈ønes, Idolatry; How glorious therfore was
it for thee, √¥ Sauior, how happy for vs, that thou wert tempted?

Where then wa≈øt thou tempted, O ble≈ø≈øed Ie≈øu; or whither wente≈øt thou to meet with our great aduer≈øary? I doe not ≈øee thee led into the market-place, or any other part of the city, or thy home-≈øted of Nazareth, but into the va≈øt wilderne≈ø≈øe, the habitation of bea≈øtes; a place that caryeth in it, both horror and oportunity; why would≈øt thou thus retyre thy ≈øelfe from men, but as confident Champions are wont to giue aduantage of ground, or weapon, to their Antagoni≈øt, that the glory of their victory may be the greater: So would≈øt thou, O Sauiour, in
this can but with our common enemy, yeeld him his owne tearmes for circum≈øtances, that thine honour and his foyle may be the more; Solitaryne≈ø≈øe is no ≈ømall helpe to the ≈øpeed of a tentation; Wo to him that is alone, for if he fall, there is not a ≈øecond to lift him vp; Tho≈øe that out of an affectation of holines ≈øeeke for ≈øolitude, in rocks and caues of the de≈øerts, doe no other then runne into the mouth of the danger of tentation, whiles they thinke to avoyd it. It was enough for thee, to who≈øe diuine power the gates of hell were weakene≈ø≈øe; thus to challenge the Prince of darkne≈ø≈øe; Our care mu≈øt be alwaies
to e≈øchue all occa≈øions of ≈øpirituall danger; and (what we may) to get vs out of the reach of tentations.

But O the depth of the wi≈ødome of God; How cam≈øt thou √¥ Sauiour, to be thus tempted? That Spirit whereby thou wa≈øt conceiued, as man, and which was one with thee and the Father, as God, Led thee into the wilderne≈ø≈øe to bee tempted of Satan; Whiles thou taughte≈øt vs to pray to thy Father, Lead vs not into temptation, thou meante≈øt to in≈øtruct vs, that if the ≈øame Spirit lead vs not into this perilous way, we goe not into it; We haue ≈øtill the ≈øame conduct; Let the path bee what it will,
how can wee mi≈øcarry in the hand of a Father. Now may we ≈øay to Satan as thou did≈øt vnto Pilate; thou could≈øt haue no power ouer me, except it were giuen thee from aboue; The ≈øpirit led thee, it did not driue thee; heere was a ≈øweet inuitation, no compul≈øion of violence; So ab≈øolutely conformable was thy wil to thy deity, as if both thy natures had but one volition; In this fir≈øt draught of thy bitter potion, thy Soule ≈øaid in a reall ≈øubjection, Not my will, but thy will be done: We imitate thee, √¥ Sauiour, though we cannot reach to thee; All thine are led by thy Spirit; Oh teach vs to forget that we haue wils of our owne.
The ≈øpirit led thee; thine inuin
‚Ä¢ ible ≈øtrength did not animate thee into thi ‚Ä¢ combat vncalled, What doe we weakelings ≈øo far pre≈øume vpon our abilities, or ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, as that we dare thru≈øt our ≈øelues vpon temptations vnbidden, vnwarranted? Who can pitty the ≈øhip-wracke of tho≈øe Mariners, which will needs put forth, and hoi≈øe ≈øayles in a tempe≈øt?

Forty dayes did our Sauiour ≈øpend in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, fa≈øting, and ≈øolitary, all which time was worne out in temptation; how euer the la≈øt brunt, becau≈øe it was mo≈øt violent, is only expre≈ø≈øed; Now could not the Aduer≈øary complaine of di≈øadvantage,
whiles he had the ful ≈øcope both of time and place to doe his wor≈øt; And why did i ‚Ä¢ plea≈øe thee, √¥ Sauiour, to fa≈ø ‚Ä¢ forty dayes, and forty nights ‚Ä¢ vnle≈ø≈øe as Mo≈øes fa≈øted forty daies at the deliuery of the law and Elias at the re≈øtetution o ‚Ä¢ the law; So thou thoughte≈øt fit at the accompli≈øhment of the law, and the promulgation of the Go≈øpell, to fulfill the time of both the≈øe tipes of thine, wherin thou intended≈øt our wonder, not our imitation; Not our imitation of the time, though of the act. Heere were no faulty de≈øires of the fle≈øh, in thee to be tamed, no po≈ø≈øibility of a freer and more ea≈øie a≈øcent of the
≈øoule to God, that could be affected of thee, who wa≈øt perfectly vnited vnto God, but as for vs thou woulde≈øt ≈øuffer death, ≈øo for vs, thou would≈øt ≈øuffer hunger, that wee might learne by fa≈øting, to prepare our ≈øelues for tentations: In fa≈øting ≈øo long thou intended≈øt the manife≈øtation of thy power; in fa≈øting no longer, the truth of thy manhood; Mo≈øes and Elias, through the miraculous ≈øu≈øtentation of God, fa≈øted ≈øo long, without any que≈øtion made of the truth of their bodies; So long therefore thou thoughte≈øt good to fa≈øt, as by rea≈øon of the≈øe precedents, might be without preiudice of thine humanity,
which if it ≈øhould haue plea≈øed thee to ≈øupport, as thou could≈øt, without meanes, thy very power might haue opened the mouth of cauills again≈ø ‚Ä¢ the verity of thine humane nature; That thou mighte≈øt therfore well approue, that ther ‚Ä¢ was no difference betwixt the ‚Ä¢ and vs, but ≈øinne; thou tha ‚Ä¢ could≈øt haue fa≈øted withou ‚Ä¢ hunger, and liued withou ‚Ä¢ meate; would≈øt both feed, and fa≈øt, and hunger.

Who can be di≈øcouraged with the ≈øcantne≈ø≈øe of frends, or bodily proui≈øions, when hee ≈øees his Sauiour thus long de≈øtitute of all earthly comforts, both of ≈øociety and ≈øu≈øtenance. Oh the
policie and malice of that old Serpent, when he ≈øees Chri≈øt bewray ≈øome infirmity of nature in being hungry, then he layes ≈øore≈øt at him by tentations; His eye was neuer off from our Sauiour‚ñ™ all the time of his ≈øeque≈øtration; and now that he thinks he e≈øpies any one part to lye open, he driues at it with all his might; We haue to doe with an aduer≈øary, no le≈ø≈øe vigilant then malicious; who will bee ≈øure to watch all opportunities of our mi≈øchiefe, and where he ≈øees any aduantage of our weakene≈ø≈øe, will not neglect it. How ≈øhould we ≈øtand vpon our guard for preuention; that both we may not giue him occa≈øions,
of our hurt, nor take hurt by tho≈øe we haue giuen.

When our Sauiour was hungry, Satan temptes him in matter of food; not then, of wealth or glory; He well knowes both what bayts, to fi≈øh withall, and when, and how to lay them; How ≈øafe and happy ≈øhall wee be, if we ≈øhall bend our greate≈øt care where we di≈øcerne the mo≈øt danger?

In euery tentation there is an appearance of good; whether of the body, or minde, or e≈øtate; The fir≈øt is the lu≈øt of the fle≈øh, in any carnall de≈øire, the ≈øecond the pride of hart, and life; the third the lu≈øt of the eyes; To all the≈øe, the fir≈øt Adam is tempted,
and in all mi≈øcarryed; the ≈øecond Adam is tempted to them all, and ouercommeth; The fir≈øt man was tempted, to a carnall appetite by the forbidden fruit, to pride by the ≈øugge≈øtion of being as God; To couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, in the ambitious de≈øire of knowing good and euill; Satan hauing found all the motions ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈ø-full with the fir≈øt Adam in his innocent e≈øtate, will now tread the ≈øame ≈øteps in his temptations of the ≈øecond; The ≈øtones mu≈øt bee made bread; there is the motion to a carnall appetite; The gard and attendance of Angels mu≈øt bee pre≈øumed on, there is a motion to pride; The Kingdomes of the
earth, and the glory of them mu≈øt be offered, there, to couetou≈ønes and ambition.

Satan could not but haue heard God ≈øay, This is my welbeloued Son, he had heard the me≈ø≈øage and the Caroll of the Angels; he ≈øaw the Starre, and the iourney, and offrings, of the Sages, he could not but take notice of the gratulations of Zachary, Simeon, Anna; he well knew the predictions of the Prophets; yet now that hee ≈øaw Chri≈øt fainting with hunger, as not comprehending how infirmities could con≈øi≈øt with a Godhead, he can ≈øay, (If thou bee the Son of God;) Had not Satan knowne that the Son of God
was to come into the world, he had neuer ≈øaid (If thou be the Son of God) His very ≈øuppo≈øition conuinces him; The ground of his tentation, an≈øwers it ≈øelfe; If therefore Chri≈øt ≈øeemed to be a meere man, becau≈øe after forty dayes he was hungry, why was he not confe≈ø≈øed more then a man, in that for forty daies he hungred not? The motiue of the tentation is wor≈øe then the motion, (If thou be the Son of God) Satan could not choo≈øe another ≈øugge≈øtion of ≈øo great importance. All the worke of our redemption, of our ≈øaluation, depends vpon this one truth, Chri≈øt is the Son of God; How ≈øhould hee el≈øe haue ran≈øomed
the world, how ≈øhould he haue done, how ≈øhould he haue ≈øuffered that, which was ≈øatisfactory ‚Ä¢ o his fathers wrath? how ≈øhould his actions, or pa≈ø≈øion beene valuable to the ≈øinnes of all the world? What maruell is it if we that are ≈øonnes by adoption, be a≈ø≈øaulted with the doubts of our intere≈øt in God, when the naturall Son, the Son of his e≈ø≈øence is thus tempted? Since all our comfort con≈øi≈øts in this point, heere mu≈øt needes bee laid the chiefe battery; and heere mu≈øt be placed our ≈øtronge≈øt defence.

To turne ≈øtones into bread, had beene no more faulty in it ≈øelfe, then to turne water into
wine: But to doe this in a di≈øtru≈øt of his Fathers prouidence, to abu≈øe his power and liberty in doing it, to worke a miracle of Satans choyce, had beene di≈øagreeable to the Son of God: There is nothing more ordinary with our ≈øpirituall enemy, then by occa≈øion of want to moue vs to vnwarrantable cour≈øes; Thou art poore, ≈øteale; Thou can≈øt not ri≈øe by hone≈øt meanes, v≈øe indirect; How ea≈øie had it beene for our Sauiour, to haue confounded Satan by the power of his Godhead? But he rather choo≈øes to vanqui≈øh him by the ≈øword of the Spirit, that he might teach vs how to re≈øi≈øt and ouercome the powers of
darkne≈ø≈øe? If hee had ≈øubdued Satan by the almighty power of the deity, wee might haue had what to wonder at, not what to imitate; now hee v≈øeth that weapon, which may be familiar vnto vs, that he may teach our weakene≈ø≈øe how to be victorious; Nothing in heauen or earth can beat the forces of hell, but the word of God; How carefully ≈øhould wee furni≈øh our ≈øelues with this powerfull munition; how ≈øhould our hearts and mouthes bee full of it? Teach mee O Lord the way of thy ≈øtatutes; O take not from mee the words of Truth; Let them bee my ≈øongs in the hou≈øe of my pilgrimage; So ≈øhall I make an≈øwer to my bla≈øphemers.
What needed Chri≈øt to haue an≈øwered Satan at all, if it had not beene to teach vs, that tentations mu≈øt not haue their way; but mu≈øt be an≈øwered by re≈øi≈øtance; and re≈øi≈øted by the word.

What ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary dependance hath the ble≈ø≈øing vpon the creature, if our ptayers hold them not together; As we may not neglect the meanes, ≈øo wee may not neglect the procurement of a ble≈ø≈øing vpon the meanes, nor bee vnthankefull to the hand that hath giuen the ble≈ø≈øing.

In the fir≈øt a≈ø≈øault, Satan moues Chri≈øt to doubt of his fathers prouidence, and to v≈øe vnlawfull meanes to help him≈øelfe: in the next, he moues him to pre≈øume vpon his Fathers protection, and the ≈øeruice of his ble≈ø≈øed Angels; He grounds the fir≈øt vpon a conceit of want, the next of abundance; If he be in extremes, it is all to one end, to mi≈ølead vnto euill: If wee cannot be driuen downe to de≈øpaire, he labours to lift vs vp to pre≈øumption; It is not one foile that can put this bold ≈øpirit out of countenance: Tentations, like waues, breake one in the necke of another; Whiles wee are in this warre-fare, wee
mu≈øt make account, that the repul≈øe of one tentation doth but inuite another.

That ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour of ours, that was content to be led from lordan into the wildernes, for the aduantage of the fir≈øt tentation, yeelds to be led from the wilderne≈ø≈øe to Ieru≈øalem, for the aduantage of the ≈øecond; The place doth not a little auaile to the act: The wilderne≈ø≈øe was fit for a tentation, arifing from want, it was not fit for a tentation mouing to vain-glory. The populous City was the fitte≈øt for ≈øuch a motion; Ieru≈øalem was the glory of the world, the Temple was the glory of Ieru≈øalem, the pinacles, the highe≈øt
peece of the Temple, there is Chri≈øt content to be ≈øet for the opportunity of tentation: O Sauiour of men, how can wee wonder enough at this humility of thine, that thou would≈øt ≈øo farre aba≈øe thy ≈øelfe, as to ≈øuffer thy pure and ≈øacred body to bee tran≈øported by the pre≈øumptuous and malicious hand of that vncha≈øte ≈øpirit? It was not his power, it was thy patience, that de≈øerues our admiration, Neither can this ≈øeem ouer-≈øtrange to vs, when wee con≈øider, that if Satan bee the head of wicked men, wicked men are the members of Satan; What was Pilate, or the Iewes that per≈øecuted thine innocence,
but lims of this Diuell? and why are we then amazed, to ≈øee thee touched, and locally tran≈øported by the head, when wee ≈øee thee yeelding thy ≈øelfe ouer, to be crucified by the members? If Satan did the wor≈øe, and greater, mediately by their hands, no maruell if hee doe the le≈ø≈øe and ea≈øier, immediately by his own, yet neither of them without thy voluntary di≈øpen≈øation. Hee could not haue looked at thee, without thee; And if the Son of God, did thus ≈øuffer his owne holy and precious body, to bee carried by Satan, what wonder is it, if that Enemy haue ≈øometimes power giuen him, ouer the ≈øinfull bodies of the adopted
Sons of God. It is not the ≈øtrength of faith, that can ≈øecure vs from the outward violences of that euill One; This difference I finde betwixt his ≈øpirituall and bodily a≈ø≈øaults: tho≈øe are beaten backe by the ≈øhield of faith, the≈øe admit not of ≈øuch repul≈øe; As the be≈øt man may bee lame, blinde, di≈øea≈øed, ≈øo through the permi≈ø≈øion of God, he may be bodily vexed by that olde Man-≈ølayer; Grace was neuer giuen vs for a target again≈øt externall afflictions.

Me thinkes I ≈øee Chri≈øt, hoy≈øed vp on the highe≈øt battlements of the Temple; who≈øe very roofe was an hundred and thirty cubits high; and Satan
≈øtanding by him with this ≈øpeech in his mouth; Well then, ≈øince in the matter of nouri≈øhment, thou wilt needes depend vpon thy Fathers prouidence, that he can without meanes ≈øu≈øtaine thee, take now further triall of that prouidence, in thy miraculous pre≈øeruation; Ca≈øt thy ≈øelfe down from this height; Behold, thou art here in Ieru≈øalem, the famous and holy City of the world; here thou art, on the top of the pinacle of that Temple, which is dedicated to thy Father, and, if thou be God, to thy ≈øelfe; the eyes of all men are now fixt vpon thee, there cannot be deui≈øed a more ready way to ≈øpred thy glory, and to
proclaime thy Deity, then by ca≈øting thy ≈øelfe headlong to the earth. All the world will ≈øay, there is more in thee, then a man; and for danger, there can bee none; What can hurt him, that is the Son of God? and wherefore ≈øerues that glorious Guard of Angels, which haue by diuine commi≈ø≈øion, taken vpon them the charge of thine humanity? ≈øince therefore in one act, thou may≈øt bee both ≈øafe, and celebrated, tru≈øt thy Father, and tho≈øe thy ≈øeruiceable ≈øpirits with thine a≈ø≈øured pre≈øeruation, Ca≈øt thy ≈øelfe downe: And why did≈øt thou not, √¥ thou malignant ≈øpirit, endeauour to ca≈øt downe my Sauiour, by tho≈øe
≈øame pre≈øumptuous hands, that brought him vp, ≈øince the de≈øcent is more ea≈øie then the rai≈øing vp? was it for that, it had not beene ≈øo great an aduantage to thee, that hee ≈øhould fall by thy meanes, as by his owne? falling into ≈øinne, was more then to fall from the pinacle; ≈øtill thy care and ≈øute is, to make vs Authours to our ≈øelues of euill; thou gaine≈øt nothing by our bodily hurt; if the ≈øoule be ≈øafe: Or was it rather for that, thou could≈øt not? I doubt not, but thy malice could as well haue ≈øerued, to haue offered this mea≈øure to him≈øelfe, as to his holy Apo≈øtle ≈øoone after; but he that bounded thy power,
tether'd thee ≈øhorter; Thou could≈øt not, thou can≈øt not doe what thou would≈øt. Hee that would permit thee to carry him vp, binds thy hands from ca≈øting him downe: And wo were it for vs if thou wert not euer ≈øtinted:

Why did Satan carry vp Chri≈øt ≈øo high, but on purpo≈øe, that his fall might bee the more deadly; ≈øo deales hee ≈øtill with vs, he exalts vs, that we may be dangerou≈øly aba≈øed; Hee puffs men vp with ≈øwelling thoughts of their owne worthine≈ø≈øe, that they may bee vile in the eyes of God, and fall into condemnation: It is the manner of God, to ca≈øt downe, that he may rai≈øe, to
aba≈øe that he may exalt; Contrarily, Satan rai≈øes vp, that hee may throw downe, and intends nothing but our deiection, in our aduancement.

Height of place giues opportunity of tentation; Thus bu≈øie is that wicked one, in working again≈øt the members of Chri≈øt. If any of them bee in eminence aboue others, tho≈øe hee labours mo≈øt to ruinate‚ñ™ They had need to ≈øtand fa≈øt, that ≈øtand high; Both there is more danger of their falling, and more hurt in their fall.

How idly doe Satan and wicked men mea≈øure God, by the crooked line of their owne mi≈øconceit: Ywis, Chri≈øt cannot be the Son of God, vnle≈ø≈øe hee ca≈øt him≈øelfe downe from the pinacle; vnle≈ø≈øe he come down from the Cro≈ø≈øe. God is not mercifull, vnles he humor them in all their de≈øires, not iu≈øt, vnle≈ø≈øe hee take ≈øpeedy vengeance, where they require it; But when
they haue ≈øpent their folly vpon the≈øe vaine imaginations, Chri≈øt is the Son of God, though hee ≈øtay on the top of the Temple, God will bee mercifull, though wee mi≈øcarry, and iu≈øt, though Sinners ≈øeeme lawle≈ø≈øe. Neither will he be any other then he is, or mea≈øured by any rule, but him≈øelfe.

But what is this I ≈øee, Satan him≈øelfe with a Bible vnder his arme, with a Text in his mouth, It is written, He ≈øhall giue his Angels charge ouer thee? How ≈øtill in that wicked One doth ≈øubtilty ≈øtriue with pre≈øumption? Who could not, but ouer-wonder at this, if hee did not con≈øider, that ≈øince the Deuill dared to touch the
≈øacred b√≥dy of Chri≈øt with his hand, hee may well touch the Scriptures of God with his tongue? Let no man henceforth maruell, to heare heretikes, or hypocrites, quote Scriptures, when Satan him≈øelfe hath not ≈øpared to cite theÃÑ; what are they the wor≈øe for this, more then that holy body, which he tran≈øported? Some haue been poy≈øoned, by their meats & drinks, yet either the≈øe nouri≈øh vs, or nothing: It is not the letter of the Scripture that can carry it, but the ≈øence; if we diuide the≈øe two, wee prophane and abu≈øe that word wee alledge. And wherfore doth this foule Spirit vrgea Text, but for imitation,
for preuention, and for ≈øucce≈ø≈øe? Chri≈øt had alledged a Scripture vnto him, hee re-alledges Scripture vnto Chri≈øt: At lea≈øt wi≈øe, he will counterfet an imitation of the Son of God; Neither is it in this alone; what one act euer pa≈ø≈øed the hand of God, which Satan did not api≈øhly attempt to ≈øecond? If we follow Chri≈øt in the outward action, with contrary intentions, wee follow Satan, in following Chri≈øt. Or, perhaps, Satan meant to make Chri≈øt hereby weery of this weapon; As wee ≈øee fa≈øhions, when they are taken vp of the vnworthy. are ca≈øt of by the great, It was doubtles, one cau≈øe, why Chri≈øt
afterwards forbad the Diuell euen to confe≈ø≈øe the truth, becau≈øe his mouth was a ≈ølander. But chiefely doth he this, for a better colour of his tentation: He guilds ouer this falfe mettall with Scripture, that it may pa≈ø≈øe currant; Euen now is Satan transformed into an Angel of light, and will ≈øeeme godly for a mi≈øcheife; If hypocrites make a faire ≈øhow to deceiue with a glorious lu≈øtre of holine≈ø≈øe, we ≈øee whence they borrowd it: How many thou≈øand ≈øoules are betrayd by the abu≈øe of that word, who≈øe v≈øe is ≈øoueraigne and ≈øauing. No diuell is ≈øo dangerous as the religious diuell. If good meate turne to the nouri≈øhment,
not of nature, but of the di≈øea≈øe, we may not forbeare to feed, but indeauour to purge the body of tho≈øe euill humors, which cau≈øe the ≈øtomach to worke again≈øt it ≈øelfe. O God, thou that ha≈øt giuen vs light, giue vs cleare and ≈øound eyes, that we may take comfort of that light thou ha≈øt giuen vs; Thy word is holy, make our hearts ≈øo, and then ≈øhall they finde that word, not more true then cordiall; Let not this diuine table of thine, bee made a ≈ønare to our ≈øoules.

What can be a better act then to ≈øpeake Scripture? It were a wonder if Satan ≈øhould doe a good thing well; He cites ≈øcripture
then, but with mutilation, and di≈øtortion; it comes not out of his mouth, but maymed and peruerted; One peece is left out, all mi≈øapplyed; Tho≈øe that wre≈øt or mangle Scripture for their owne turne, it is ea≈øie to ≈øee from what ≈øchoole they come. Let vs take the word from the author, not from the v≈øurper: Dauid would not doubt to eate that ≈øheep, which hee pulled out of the mouth of the Beare or Lyon; (Hee ≈øhall giue his Angels charge ouer thee:) Oh comfortable a≈ø≈øurance of our protection; Gods children neuer goe vnattended; Like vnto great Princes we walke euer in the mid≈øt of our guard; though inui≈øible,
yet true, carefull, powerfull; What creatures are ≈øo glorious as the Angels of heauen, yet their maker hath ≈øet them to ≈øerue vs: Our adoption makes vs at once great and ≈øafe; Wee may be contemptible and ignominious in the eyes of the world, but the Angels of God ob≈øerue vs the while, and ≈øcorne not to wait vpon vs in our homelie≈øt occa≈øions; The Sun, or the light may wee keepe out of our hou≈øes, the ayre we cannot; much le≈ø≈øe the≈øe fpirits, that are more ≈øimple and immateriall: No walls, no bolts, can ≈øeuer them from our ≈øides: they accompany vs in dungeons, they goe with vs into our exile;
How can wee either feare danger, or complaine of ≈øolitarine≈ø≈øe, whiles we haue ≈øo vn≈øeperable, ≈øo glorious companions?

Is our Sauiour di≈øta≈øted with Scripture, becau≈øe Satan mi≈ølaies it in his di≈øh? Doth he not rather ≈ønatch this ≈øword out of that impure hand, and beat Satan with the weapon which hee abu≈øeth; (It is written, Thou ≈øhalt not tempt thy Lord thy God;) The Scripture is one, as that God, who≈øe it is; Where it carryes an appearance of difficulty or inconuenience, it needs no light to cleare it, but that, which it hath in it ≈øelfe. All doubts that may ari≈øe from it, are fully an≈øwered by collection; It is true
that God hath taken this care, and giuen this charge of his owne; he will haue them kept, not in their ≈øinnes; they may tru≈øt him, they may not tempt him; hee meant to incourage their faith, not their pre≈øumption. To ca≈øt our ≈øelues vpon an immediate prouidence, when meanes faile not, is to di≈øobey, in ≈øteed of beleeuing God; we may challenge God on his word, we may not ≈øtraine him beyond it; wee may make account of what he promi≈øed, we may not ≈øubiect his promi≈øes to vniu≈øt examinations; and where no need is, make triall of his power, iu≈øtice, mercie, by deui≈øes of our owne. All the Diuels
in hel, could not elude the force of this diuine an≈øwer; and now Satan ≈øees how vainely he tempteth Chri≈øt to tempt God.

Yet againe for all this, doe I ≈øee him ≈øetting vpon the Son of God: Satan is not foyled when he is re≈øi≈øted: neither diffidence, nor pre≈øumption can fa≈øten vpon Chri≈øt, he ≈øhall be tryed with honor; As ≈øome expert Fencer that challenges at all weapons, ≈øo doth this great enemy; In vaine ≈øhall we plead our skill in ≈øome, if we faile in any; It mu≈øt be our wi≈ødome to be prepared for all kinde of a≈ø≈øaults: As tho≈øe that hold townes and forts doe, not only defend them≈øelues from incur≈øions, but from the
cannon and the Pioner; ≈øtill doth that ≈øubtil Serpent trauer≈øe his ground for an aduantage; The Temple is not hye enough for his next tentation; He therefore carryes vp Chri≈øt to the top of an exceeding high mountaine; All enemies in pitcht fields ≈øtriue for the benefit of the hill, or riuer, or winde, or ≈øunne; That which his ≈øeruant Balac did by his in≈øtigation, him≈øelfe doth now immediately, change places in hope of preuailing. If the ob≈øcure country will not moue vs, hee tries what the Court can do, if not our home, the Tauerne, if not the field, our clo≈øet,; As no place is left free by his malice, ≈øo no place mu≈øt
be made preiudiciall by our carele≈øne≈ø≈øe; and as wee ≈øhould alwayes watch ouer our ≈øelues, ≈øo then mo≈øt, when the oportunity carries cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpicion.

Wherfore is Chri≈øt caryed vp ≈øo high but for pro≈øpect? If the kingdomes of the earth and their glory, were only to be repre≈øented to his imagination; the valley would haue ≈øerued; If to the outward ≈øence, no hill could ≈øuffice; Circular bodyes though ≈ømal, cannot be ≈øeene at once. This ≈øhow was made to both, diuers kingdomes lying round about Iudea were repre≈øented to the eye; The glory of them to the imagination; Satan meant the eye could tempt the
fancy; no le≈ø≈øe then the fancy could tempt the will. How many thou≈øand ≈øoules haue dyed of the wound of the eye; If we doe not let in ≈øinne at the window of the eye, or the dore of the eare, it cannot enter into our hearts.

If there bee any pompe, maie≈øty, plea≈øure, brauery in the world, where ≈øhould it be but in the Courts of Princes, whom God hath made his Images, his deputies vpon earth? There is ≈øoft rayment, ≈øumptuous fea≈øts, rich Iewels, honorable attendance, glorious triumphs, royall ≈øtate, the≈øe Satan laies out to the faire≈øt ≈øhow: But oh the craft of that old Serpent; Many
a care attends greatne≈ø≈øe; No creature is without thornes: High ≈øeats are neuer but vnea≈øie; all tho≈øe infinite di≈øcontentments, which are the ≈øhaddow of earthly ≈øoueraignety, he hides out of the way; nothing may bee ≈øeene, but what may both plea≈øe and allure. Satan is ≈øtill and euer like him≈øelfe; If tentations might be but turnd about and ≈øhowne on both ≈øides, the kingdome of darkne≈ø≈øe would not be ≈øo populous. Now when≈øoeuer the Tempter ≈øets vpon any poore ≈øoule, all ≈øting of con≈øcience, wrath, iudgement, torment is concealed, as if they were not; Nothing may appeare to the eye but plea≈øure,
profit, and a ≈øeeming happine≈ø≈øe in the inioying our de≈øires; tho≈øe other wofull obiects are re≈øerued for the farewell of ≈øinne; that our mi≈øery may bee ≈øeene and felt at once; When we are once ≈øure, Satan is a Tyrant, till then, he is a Para≈øite: There can be no ≈øafety, if we do not view as well the backe as the face of tentations.

But oh pre≈øumption and impudence, that hell it ≈øelfe may be a≈øham'd of; The Diuell dares ≈øay to Chri≈øt, All the≈øe will I giue thee, if thou wilt fall downe and wor≈øhip mee; That beggerly ≈øpirit, that hath not an inch of earth, can offer the whole world to the maker; to the owner of it;
The ≈ølaue of God would be adord of his Creator; How can we hope he ≈øhould be ≈øparing of fal≈øe boa≈øts, and of vnrea≈øonable promi≈øes vnto vs, when hee dares offer kingdomes to him by whom kings raigne?
Tentations on the right hand are mo≈øt dangerous; how many that haue bene hardned with feare, haue melted with honor; There is no doubt of that ≈øoule that will not bite at the golden hooke.

Fal≈øe lyers and vaineglorious boa≈øters, ≈øee the top of their pedigree; If I may not rather ≈øay, that Satan doth borrow the v≈øe of their tongues for a time; Whereas faithfull is he that hath
promi≈øed; who will al≈øo doe it. Fidelity and truth is the i≈ø≈øue of heauen.

If Idolatry were not a deare ≈øinne to Satan, he would not be ≈øo importunate to compa≈ø≈øe it; It is mi≈øerable to ≈øee how hee drawes the world in≈øen≈øibly into this ≈øin, which they profe≈ø≈øe to dete≈øt; Tho≈øe that would rather hazard the furnace, then wor≈øhip gold in a ≈øtatue, yet doe adore it in the ≈øtampe, and finde no fault with them≈øelues. If our hearts be drawne to ≈øtoope vnto an ouer-high re≈øpect of any creature, wee are Idolaters. O God, it is no maruell if thy ielou≈øie be kindled at the admi≈ø≈øion of any of thine owne works
into a competition of honor with their Creator.

Neuer did our Sauiour ≈øay, Auoid Satan, till now; It is a iu≈øt indignation, that is conceiued at the motion of a riuality with God, Neither yet did Chri≈øt exerci≈øe his diuine power in this command, but by the nece≈ø≈øary force of Scripture, driues away that impure Tempter; It is written, Thou ≈øhalt wor≈øhip the Lord thy God, and him only ≈øhalt thou ≈øerue: The re≈øt of our Sauiours an≈øwers were more full and direct, then that they could admit of a reply, but this was ≈øo flat and ab≈øolute, that it vtterly daunted the courage of Satan, and put him to a ≈øhamefull flight, and
made him for the time, weary of his trade.

The way to bee rid of the trouble≈øome ≈øolicitations of that wicked one, is continued re≈øi≈øtance. Hee that forcibly droue the tempter from him≈øelfe, takes him off from vs, and will not abide his a≈ø≈øaults perpctuall; It is our exerci≈øe and triall, that hee intends, not our confu≈øion.

div.head: Simon called.
div.p:
AS the Sun in his fir≈øt ri≈øing, drawes all e ‚Ä¢ es to it; So did this Sun of righteou≈ønes, when hee fir≈øt ≈øhone forth into the world; His miraculous cures drew Patients, his diuine doctrine drew Auditors, both together drew the admiring multitude by troopes after him. And why doe wee not ≈øtill follow
thee, √¥ Sauiour, thorow de≈øerts and mountaines, ouer land and ≈øeas, that wee may bee both healed, and taught. It was thy word, that when thou wert lift vp, thou would≈øt draw all men vnto thee; Behold, thou art lift vp long ≈øince, both to the tree of ≈øhame, and to the throne of heauenly glory, Draw vs, and we ≈øhall run after thee; Thy word is ≈øtill the ≈øame, though proclaimed by men, thy vertue is ≈øtill the ≈øame, though exerci≈øed vpon the ≈øpirits of men; Oh giue vs, to hunger after both, that by both, our ≈øoules may be ≈øatisfied.

I ≈øee the people, not onely following Chri≈øt, but pre≈ø≈øing
vpon him; euen very vnmannerline≈ø≈øe findes here both excu≈øe and acceptation; They did not keepe their di≈øtances in an awe to the Maie≈øty of the Speaker, whiles they were raui≈øhed with the power of the ≈øpeech, yet did not our Sauiour checke their vnreuerent thronging, but rather encourages their forwardne≈ø≈øe. Wee cannot offend thee, √¥ God, with the importunity of our de≈øires; It likes thee well, that the Kingdom of Heauen ≈øhould ≈øuffer violence. Our ≈ølackne≈ø≈øe doth euer di≈øplea≈øe theee, neuer our vehemence.

The throng of Auditors forced Chri≈øt to leaue the ≈øhore, and to make Peters ≈øhip his Pulpit;
Neuer were there ≈øuch nets ca≈øt out of that fi≈øher-boat before; whiles hee was vpon the land, he healed the ≈øicke bodies by his touch; now that he was vpon the ≈øea, he cured the ≈øicke ≈øoules by his doctrine; and is purpo≈øely ≈øeuered from the multitude, that hee may vnite them to him. Hee that made both ≈øea and land, cau≈øeth both of them to con≈øpire to the opportunities of doing good.

Simon was bu≈øie, wa≈øhing his nets: Euen tho≈øe nets that caught nothing, mu≈øt bee wa≈øhed, no le≈ø≈øe then if they had ≈øped well: The nights toyle doth not excu≈øe his dayes work: Little did Simon thinke of leauing
tho≈øe nets, which hee ≈øo carefully wa≈øhed; and now Chri≈øt interrupts him with the fauour and ble≈ø≈øing of his gracious pre≈øence; Labour in our callings (how homely ≈øoeuer) makes vs capable of diuine benediction.

The hone≈øt Fi≈øher-man, when hee ≈øaw the people flocke after Chri≈øt, and heard him ≈øpeake with ≈øuch power, could not but conceiue a generall & confu≈øe apprehen≈øion of ≈øome excellent worth in ≈øuch a Teacher, and therefore is glad to honour his ≈øhip with ≈øuch a gue≈øt; and is fir≈øt Chri≈øts ho≈øt by ≈øea, ere hee is his Di≈øciple by land; An humble and ≈øeruiceable entertainment
of a Prophet of God, was a good foundation of his future honour; Hee that would ≈øo ea≈øily lend Chri≈øt his hand, and his ≈øhip, was likely ≈øoone after to be≈øtow him≈øelfe vpon his Sauiour.

Simon hath no ≈øooner done this ≈øeruice to Chri≈øt, then Chri≈øt is preparing for his reward; when the ≈øermon is ended, the ≈øhip-roome ≈øhall bee payd for abundantly; Neither ≈øhall the Ho≈øt expect any other pay-ma≈øter then him≈øelfe: Lanch forth into the deepe, and let downe your nets to make a draught: That ≈øhip which lent Chri≈øt an opportunity of catching men vpon the ≈øhore, ≈øhall bee requited
with a plentifull draught of fi≈øh in the deepe: It had beene as ea≈øie for our Sauiour, to haue brought the fi≈øh to Peters ≈øhip, clo≈øe to the ≈øhore, yet as chu≈øing rather to haue the ≈øhip carried to the ≈øhole of fi≈øh, hee bids (Lanch forth into the deep:) In his miracles, hee loues euer to meet nature in her bounds; and when ≈øhe hath done her be≈øt, to ≈øupply the re≈øt by his ouer-ruling power; The ≈øame power therefore, that could haue cau≈øed the fi≈øhes to leap vpon dry land, or to leaue them≈øelues for≈øaken of the waters, vpon the ≈øands of the Lake, will rather finde them in a place naturall to their abiding (Lanch out into the deepe.)

Rather in a de≈øire to gratifie and obey his gue≈øt, then to plea≈øure him≈øelfe, will Simon be≈øtow one ca≈øt of his net; Had Chri≈øt enioyned him an harder taske, he had not refu≈øed; yet not without an allegation of the vnlikelyhood of ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, (Ma≈øter wee haue trauailed all night, and caught nothing; yet at thy word I will let downe the net.

The night was the fitte≈øt time for the hopes of their trade; not vniu≈øtly might Simon mi≈ødoubt his ≈øpeed by day, when hee had worne out the night in vnprofitable labour: Sometimes God cro≈ø≈øeth the fayre≈øt of our expectations, and giues a ble≈ø≈øing to tho≈øe times and means wherof
we de≈øpayre. That paynes cannot be ca≈øt away which we re≈øolue to loo≈øe for Chri≈øt.

Oh God, how many doe I ≈øee ca≈øting out their netsin the great lake of the world, which in the whole night of their life haue caught nothing; They conceiue mi≈øchiefe and bring forth iniquity; They hatch Cokatrices eggs, & weaue the ≈øpiders web; he that eateth of their egs dyeth, and that which is troden vpon, breaketh out into a Serpent; Their webs ≈øhal be no garment, neither ≈øhall they couer them≈øelues with their labours.

Oh ye ≈øonnes of men, how long will ye loue vanity and follow after lyes? Yet, if wee haue thus vainely
mi≈øpent the time of our darkene≈ø≈øe; Let vs at the command of Chri≈øt, ca≈øt out our new-wa≈øhen nets; our humble and penitent obedience, ≈øhall come home laden with ble≈ø≈øings, (And when they had ≈øo done, they inclo≈øed a great multitude of fi≈øhes, ≈øo that their net brake:) What a difference there is betwixt our owne voluntary acts, and tho≈øe that are done vpon command; not more in the grounds of them, then in the i≈ø≈øue? tho≈øe are oft-times fruitle≈ø≈øe, the≈øe euer ≈øucce≈øsfull: Neuer man threw out his net at the word of his Sauiour, and drew it backe empty; who would not obey thee, √¥ Chri≈øt, ≈øince thou do≈øt ≈øo
bountifully requite our weake≈øt ≈øeruices?

It was not meere retribution that was intended in this euent, but in≈øtruction al≈øo: This act was not without a mi≈øtery; He that ≈øhould be made a fi≈øher of men, ≈øhall in this draught fore≈øee his ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; The kingdome of heauen is like a draw-net, ca≈øt into the ≈øea, which when it is full men draw to land; The very fir≈øt draught that Peter made after the complement of his Apo≈øtle≈øhip, inclo≈øed no le≈ø≈øe then three thou≈øand ≈øoules. Oh powerfull Go≈øpell, that can fetch ≈øinfull men from out of the depthes of naturall corruption: Oh happy ≈øoules, that from the
blinde and muddy cells of our wicked nature, are drawne forth to the glorious liberty of the ≈øonnes of God. Simons net breaks with the ≈øtore; Abundance is ≈øometimes no le≈ø≈øe trouble≈øome then want; the net ≈øhould haue held, if Chri≈øt had not meant to ouer-charge Simon both with ble≈ø≈øing and admiration: How happily is that net broken, who≈øe rupture drawes the fi≈øher to Chri≈øt. Though the net brake, yet the fi≈øh e≈øcaped not; Hee that brought them thither to be taken, held them there till they were taken, (They beckened to their partners in the other ≈øhip, that they ≈øhould come and help them;) There are other ≈øhips in partner≈øhip
with Peter, he doth not fi≈øh all the lake alone; There cannot be a better improuement of ≈øociety, then to helpe vs againe, to releeue vs in our profitable labours; to draw vp the ≈øpirituall draught into the ve≈ø≈øell of Chri≈øt, and his Church: wherfore hath God giuen vs partners, but that he ≈øhould becken to them for their ayd in our nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øions? Neither doth Simon ≈ølacken his hand, becau≈øe he had a≈ø≈øi≈øtants. What ≈øhall we ≈øay to tho≈øe lazie fi≈øhers, who can ≈øet others to the drag, whiles them≈øelues looke on at ea≈øe; caring onely to feede them≈øelues with the fi≈øh, not willing to wet their hands with the nett?

What ≈øhall wee ≈øay to this exce≈ø≈øe of gaine? The nets breake, the ≈øhips ≈øinke with their burden: Oh happy complaint of too large a capture! O Sauiour, if tho≈øe Apo≈øtolicall ve≈ø≈øels of thy fir≈øt rigging, were thus ouerlayd, ours flote and totter with an vnballa≈øted lightnes: Thou, who art no le≈ø≈øe pre≈øent in the≈øe bottoms of ours, lade them with an equall fraight of conuerted ≈øoules, and let vs pray≈øe thee for thus ≈øinking.

Simon was a skilful Fi≈øher, and knew well the depth of his trade, and now perceiuing more then Art or nature in this draught, hee fals downe at the knees of Ie≈øus, ≈øaying, (Lord, goe
from mee, for I am a ≈øinfull man.) Him≈øelfe is caught in this net: He doth not greedily fall vpon ≈øo vnexpected and profitable a booty, but hee turnes his eyes from the draught to him≈øelfe, from the act to the Author, acknowledging vilene≈ø≈øe in the one, in the other Maie≈øty; (Goe from me Lord, for I am a ≈øinfull man.)

It had beene pitty the hone≈øt Fi≈øher-man ≈øhould haue beene taken at his Word: Oh Simon, thy Sauiour is comne into thine owne ≈øhip to call thee, to call others by thee vnto ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe, and doe≈øt thou ≈øay, Lord, goe from me? As if the Patient ≈øhould ≈øay to the Phy≈øician; Depart from me, for I am ≈øicke. It was the
voyce of a≈øtoni≈øhment, not of di≈ølike; the voyce of humility, not of di≈øcontentment: yea, becau≈øe thou art a ≈øinfull man, therfore hath thy Sauiour neede to come to thee, to ≈øtay with thee; and becau≈øe thou art humble in the acknowledgement of thy ≈øinfulnes, therfore Chri≈øt delights to abide with thee, and will call thee to abide with him; No man euer fared the wor≈øe for aba≈øing him≈øelfe to his God; Chri≈øt hath left many a ≈øoule, for froward and vnkinde v≈øage, neuer any for the di≈øparagement of it ≈øelfe, and intreaties of humility. Simon could not deui≈øe how to hold Chri≈øt fa≈øter, then by thus ≈øuing to him, to be
gone, then by thus pleading his vnworthine≈ø≈øe.

O my ≈øoule be not weary of complaining of thine owne wretchedne≈ø≈øe, di≈øgrace thy ≈øelfe to him that knowes thy vilenes; be a≈øtoni≈øhed at tho≈øe mercies which haue ≈øhamed thine ill de≈øeruings; Thy Sauiour hath no power to goe away from a pro≈øtrate hart; Hee that re≈øi≈øts the proud, hartens the lowly (Feare not, for I will make thee hence-forth a fi≈øher of men.) Lo, this humility is rewarded with an Apo≈øtle≈øhip: What had the earth euer more glorious, then a legacy from heauen? He that bad Chri≈øt goe from him, ≈øhall haue the honor to goe fir≈øt on this happy
errand; This was a trade that Simon had no skill of: it could not but be enough to him, that Chri≈øt ≈øaid, I will make thee; the miracle ≈øhewd him, able to make good his word; hee that hath power to command the fi≈øhes to be taken, can ea≈øily enable the hands to take them.

What is this diuine trade of ours then, but a ≈øpirituall pi≈øcation? The world is a ≈øea; ≈øoules like fi≈øhes ≈øwim at liberty in this deep, the nets of whol≈øome doctrine, draw vp ≈øome to the ≈øhore of grace and glory; How much skill, and toyle, and patience, is requi≈øite in this art? Who is ≈øufficient for the≈øe things? This ≈øea, the≈øe nets, the
fi≈øhers, the fi≈øh, the ve≈ø≈øels are all thine, √¥ God; doe what thou wilt in vs, and by vs; Giue vs ability and grace to take, giue men will and grace to bee taken, and take thou glory by that which thou ha≈øt giuen.

div.head: The marriage in Cana.
div.p:
WAS this then thy fir≈øt miracle, √¥ Sauiour, that thou wroughts in Cana of Galile? And could there be a greater miracle then this, that hauing bene thirty yeares vpon earth, thou did≈øt no miracle till now? That thy diuinity did hide it ≈øelfe thus long in fle≈øh; that ≈øo long thou would≈øt lye ob≈øcure in a corner of Galile, vnknowne to that world thou
came≈øt to redeeme? That ≈øo long thou would≈øt ≈øtrayne the patient expectation of tho≈øe, who euer ≈øince thy Star, waited vpon the reuelation of a Me≈ø≈øias? Wee ≈øilly wretches, if wee haue but a dram of vertue, are ready to ≈øet it out to the be≈øt ≈øhow, thou who receiued≈øt not the Spirit by mea≈øure, would≈øt content thy ≈øelfe with a willing ob≈øcurity, and concealed≈øt that power that made the world, in the roofe of an humane bre≈øt, in a cottage of Nazareth. O Sauiour, none of thy miracles is more worthy of a≈øtoni≈øhment, then thy not doing of miracles. What thou did≈øt in priuate, thy wi≈ødome thought fit for ≈øecrecy;
but if thy ble≈ø≈øed mother had not beene acquainted with ≈øome dome≈øticall wonders, ≈øhe had not now expected a miracle abroad; The ≈øtarres are not ≈øeene by day; the Sun it ≈øelfe is not ≈øeene by night: As it is no ≈ømall art to hide Art, ≈øo is it no ≈ømall glory, to conceale glory; Thy fir≈øt publique miracle graceth a marriage; It is an ancient and laudable in≈øtitution, that the rites of matrimony ≈øhould not want a ≈øolemne celebration; When are fea≈øts in ≈øea≈øon, if not at the recouery of our lo≈øt ribbe? If not at this maine change of our e≈øtate, wherein the ioy of obtaining, meets with the hope of further comforts? The Son
of the Virgin, and the Mother of that Son are both at a wedding; It was in all likelyhood ≈øome of their kindred, to who≈øe nuptiall fea≈øt, they were inuited ≈øo farre; yet was it more the honor of the act, then of the per≈øon, that Chri≈øt intended; He that made the fir≈øt marriage in Paradi≈øe, be≈øtowes his fir≈øt miracle vpon a Galilean marriage; Hee that was the author of matrimony and ≈øanctified it, doth by his holy pre≈øence, hone≈øt the re≈øemblance of his eternall vnion with his Church: How boldly may we ≈øpit in the faces of all the impure aduer≈øaries of wedlocke, when the Sonne of God plea≈øes to honor it?

The glorious bride-groome of the Church, knew well how ready men would bee to place ≈øhame, euen in the mo≈øt lawfull coniunctions; and therfore his fir≈øt worke ≈øhall be, to countenance his own ordinance. Happy is that wedding, where Chri≈øt is a gue≈øt; O Sauiour, tho≈øe that marry in thee, cannot marry without thee; There is no holy marriage whereat thou art not (how euer inui≈øible) yet truely pre≈øent, by thy Spirit, by thy gracious benediction. Thou make≈øt marriages in heauen, thou ble≈ø≈øe≈øt them from heauen. Oh thou, that ha≈øt betrothed vs to thy ≈øelfe in truth and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, doe thou
con≈øummate that happy marriage of ours in the highe≈øt heauens.

It was no rich or ≈øumptuous Bridall, to which Chri≈øt with his Mother, & Di≈øciples vouch≈øafed to come, from the further parts of Galile; I finde him not at the magnificent fea≈øts or triumphs of the great; the proud pompe of the world, did not agree with the ≈øtate of a ≈øeruant; This poore needy bride-groom wants drinke for his gue≈øts. The ble≈ø≈øed virgin (though a ≈øtranger, to the hou≈øe) out of a charitable compa≈ø≈øion, and a frendly de≈øire, to maintaine the decency of an ho≈øpital intertainment, inquires into the wants of her
ho≈øt; pittyes them, bemones them, where there was power of redre≈ø≈øe; (When the wine failed, the the mother of Ie≈øus ≈øaid vnto him, They haue no wine.) How well doth it be≈øeeme the eyes of piety, and chri≈øtian loue to looke into the nece≈ø≈øities of others? She that conceiued the God of mercies, both in her heart, and in her wombe, doth not fixe her eyes vpon her owne trencher, but ≈øearcheth into the penury of a poore I≈øraelite, and feeles tho≈øe wants, whereof he complaines not; They are made for them≈øelues, who≈øe thoughts are only taken vp with their owne ≈øtore, or indigence.

There was wine enough for a
meale, though not for a fea≈øt: and if there were not wine enough, there was enough water; yet the holy virgin complaines of the want of wine; and is troubled with the very lacke of ≈øuperfluity; The bounty of our God reaches not to our life only, but to our contentment; neither hath hee thought good to allow vs only the bread of ≈øufficiency, but ≈øomtimes of plea≈øure.
