One while that is but nece≈ø≈øary, which ≈øome other time were ≈øuperfluous. It is a ≈øcrupulous iniu≈øtice to ≈øcant our ≈øelues, where God hath bene liberall.

To whom ≈øhould wee complaine of any want, but to the
maker and giuer of all things? The ble≈ø≈øed virgin knew to whom ≈øhe ≈øued; She had good rea≈øon to know the diuine nature and power of her Sonne: Perhaps the Bride-groome was not ≈øo needy, but if not by his pur≈øe, yet by his credit, he might haue ≈øupplyed that want; or, it were hard if ≈øome of the neighbour-gue≈øts (had they bene duly ≈øolicited) might not haue furni≈øhed him with ≈øo much wine, as might ≈øuffice for the la≈øt ≈øeruice of a dinner; but ble≈ø≈øed Mary knew a nearer way; ≈øhe did not thinke be≈øt to lade at the ≈øhallow channell, but runs rather to the well-head, where ≈øhe may dip, and fill the
firkins at once, with ea≈øe. It may bee ≈øhee ≈øaw that the traine of Chri≈øt (which vnbidden followed vnto that fea≈øt, and vnexpectedly added to the number of the gue≈øts) might help forward that defect, and therefore ≈øhe iu≈øtly ≈øolicites her Son Ie≈øus for a ≈øupply: Whether wee want bread, or water, or wine; nece≈ø≈øaries or comforts, whither ≈øhould we runne, √¥ Sauiour, but to that infinite munificence of thine, which neither denieth, nor vpbraideth any thing? We cannot want, wee cannot abound, but from thee, Giue vs what thou wilt, ≈øo thou giue vs contentment with what thou giue≈øt.

O ble≈ø≈øed virgin, if in that heauenly glory wherin thou art, thou can≈øt take notice of the≈øe earthly things, with what indignation, Do≈øt thou looke vpon the pre≈øumptuous ≈øuper≈øtition of vaine men, who≈øe ≈øuits make thee more then a ≈øolicitor of diuine fauours? Thine humanity is not lo≈øt in thy mother-hood, nor in thy glory: The re≈øpects of nature reach not ≈øo high as heauen; It is far from thee to abide
that honour, which is ≈øtolne from thy Redeemer.

There is a marriage, whereto we are inuited, yea, wherein we are already intere≈ø≈øed, not as the gue≈øts only, but as the Bride; in which there ≈øhall be no want of the wine of gladne≈ø≈øe: It is maruell, if in the≈øe earthly banquets there be not ≈øome lacke; In thy pre≈øence, √¥ Sauiour, there is fulne≈ø≈øe of ioy, and at thy right hand are plea≈øures for euermore. Ble≈ø≈øed are they, that are called to the marriage-≈øupper of the Lamb.

Euen in that rough an≈øwer, doth the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin de≈øcry cau≈øe of hope. If his houre were not yet comne, it was therfore
comming; when the expectation of the gue≈øts, and the nece≈ø≈øity of the occa≈øion had made fit roome for the miracle, it ≈øhall come forth, & challenge their wonder. Faithfully therefore, and ob≈øeruantly, doth ≈øhee turne her ≈øpeech from her Son to the Wayters (What≈øoeuer hee ≈øaith vnto you, doe it.) How well doth it be≈øeeme the mother of Chri≈øt to agree with his Father in Heauen, who≈øe voyce from Heauen ≈øayd, This is my welbeloned Son, heare him; She that ≈øayd of her ≈øelfe, Be it vnto mee according to thy word, ≈øaies vnto others, What≈øoeuer hee ≈øaith to you, doe it. This is the way to haue miracles wrought in vs, obedience to his
Word. The power of Chri≈øt did not ≈øtand vpon their officiou≈øne≈ø≈øe; he could haue wrought wonders in ≈øpite of them; but their peruer≈øe refu≈øall of his commands, might haue made them vncapable of the fauour of a miraculous action: Hee that can (when hee will) conuince the ob≈øtinate, will not grace the di≈øobedient. Hee that could worke without vs, or again≈øt vs, will not worke for vs, but by vs.

This very poore hou≈øe, was furni≈øhed with many and large ve≈ø≈øels, for outward purifications; As if ≈øin had dwelt vpon the skin, that ≈øuper≈øtitious people ≈øought holine≈ø≈øe in frequent
wa≈øhings; Euen this rin≈øing fouled them, with the vncleanne≈ø≈øe of a traditionall will-wor≈øhip. It is the ≈øoule which needs ≈øcouring; and nothing can wa≈øh that, but the bloud, which they de≈øperately wi≈øhed vpon them≈øelues, and their children; for guilt, not for expiation. Purge thou vs, √¥ Lord, with hy≈ø≈øop, and we ≈øhall bee cleane, wa≈øh vs and we ≈øhall be whiter then ≈ønow.

The wayters could not but thinke ≈øtrange of ≈øo vn≈øea≈øonable a command; (Fill the waterpots.) It is wine that wee want, what doe we go to fetch water; Doth this holy man mean thus to quench our fea≈øt, and coole
our ≈øtomachs? If there bee no remedy, wee could haue ≈øought this ≈øupply vnbidden; yet ≈øo far hath the charge of Chri≈øts mother preuailed, that in ≈øteede of carrying flagons of wine to the table, they goe to fetch pailesfull of water from the ci≈øternes. It is no pleading of vnlikelyhoods again≈øt the command of an Almighty power.

Hee that could haue created wine immediately in tho≈øe ve≈ø≈øels, will rather turne water into wine; In all the cour≈øe of his mitacles, I doe neuer finde him making out of nothing; all his great workes are grounded vpon former exi≈øtences; he multiplyed the bread, hee changed
the water, he re≈øtored the withered lims, hee ray≈øed the dead; and ≈øtill wrought vpon that which was, and did not make that which was not: What doth he in the ordinary way of nature, but turne the watery iuyce that ari≈øes vp from the root, into wine; he will onely doe this now ≈øuddenly, and at once, which he doth v≈øually by in≈øen≈øible degrees. It is euer duly ob≈øerued by the Son of God, not to doe more miracle then hee needes.

How liberall are the proui≈øions of Chri≈øt? If he had turned but one of tho≈øe ve≈ø≈øels, it had beene a iu≈øt proofe of his power, and perhaps that quantity
had ≈øerued the pre≈øent nece≈ø≈øity; now hee furni≈øheth them with ≈øo much wine, as would haue ≈øerued an hundred and fifty gue≈øts for an intire ≈øea≈øt; Euen the mea≈øure magnifies at once, both his power and mercy. The munificent hand of God, regards not our neede onely, but our hone≈øt affluence: It is our ≈øin and our ≈øhame, if wee turne his fauour into wantonne≈ø≈øe. There mu≈øt be fir≈øt a filling, ere there be a drawing out: Thus, in our ve≈ø≈øels, the fir≈øt care mu≈øt be of our receit; the next, of our expence: God would haue vs ci≈øternes, not channels.

Our Sauiour would not bee his owne ta≈øter, but he ≈øends the
fir≈øt draught to the Gouernour of the fea≈øt. He knew his own power, they did not; Neither would he beare witnes of him≈øelfe, but fetch it out of others mouthes; They that knew not the originall of that wine, yet pray≈øed the ta≈øte; (Euery man at the beginning, doth ≈øet forth good wine, and when men haue well drunk, then that which is wor≈øe, but thou ha≈øt kept the good wine vntill now;) The ≈øame bounty that expre≈ø≈øed it ≈øelfe in the quantity of the wine, ≈øhewes it ≈øelfe no le≈ø≈øe in the excellence: Nothing can fall from that diuine hand not exqui≈øite: That liberality hated to prouide crab-wine for his gue≈øts. It was fit, that the miraculous
effects of Chri≈øt, (which came from his immediate hand) ≈øhould be more perfect, then the naturall. O ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour, how delicate is that new wine, which we ≈øhall one day drinke with thee, in thy Fathers Kingdome. Thou ≈øhalt turne this water of our earthly affliction, into that wine of gladne≈ø≈øe, wherewith our ≈øoules ≈øhall bee ≈øatiate for euer. Make ha≈øte, √¥ my Beloued, and bee thou like to a Roe, or to a young Hart, vpon the mountaine of ≈øpices.

div.head: The good Centurion.
div.p:
EVEN the bloudy trade of warre yeelded worthy Clients to Chri≈øt: This Roman Captaine had learned to beleeue in that Ie≈øus, whom many Iewes de≈øpi≈øed: No nation, no trade, can ≈øhut out a good heart from God: If hee were a Forrainer for birth; yet he was a Dome≈øtique in heart; Hee could not change his bloud, hee could ouer-rule his affections;
Hee loued that Nation, which was cho≈øen of God; and if hee were not of the Synagogue, yet he built a Synagogue; where hee might not bee a Party, hee would be a Benefactor; Next to being good, is a fauouring of goodne≈ø≈øe; We could not loue religion, if we vtterly wanted it: How many true Iewes were not ≈øo zealous? Either will, or ability lacked in them, whom duty more obliged; Good affections doe many times more then ≈øupply nature: Neither doth God regard whence, but what wee are.

I doe not ≈øee this Centurion come to Chri≈øt, as the I≈øraeliti≈øh Captaine came to Elias in Carmel,
but with his cap in his hand, with much ≈øuit, much ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, by others, by him≈øelfe; He ≈øends fir≈øt the Elders of the lewes, whom hee might hope, that their nation & place, might make gracious: then, le≈øt the imployment of others might argue neglect, he ≈øeconds them in per≈øon; Cold and fruitle≈ø≈øe are the motions of frends, where wee doe wilfully ≈øhut vp our owne lips: Importunity cannot but ≈øpeede well in both. Could wee but ≈øpeake for our ≈øoules, as this Captaine did for his ≈øeruant, what could we po≈ø≈øibly want? What maruell is it, if God bee not forward to giue, where wee care not to aske; or
aske, as if wee cared not to receiue? Shall wee yet call this a ≈øuit, or a complaint? I heare no one word of entreaty; The le≈ø≈øe is ≈øayd, the more is concealed, It is enough to lay open his wants; He knew well, that hee had to deale with ≈øo wi≈øe and mercifull a Phy≈øician, as that the opening of the malady was a crauing of cure: If our ≈øpirituall mi≈øeries bee but confe≈ø≈øed, they cannot faile of redre≈ø≈øe.

Great variety of Suitors re≈øorted to Chri≈øt; One comes to him for a ≈øon, another for a daughter, a third for him≈øelfe: I ≈øee none come for his ≈øeruant, but this one Centurion; Neither was hee a better man then a Ma≈øter:
His ≈øeruant is ≈øicke; hee doth not driue him out of doores, but layes him at home; neither doth he ≈øtand gazing by his beds-≈øide, but ≈øeekes forth; He ≈øeekes forth, not to Witches, or Charmers, but to Chri≈øt; he ≈øeekes to Chri≈øt, not with a fa≈øhionable relation, but with a vehement aggrauation of the di≈øea≈øe. Had the Ma≈øter beene ≈øicke, the faithfulle≈øt ≈øeruant could haue done no more: He is vnworthy to bee well ≈øerued, that will not ≈øomtimes wait vpon his followers. Conceits of inferiority, may not breed in vs a neglect of charitable offices; ≈øo mu≈øt we look downe vpon our ≈øeruants, here on earth, as that
wee mu≈øt ≈øtill looke vp to our Ma≈øter, which is in heauen.

But why did≈øt thou not, √¥ Centurion, rather bring thy ≈øeruant to Chri≈øt for cure, then ≈øue for him ab≈øent? There was a Paralytick, whom faith and charity brought to our Sauiour, and let downe thorow the vncouered roofe, in his bed; why was not thine ≈øo carried, ≈øo pre≈øented? Was it out of the ≈øtrength of thy faith, which a≈ø≈øured thee, thou neede≈øt not ≈øhew thy ≈øeruant to him, that ≈øaw all things? One and the ≈øame grace, may yeeld contrary effects; They, becau≈øe they beleeued, brought the Patient to Chri≈øt, thou broughte≈øt not thine to him, becau≈øe
thou beleeued it; Their act argued no le≈ø≈øe de≈øire, thine, more confidence; Thy labour was le≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe thy faith was more: Oh, that I could come thus to my Sauiour, and make ≈øuch mone to him for my ≈øelfe: Lord, my ≈øoule is ≈øicke of vnbeleefe, ≈øicke of ≈øelfe-loue, ≈øicke of inordinate de≈øires, I ≈øhould not neede to ≈øay more; Thy mercy, √¥ Sauiour, would not then ≈øtay for my ≈øuit, but would preuent me (as here) with a gracious ingagement, I will come and heale thee; I did not heare the Centurion ≈øay, Either come, or heale him; The one he meant, though hee ≈øayd not, the other, he neither ≈øayd, nor meant: Chri≈øt
ouer-giues, both his words and intentions; It is the manner of that diuine munificence, where he meets with a faithfull ≈øuitor, to giue more then is reque≈øted; to giue when he is not reque≈øted. The very in≈øinuations of our nece≈ø≈øit ‚Ä¢ es are no le≈ø≈øe violent, then ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull: Wee thinke the mea≈øure of humane bounty, runs ouer, when we obtaine but what wee aske with importunity; that infinite goodne≈ø≈øe keeps within bounds, when it ouer-flowes the de≈øires of our hearts.

As he ≈øaid, ≈øo hee did; The word of Chri≈øt ei ‚Ä¢ her is his act, or concurres with it; He did not ≈øtand ≈øtill when hee ≈øaid, I will
come, but hee went as hee ≈øpake. When the ruler intreated him for his ≈øonne (Come downe ere hee dye) our Sauiour ≈øtird not a foote; The Centurion did but complaine of the ≈øicknes of his ≈øeruant, and Chri≈øt vnasked, ≈øaies, I will come and heale him; That he might be farre from ≈øo much as ≈øeeming to honor wealth, and de≈øpi≈øe meanene≈ø≈øe, he that came in the ≈øhape of a ≈øeruant, would goe downe to the ≈øicke ≈øeruants pallet, would not goe to the bed of the rich rulers ≈øonne; It is the ba≈øe≈øt motiue of re≈øpect, that ari≈øeth merely from outward greatne≈ø≈øe. Either more grace, or more need, may iu≈øtly challenge our fauourable
regards, no le≈ø≈øe then priuate obligations.

Euen ≈øo, √¥ Sauiour, that which thou offered≈øt to doe for the Centurions ≈øeruant, ha≈øt thou done for vs; We were ≈øick vnto death; So farre had the dead pal≈øy of ≈øinne ouertaken vs, that there was no light of grace left in vs; When thou wert not content to ≈øit ≈øtill in heauen, and ≈øay, I will cure them; but adde≈øt al≈øo, I will come and cure them; Thy ≈øelfe came downe accordingly to this mi≈øerable world, and ha≈øt per≈øonally healed vs; So as now we ≈øhall not dye but liue, and declare thy works, √¥ Lord; And oh! that we could enough prai≈øe that loue and mercy, which
hath ≈øo graciou≈øly aba≈øed thee, and could be but ≈øo low deiected before thee, as thou ha≈øt ≈øtooped low vnto vs; that we could be but as lowly ≈øubiects of thy goodne≈ø≈øe, as wee are vnworthy.

Oh admirable returne of humility: Chri≈øt will goe downe to vi≈øit the ≈øicke ≈øeruant; the ma≈øter of that ≈øeruant ≈øayes, Lord I am not worthy that thou ≈øhould≈øt come vnder my roofe: The Iewi≈øh Elders, that went before to mediate for him, could ≈øay, (He is worthy that thou ≈øhould≈øt doe this for him; but the Centurion, when hee comes to ≈øpeake for him≈øelfe (I am not worthy) They ≈øaid, He was worthy of Chri≈øts
miracle; He ≈øaies hee is vnworthy of Chri≈øts pre≈øence: There is great difference betwixt others valuations, and our owne; Sometimes the world vnderrates him that findes rea≈øon to ≈øet an high price vpon him≈øelfe; Somtimes againe, it ouer-values a man that knowes iu≈øt cau≈øe of his owne humiliation; If others mi≈øtake vs, this can be no warrant for our error; Wee cannot be wi≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe wee receiue the knowledge of our ≈øelues by direct beames, not by reflection; vnle≈ø≈øe we haue learned to contemne vniu≈øt applau≈øes; and ≈øcorning the flatteryes of the world, to frowne vpon our owne vilene≈ø≈øe, Lord I am not worthy.

Many a one if he had bene in the Centurions cote, would haue thought well of it; A Captaine, a man of good ability and command, a founder of a Synagogue, a Patron of religion: yet he ouerlookes all the≈øe, and when he ca≈øts his eye vpon the diuine worth of Chri≈øt, and his owne weakene≈ø≈øe, he ≈øaies, I am not worthy; Alas Lord I am a Gentile, an alien, a man of blood, thou art holy, thou art omnipotent. True humility will teach vs to finde out the be≈øt of another, and the wor≈øt peece of our ≈øelues; Pride contrarily ≈øhowes vs nothing, but matter of admiration in our ≈øelues; in others, of contempt. Whiles hee confe≈øt him≈øelfe vnworthy
of any fauour; he approued him≈øelfe worthy of all. Had not Chri≈øt bene before in his heart, hee could not haue thought him≈øelfe vnworthy to intertaine that gue≈øt within his hou≈øe; Vnder the low roofe of an humble bre≈øt, doth God euer delight to dwel; The ≈øtare of his Pallace may not bee mea≈øured by the height, but by the depth: Brags & bold faces do oft-times carry it away with men, nothing preuailes with God, but our voluntary deiections.

It is fit the foundations ≈øhould be laid deep, where the building is high; The centurions humility was not more lowe; then his faith was lofty; that reaches
vp into heauen, and in the face of humane weakne≈ø≈øe de≈øcrye omnipotence; Only ≈øay the word, and my ≈øeruant ≈øhall be whole.

Had the Centurions roof ‚Ä¢ bene heauen it ≈øelfe, it could not haue bene worthy to be comne vnder, of him, who≈øe word was almighty, and who was the Almighty word of his Father, Such is Chri≈øt confe≈ø≈øed by him that ≈øaies Only ≈øay the word; none, but a diuine power is vnlimited; neither hath faith any other bounds then God him≈øelfe. There needs no footing to remoue mountaines, or Deuills, but a word; Doe but ≈øay the word, √¥ Sauiour, my ≈øinne ≈øhall be remitted; my ≈øoule ≈øhall bee
healed, my body ≈øhall be ray≈øed from du≈øt; both ≈øoule and body ≈øhall be glorious.

Whereupon then was the ≈øteddy confidence of the Good Centurion? He ≈øaw how powerfull his own word was with tho≈øe, that were vnder his command, (though him≈øelfe were vnder the command of another) the force whereof extended euen to ab≈øent performances; well therefore might he argue, that a free and vnbounded power, might giue infallible commands, and that the mo≈øt ob≈øtinate di≈øea≈øe, mu≈øt therfore needs yeild to the becke of the God of nature: weakene≈ø≈øe may ≈øhow vs what is in ≈øtrength; By one
drop of water we may ≈øee what is in the maine Ocean; I maruell not if the Centurion were kinde to his ≈øeruants, for they were dutifull to him; he can but ≈øay, Doe this, and it is done; the≈øe mutuall re≈øpects draw on each other; cheerefull and diligent ≈øeruice in the one, calls for a due and fauourable care in the other; they that neglect to plea≈øe, cannot complaine to bee neglected.

Oh that I could be but ≈øuch a ≈øeruant to mine heauenly Ma≈øter; Alas, euery of his commands, ≈øayes, Doe this, and I doe it not; Euery of his inhibitions ≈øayes, Doe it not, and I doe it, He ≈øayes, Goe from the world, I run to it; he ≈øayes, Come to mee, I runne
from him: Woe is mee, this is not ≈øeruice, but enmity; how can I looke for fauour, whiles I returne rebellion; It is a gracious Ma≈øter whom wee ≈øerue; there can bee no duty of ours, that he ≈øees not, that he acknowledges not, that he crownes not; we could not but be happy, if we could be officious.

What can be more maruelous then to ≈øee Chri≈øt maruell? All maruelling ≈øuppo≈øes an ignorance going before, and a knowledge following ≈øome accident vnexpected: now who wrought this faith in the Centurion, but he that wondred at it? Hee knew well what hee wrought, becau≈øe hee wrought
what he would; yet he wondred at what he both wrought, and knew, to teach vs, much more to admire that which hee at once knowes and holds admirable.

Hee wrought this faith as God, he wondred at it as man; God wrought, and man admired, he that was both, did both; to teach vs where to be≈øtow our wonder. I neuer finde Chri≈øt wondring at gold, or ≈øiluer, at the co≈øtly and curious workes of humane skill or indu≈øtry; Yea, when the Di≈øciples wondred at the magnificence of the Temple, he rebuked them rather: I finde him not wondring at the frame of heauen
and earth, nor at the orderly di≈øpo≈øition of all creatures and euents; the familiarity of the≈øe things intercepts the admiration; But when he ≈øees the grace or acts of faith, he ≈øo approues them, that he is raui≈øhed with wonder; Hee that reioyced in the view of his creation, to ≈øee that of nothing, he had made all things good, reioyces no le≈ø≈øe in the reformation of his creature, to ≈øee, that hee hath made good of euill: Behold thou art faire, my loue, behold thou art faire, and there is no ≈øpot in thee; My ≈øi≈øter, my ≈øpou≈øe, thou ha≈øt wounded my heart, thou ha≈øt wounded my heart with one of thine eyes.

Our wealth, beauty, wit, learning, honor may make vs accepted of men, but it is our faith only, that ≈øhall make God in loue with vs; And why are we of any other ≈øaue Gods diet, to bee more affected with the lea≈øt mea≈øure of grace in any man, then withall the outward glories of the world? There are great men whom we iu≈øtly pitty, we can admire none but the gracious.

Neither was that plant more worthy of wonder in it ≈øelfe, then that it grew in ≈øuch a ≈øoyle, with ≈øo little help of raine and Sun; The weakne≈ø≈øe of meanes, addes to the pray≈øe and acceptation of our proficiency: To do
good vpon a little is the commendation of thrift; it is ≈ømall thanke to bee full-handed in a large e≈øtate; As contrarily, the ≈øtrength of meanes doubles the reuenge of our neglect: It is not more the ≈øhame of I≈ørael, then the glory of the Centurion, that our Sauiour ≈øayes, I haue not found ≈øo great faith in I≈ørael; Had I≈ørael yeelded any equal faith, it could not haue beene vne≈øpyed of tho≈øe all-≈øeeing eyes; yet were their helps ≈øo much greater, then their faith was le≈ø≈øe; and God neuer giues more then hee requires: Where we haue laid our tillage, and compo≈øt, and ≈øeed, who would not looke for a crop? but if the vncultured fallow
yeeld more, how iu≈øtly is that vnan≈øwerable ground neer to a cur≈øe?

Our Sauiour did not mutter this cen≈øorious te≈øtimony to him≈øelfe, nor whi≈øper it to his Di≈øciples, but he turned him about to the people, and ≈øpake it in their eares, that hee might at once worke their ≈øhame and emulation: In all other things, except ≈øpirituall, our ≈øelfe-loue makes vs impatient of equals, much le≈ø≈øe can we indure to bee out-≈øtripped by tho≈øe, who are our profe≈ø≈øed inferiours. It is well, if any thing can kindle in vs holy ambitions: Dull and ba≈øe are the ≈øpirits of that man, that can abide to ≈øee another
ouertake him in the way, and out-run him to Heauen.

Hee that both wrought this faith, and wondred at it, doth now reward it, Goe thy wayes, and as thou ha≈øt beleeued, ≈øo bee it vnto thee; Neuer was any faith vn≈øeene of Chri≈øt, neuer was any ≈øeene without allowance, neuer was any allowed without remuneration: The mea≈øure of our receits in the matter of fauour, is the proportion of our beleefe; The infinite mercy of God (which is euer like it ≈øelfe) followes but one rule in his gifts to vs, the faith that he giues vs: Giue vs, √¥ God, to beleeue, and bee it to vs as thou wilt; it ≈øhall bee to vs aboue that we will.

The Centurion ≈øues for his ≈øeruant, and Chri≈øt ≈øayes, So bee it vnto thee; The ≈øeruants health is the benefit of the Ma≈øter; and the Ma≈øters faith is the health of the ≈øeruant; And if the prayers of an earthly ma≈øter, preuailed ≈øo much with the Sonne of God, for the recouery of a ≈øeruant, how ≈øhall the interce≈ø≈øion of the Son of God, preuaile with his Father in Heauen, for vs that are his impotent children and ≈øeruants vpon earth? What can we want, √¥ Sauiour, whiles thou ≈øue≈øt for vs? Hee that hath giuen thee for vs, can deny thee nothing for vs, can deny vs nothing for thee; In thee we are happy, and ≈øhall be
glorious; To thee, √¥ thou mighty Redeemer of I≈ørael, with thine eternall Father, together with thy ble≈ø≈øed Spirit, one God infinite, and incomprehen≈øible, be giuen all prai≈øe, honour, and glory, for euer and euer. AMEN.
